PREFACE 
This Code, Volumes I and II, constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Titusville, Florida. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1963 Code, as supplemented through May 8, 1990, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1963 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code, Volume I, have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. The land development regulations are printed in Volume II. 
Numbering System 
The numbering system used in this Code, Volume I, is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of Chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. 
Indexes 
The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Alyce A. Whitson, Supervising Editor, and Ron McLaughlin, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Dwight Severs, City Attorney, Karan Rounsavall, CMC, Deputy City Clerk, and the other members of the city staff, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
	MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 31-1992 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Charter and Code for the City of Titusville, Florida; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall become Effective: 
Be It Enacted by the City of Titusville, Florida as follows: 
Section 1. The Charter and the Code contained in the "Code of Ordinances, City of Titusville, Florida" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of the Charter and Chapters 1 through 63, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. All Charter provisions and ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before June 9, 1992, and not included in the Charter and Code or recognized and continued in force by reference in the Charter and Code and in this section are repealed. 
The following sections appearing in the Code of Ordinances, 1963, and any ordinances amending such provisions, are hereby saved from repeal: 
*Chapter 13A, Marinas 
Section 22-4, New streets 
Section 25A-1, 25A-2, Titusville Environmental Commission established 
*Section 27-2(a), Location of mobile homes and parks … 
*Section 27-3, Mobile home parks, building permit requirement 
*Section 27-9, Travel trailers, camper trailers, cargo trailers, boat trailers 
Section 29-37, Off-site improvements 
*Section 29-59, Real estate sales offices 
*Section 29-62, Trailers, mobile homes—special exception 
Section 29-63, Outdoor recreation and entertainment 
Section 29-65, Flea markets 
*Section 29-68, Temporary auto sales or shows 
Section 29-95, Parking large trucks and heavy equipment 
*Section 29-107, Principal building on a lot 
*Section 29-108, Permitted building area 
Section 29-111, Subdivision of lots 
*The following sections had been saved from repeal. Subsequently, these sections have been recodified as follows: 
Sections 13A-2, 13A-4, 13A-5, 13A-7—13A-9 as sections 59-410—59-415 
Sections 13A-1, 13A-3, 13A-6 have been deleted. 
Section 27-2(a) as Section 59-209(j) 
Section 27-3 as Section 59-210 
Section 27-9 as Section 20-58 
Section 29-59 as Section 59-38(b) 
Section 29-62 as Section 59-10 
Section 29-68 as Section 11-500 
Section 29-107 as Section 59-40 
Section 29-108 has been deleted by Ord. No. 5-1998 
Section 29-116, Arthur Dunn Airport 
Section 29-125, Minimum setback from centerline of streets 
Section 29-198(a), (b), Business districts 
Section 29-260, Special uses—public 
Section 3. It is the intention of this Ordinance not to repeal all ordinances not presently codified and all zoning and rezoning ordinances and comprehensive plan adoption ordinances and each shall remain in force and effect. 
Section 4. The repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not be constructed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this Ordinance. 
Section 5. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or a term of imprisonment not exceeding sixty (60) days, or both. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this Section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the City may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 6. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the City Council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 7. Ordinances adopted after June 9, 1992, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 8. Effective date. This Ordinances shall take effect immediately upon adoption. 
Passed and adopted this 15th day of December, 1992. 
	/s/ Thomas R. Mariani 
      Thomas R. Mariani, Mayor

/s/ Janet R. Camacho 
      Janet R. Camacho, Clerk 	
 	 
 
PART I - CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— The City of Titusville was originally incorporated on July 13, 1887 (Miscellaneous Record, Brevard County, Book A, pp. 229—318). This incorporation was validated by Ch. 3784, Act 1887. Laws of Fla., ch. 63-2001 is the present Charter of the city which became effective June 3, 1963. This Charter is printed herein as Part I, Subpart A of this Code volume as adopted, except the divisions of the several sections have been renumbered and relettered for the utility of the user and for purposes of simplifying the indexing thereof, so that the first divisions (or subsections) bear numbers and the next divisions (paragraphs) bear letters. Obviously misspelled words have been corrected without notation. Words added for clarification have been added in brackets. Amendments have been included and are indicated by a history note immediately following the amended section. 
 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1. - Abolish existing municipalities. 
That the existing municipal government of the Town of Whispering Hills Golf Estates, in the County of Brevard and State of Florida, and the existing municipal government of the City of Titusville, in the County of Brevard and State of Florida, be and the same are hereby abolished. All books and records of the Municipality of the Town of Whispering Hills Golf Estates hereby abolished shall be immediately delivered by the municipal officials to the clerk of the City of Titusville to be by him filed and preserved.  
Sec. 2. - Title to property reserved. 
That the title, rights and ownership of all property, both real and personal, uncollected taxes, dues, claims, judgments, decrees, choses in action and all property and property rights held or owned by the municipality named "City of Titusville," abolished by this act, shall pass to and be vested in the municipal corporation organized under this charter to succeed the municipality abolished. 
That the title, rights, and ownership of all property, both real and personal, uncollected taxes, dues, claims, judgments, decrees, choses in action and all property and property rights held or owned by the municipality named "Town of Whispering Hills Golf Estates," abolished by this act, shall pass to and be vested in the municipal corporation organized under this charter to succeed the municipality abolished.  
Sec. 3. - Obligations unimpaired. 
That no obligations or contracts of the said municipalities hereby abolished, including bonds and revenue certificates heretofore issued or any proceeding heretofore begun for any improvement, or for the borrowing of money, or issuing of bonds or revenue certificates, shall be impaired or avoided by this charter, but such debts, obligations, contracts, bonds and revenue certificates shall pass to and be binding upon the municipality hereby created and organized, and all such proceedings heretofore begun for the construction of any improvements or for the borrowing of money or issuing of bonds or revenue certificates may be continued and completed and binding upon the said new municipality and shall be valid against the new municipality created provided, however, that only that property which was subject to the ad valorem bonded indebtedness of the City of Titusville abolished shall be subject to the ad valorem bonded indebtedness in the City of Titusville established.  
Sec. 4. - Mayor and city council. 
The mayor and city councilmen of the said municipality hereby created with the expiration dates of their terms are as follows: 
1. 	Edwin H. Willis, Councilman 	September 15, 1964 
2. 	William H. Laing, Mayor 	September 10, 1963 
3. 	Ed Kittles, Councilman 	September 15, 1964 
4. 	Millard Finch, Councilman 	September 10, 1963 
5. 	James Pritchard, Councilman 	September 15, 1964 
 
The said mayor and councilmen shall serve until their successors are elected and qualified under the provisions of this charter. 
All officers and employees heretofore elected or appointed and holding office under the said municipality of the City of Titusville hereby abolished, other than the mayor and city councilmen of same, shall continue to hold their respective offices and discharge the respective duties thereof under the new municipality hereby created until their successors are appointed or elected and qualified under the provisions of this charter. 
Cross reference— Creation, composition, term, election of city council, § 11.  
Sec. 5. - Ordinances not impaired. 
All existing ordinances and resolutions of the said abolished municipality of the City of Titusville, Florida, including the "Revised Ordinances of the City of Titusville, Florida of 1953," as since amended, not in conflict with the provisions of this Charter, shall continue in effect as the ordinances of the new municipality hereby created.  
Sec. 6. - Establishment of new municipality. 
The inhabitants of the City of Titusville, as its boundaries are hereinafter established and designated, or as may hereafter be established and designated, shall continue to be a body politic and corporate, to be known and designated as "City of Titusville," and as such shall have perpetual succession, may use a common seal, may contract and be contracted with, and may sue and be sued in all courts of this state and in all matters whatsoever.  
Sec. 7. - Boundaries; corporate limits. 
Editor's note— The current boundary description of the city is on file in the city clerk's office. Section 7 of the Charter, prior to 1973, had been amended by Sp. Act Chapters 65-2328, § 1(1); 67-2138, § 1; 72-706, § 1.  
Sec. 8. - Acts repealed. 
All the provisions of Chapter 26315, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1949; Chapter 29571, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1953; Chapter 31321, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1955; Chapter 31490, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1956; Chapters 57-1175 and 57-1916, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1957; Chapters 59-1928, 59-1929, 59-1930, 59-1931, 59-1932, 59-1934, 59-1935, and 59-1991, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1959; Chapters 61-2945, 61-2946, 61-2947, and 61-2997, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1961; all pertaining to the existing municipal governments of the City of Titusville and Whispering Hills Golf Estates, be and the same are hereby repealed.  
Sec. 9. - Change of name. 
[Editorially deleted] 
Editor's note— This section has been editorially deleted as superseded by the procedure for amending Charters in F.S. § 166.031.  
Sec. 10. - Form of government. 
The council government provided by this charter shall be known as the "Council-Manager Government." Pursuant to its provisions and subject only to the limitations imposed by the state constitution and by this charter, all powers of the city shall be vested in an elective council, hereinafter referred to as "the council," which shall enact local legislation, adopt budgets, determine policies, and appoint the city manager, who shall execute the laws and administer the government of the city. All powers of the city shall be exercised in the manner prescribed by this charter, or if the manner be not prescribed, then in such manner as may be prescribed by ordinances.  
Sec. 11. - General powers of the city. 
[The] City of Titusville hereby created, established and organized shall have full power and authority: 
(1)  Taxes and assessments. [Editorially deleted] 
(2)  Utility taxes. [Editorially deleted] 
(3)  Occupational licenses. [Editorially deleted] 
(4)  Liquor license. [Editorially deleted] 
(5)  Personal property taxes against private individuals upon public lands. [Editorially deleted] 
(6)  Acquisition of property. To acquire by purchase, gift, exchange, lease-purchase, devise, condemnation, lease or otherwise, real or personal property or any estate therein, or riparian rights or easements therein, within or without the city, to be used for any municipal purpose, including all municipal or public buildings, streets and highways; bridge and tunnel sites; plants, works and wells and other equipment necessary for supplying said city with water, gas for illuminating and heating purposes, and electric power for illuminating, heating or power purposes; the location of waterworks and sites for public utility works; the establishment of poor houses, houses of detention and correction; hospitals for the cure or detention of the sick; jails; market houses, public parks, playgrounds, airports, docks, sea walls, yacht harbors, wharves, warehouses, promenades; plants for cremating, neutralizing or otherwise destroying sewerage, garbage and refuse; for extension of sewer and drainage pipes and water mains; and to improve, sell, lease, pledge or otherwise dispose of same or any part thereof for the benefit of the city, to the same extent that natural persons might do, in the proper manner at any regular or special meeting of the council.

To acquire by purchase, gift, devise, condemnation, exchange, lease or otherwise real or personal property or any estate or interest therein, located within or without the corporate limits, and on same build, repair, improve, construct, own, operate and maintain any and all manner of recreational facilities and any and all necessary or convenient appurtenances or aids in connection therewith.

To purchase, acquire, lease, take hold, establish, construct, equip, maintain and operate municipal airports, landing fields, hangars, aviation terminals and administration buildings, runways, depots, warehouses, garages, repair shops, oil and fuel tank or stations, or other necessary appurtenances for the use of airplane and other aircraft, and to acquire or lease any and all real property within or without the corporate limits, for such purposes; to set apart and use for such purpose any real property owned or leased by the city, whether or not originally acquired by condemnation, purchase or lease for another purpose; to adopt and enforce reasonable rules and regulations governing the use of such municipal airports; to employ airport directors, airport managers, employees or agents in connection with such operation; to impose fees or charges in connection with the use of such airport or airport facilities; to sell gasoline or other supplies necessary in connection with the operation of such airports; to provide lounges, eating places, refreshment parlors and other facilities in connection with such municipal airports; to let or lease to private persons or corporations portions of the said airports for building sites, hangar space, nonpublic uses, industrial development, concessions or other uses; to prescribe and promulgate reasonable rules and regulations for the operation of such airports, and to exercise supervision and control of such operation; to accept and receive grants from the state and federal governments and any body politic for the construction, maintenance, operation and management of such airport facilities. 
(9)  Hospitals. [Editorially deleted] 
(10)  Public libraries. [Editorially deleted] 
(11)  Golf courses. To acquire, construct, own and operate a golf course or golf courses and all such buildings and improvements as said city may deem necessary or desirable for use in connection therewith, within or outside the limits of said city, and to sell same when deemed unprofitable to operate, or expedient to do so; to use any lands now owned by said city for the purpose of golf course or golf courses, and to acquire by purchase, lease, condemnation or otherwise for such purposes and lands within or outside the limits of said city as it may deem necessary or desirable; to charge reasonable admissions, rentals or fees for the use of and enjoyment of such golf course or golf courses by the users thereof; to prescribe reasonable rules and regulations for the use and operation thereof; to lease any portion or all of any municipal golf course upon terms deemed beneficial to the city. 
(12)  Cemeteries. The City of Titusville is hereby authorized and empowered to acquire, own, maintain and operate a cemetery or cemeteries within or without the corporate limits of the city for the burial and memorialization of the dead and activities incidental and convenient thereto; to issue bonds or revenue certificates for the purposes of obtaining money to establish or improve said facilities in the same manner as other bonds or revenue certificates are provided for in the Charter of the City of Titusville; to establish and administer an endowment or perpetual care fund for the maintenance of said cemetery or cemeteries to be made up by depositing a portion of the moneys received from the sale of lots or plots, and accept gifts to be deposited in said fund; to regulate the uniformity, class and kind of all markers and memorials within the cemetery or cemeteries; to erect, maintain and operate chapels, buildings, workshops, green houses, nurseries and other incidental buildings and equipment; to sell burial lots and burial rights and all things incidental thereto; and to do any and all things necessary or incidental to the accomplishment of any of such purposes.

Such "Revised Ordinances of the City of Titusville, Florida, of 1953," as amended from time to time, may be revised and codified or re-codified, and such revised Code may be adopted by a single ordinance, and upon such revision shall be in full force and effect. [The] city may arrange with any corporation or agency for keeping said Code of ordinances up to date. 
(43)  Enforcing ordinances. [Editorially deleted] 
(44)  Powers of local self-government. To exercise all of the powers of local self-government and to do whatever may be deemed necessary or proper for the safety, health, convenience or general welfare of the inhabitants of said city, to exercise full police power; to expend moneys to advertise and publicize the city; to do and perform all acts and things permitted by the laws of the State of Florida, and comprehended as duties in the performance of any thing recognized as a "Municipal Purpose," whether now existing and recognized, or hereafter recognized as a municipal purpose by statute law or court decision. 
(45)  All powers customarily exercised by municipalities. The enumeration of particular powers by this Charter shall not be held or deemed to be exclusive, but in addition to the powers enumerated herein, implied thereby, or appropriate to the exercise thereof, the City of Titusville shall have and may exercise all other powers which under the constitution and laws of Florida it would be competent for this paragraph specifically to enumerate. 
(46)  Declared municipal purposes. All public improvements authorized in this Charter are hereby determined and declared to be public municipal functions, and all of the acts authorized to be done and performed in connection therewith are hereby designated and declared to be for a public, municipal purpose. In connection with providing funds for the payment of any or all of the cost of construction of any project or public improvement recognized or designated as a "Municipal Purpose," the city may use, appropriate or pledge any revenues of the city available for such purpose, including the power, rights and authority to use or pledge the proceeds of utilities service taxes, franchise taxes and cigarette taxes. 
(Ord. No. 6-1979, § 1, 1-23-79) 
Editor's note— Parts of this section have been editorially deleted as the home rule powers of a municipality other than extraterritorial powers which shall be by general or special law are derived from the Constitution and F.S. ch. 166. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule powers, F.S. § 166.021; authority for borrowing, F.S. § 166.101 et seq.; authority to levy certain taxes, F.S. § 166.201 et seq.; eminent domain authority, F.S. § 166.400; ad valorem taxes, F.S. ch. 192 et seq.; occupational license tax authority, F.S. ch. 205; regulating railroads, F.S. ch. 551; weight and measures standards, F.S. ch. 552; minimum building standards and regulations, F.S. ch. 553.  
ARTICLE II. - THE COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Code of ethics, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public records, F.S. ch. 119; public meetings, F.S. ch. 286. 
 
Sec. 12. - Establishment of governing body; term of office; determining the mayor's seat; and providing for effective date. 
The governing body of the city, which will exercise all the legislative and jurisdictional powers of the city, shall be composed of five (5) members of the city council, four (4) of whom shall be council members and one (1) shall be the mayor. The mayor shall be elected by the majority of the votes cast by the qualified electors of the City at large. Each of the four (4) council members shall be elected by the majority of the votes cast by the qualified electors casting ballots at the election of the entire municipality. The term of office of the mayor and city council members shall be for a period of four (4) years. There are hereby created five (5) election seats in the city, such seats being numbered one (1) to five (5) inclusive. 
Seats 1, 2, 3 and 5 shall be council seats. Seat 4 shall be the mayor's seat. Seats 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 shall consist of the entire municipality. 
Beginning with the regular or general election to be held in 1992 and future elections thereafter, the following shall apply: 
For the year 1992, the council member for seat 2 shall be elected and serve for a term of four (4) years. The mayor elected from seat 4 shall serve for a period of four (4) years. 
For the year 1994, the council member so elected from seats 1, 3 and 5 shall serve for a term of four (4) years. 
Beginning with the regular or general election in 1992 and future elections thereafter in the event more than two (2) candidates qualify for a particular council seat or mayoral seat, then in that event, the candidate's election shall be held on the Tuesday nine weeks prior to the general election or such other date as established by applicable general law of the state for primary elections. 
If no candidate receives a majority of the votes cast, a runoff election shall be held between the two (2) candidates with the highest number of votes cast to be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November in each applicable year. If a candidate receives a majority of the votes cast for council member or mayor said candidate shall be so elected. 
If only two (2) candidates qualify for a council seat or mayoral seat then in that event the election shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each applicable year. 
If only one candidate qualifies for a council seat or mayoral seat, said candidate shall be deemed elected. 
Newly elected council members and mayor shall take office on the fourth Tuesday in the month of November following their election. 
(Ord. No. 24-1971, § 2, 9-9-71; Ord. No. 46-1972, § 1, 7-25-72; Ord. No. 6-1980, § 2, 1-22-80; Ord. No. 60-1981, § 1, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 68-1985, § 6, 9-17-85; Ord. No. 40-1991, § 1, 11-26-91; Ord. No. 3-1998, § 1, 1-27-98)  
Sec. 13. - Qualifications and disqualifications. 
Members of the city council shall be and shall have been residents of the city for one year, and shall have the qualifications of electors in the city. Members of the city council shall not hold any other elective public office. Any member of the city council or mayor who cease to possess the qualifications of being a resident of the city or qualifications of electors shall forfeit their office automatically. Members of the city council may be suspended or removed as provided for by state law. Absence from four (4) consecutive regular and/or special meetings of the city council shall operate to vacate the seat by the city council member, unless excused by the city council by motion. Any illness of a member of the city council or their immediate family member that interferes with a council member's ability to attend meetings, shall count as an excused absence unless the absence continues for more than three (3) months after which time the council may grant additional excused absences. 
(Sp. Acts, Ch. 67-2138, § 2; Ord. No. 60-1981, § 2, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 2, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 14. - Presiding officer; mayor. 
The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the city council, shall be recognized as head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes and by the governor for purposes of military law, and shall when directed to do so by the city council execute all instruments to which the city is a party, unless otherwise provided by this Charter or by ordinance, but shall have no regular administrative duties. The mayor shall have a vote as a council member on any matters coming before the council. The city council shall elect a vice-mayor who shall act as mayor during the absence or disability of the mayor. If a vacancy occurs in the mayor or any city council seats, it shall be filled by the remaining council members for the completion of the unexpired term or until the next regularly scheduled city council election (provided the vacancy occurs prior to the time period for qualifying), whichever is the shortest period of time. The vice-mayor shall be elected from among the city council at its organizational meeting each year or such other date as established by the City Council and shall hold office for a term of one year or until his successor is elected and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 24-1971, § 3, 9-9-71; Ord. No. 9-1998, §§ 1, 3, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 35-2013, § 1, 12-10-13)  
Sec. 14-A. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 3 of Ord. No. 60-1981, adopted Sept. 22, 1981, repealed § 14-A, concerning recall elections. The deleted section derived from Ord. No. 24-1971, § 5, adopted Sept. 9, 1971, and Ord. No. 46-1972, § 2, adopted July 25, 1972.  
Sec. 15. - Powers. 
All powers of the city and the determination of all matters of policy shall be vested in the council. The city council may by ordinance or resolution prescribe the manner in which any power of said city shall be exercised. Without limitation of the foregoing, the council shall have the power to: 
(1)  Appoint and remove the city manager; 
(2)  Appoint and remove the city attorney; 
(3)  [Editorially deleted] 
(4)  Establish other administrative departments and distribute the work of divisions within the departments; 
(5)  Adopt the budget of the city. 
(6)  Appoint city auditor. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 4, 2-10-98) 
Editor's note— The appointment of a municipal judge has been editorially deleted as municipal courts were abolished by Fla. Const., art. V, § 20.  
Sec. 16. - Appointment of city manager. 
The council shall appoint an officer of the city who shall have the title of city manager and shall have the powers and perform the duties of this Charter. No council member shall receive such appointment during the term for which he shall have been elected, nor within one year after the expiration of his term. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 1, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 17. - Removal of city manager. 
The council shall appoint the city manager for an indefinite term and may remove him by a majority vote of its members. If removed at any time after having served six (6) months, the city manager may demand written charges and a public hearing upon the same before the council, and his final removal shall not take effect until such hearing has been had, but the council may suspend him from office pending such hearing.  
Sec. 18. - Council not to interfere in appointments or removals. 
Neither the council nor any of its members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to, or his removal from office by the city manager or by any of his subordinates or in any manner take part in the appointment or removal of officers and employees in the administrative service of the city. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the council and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely through the city manager and neither the council nor any member thereof shall give orders to any subordinates of the city manager, either publicly or privately.  
Sec. 19. - Vacancies in the city council. 
If any vacancy occurs in the city council, the remaining members of the city council shall elect within 15 days by the affirmative votes of not less than three members, an eligible person to fill vacancy until the next general election, at which time the office shall be filled for the unexpired term.  
Sec. 20. - Annual organization meeting. 
On the fourth Tuesday of November, the existing city council shall meet at the usual place for holding the meetings of the legislative body of the city, for the purpose of transacting any and all necessary business before assumption of office by the newly elected council member if an election had occurred in that year. At 11:00 o'clock a.m. Eastern Standard Time the newly elected city council shall assume the duties of office. If there was no election, the City Council shall select the vice mayor during the regular City Council meeting held on the fourth Tuesday in November or such other date as established by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 1, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 35-2013, § 2, 12-10-13)  
Sec. 21. - Regular meetings. 
The city council shall meet regularly at such times as may be specified by ordinance, except that it shall meet regularly not less than once each month. 
State Law reference— Public meetings, F.S. ch. 286.  
Sec. 22. - Special meetings; how called. 
Special meetings of the city council will be scheduled by motion of any council member and passed by a majority of the members present at a regular or special council meeting. The mayor or city manager can schedule a special council meeting if in their judgment a meeting is necessary. Any council member may request the city manager to schedule a special meeting. In all cases a twenty-four (24) hour public notice must be posted and notice given to all council members verbally and in writing at their home or business and if unavailable by delivery of a notice to their home. All official meetings of the city council shall be public and any citizen shall have access to the minutes and records thereof during the regularly scheduled hours that city hall is opened. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 4, 2-10-98) 
State Law reference— Public meetings, F.S. ch. 286.  
Sec. 23. - Legislative procedure. 
A quorum must exist as determined by the city attorney or in his absence, the city manager to convene an official city council meeting. A quorum will include at least three city council members present to convene an official city council meeting. All meetings of the city council will be either regular or special meetings. The affirmative vote of three (3) members shall be necessary to adopt any ordinance or resolution and the passage of all ordinances and resolutions shall be taken by "yes" and "no" and entered upon the minutes. 
(Sp. Acts, Ch. 63-2001, § 23; Ord. No. 24-1971, § 1, 9-9-71; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 5, 2-10-98) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 24-1971, § 1, amended § 23 to read as set out. Said amendment was approved at a referendum held Sept. 7, 1971, pursuant to Ord. No. 21-1971. 
State Law reference— Procedure for adoption of ordinances, F.S. § 166.041.  
Sec. 24. - Council to be judge of qualifications of its members. 
The city council shall be the judge of the election and qualifications of its members as established by the charter and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 6, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 25. - Rules of procedure; journal. 
The council shall determine its own rules and order of business. It shall keep a minutes of its proceedings and the meetings shall be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 7, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 26. - Ordinances and resolutions. 
Every proposed ordinance or resolution shall be introduced in typewritten, written or printed form at any regular or special meeting. The enacting clause of all ordinances shall be "Be it enacted by the City of Titusville, Florida." A proposed ordinance may be read by title, or in full, on at least two separate days and shall, at least ten days prior to adoption, be noticed once in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality. The notice of proposed enactment shall state the date, time and place of the meeting; the title or titles of proposed ordinances; and the place or places within the municipality where such proposed ordinances may be inspected by the public. The notice shall also advise that interested parties may appear at the meeting and be heard with respect to the proposed ordinance. All proposed ordinances shall be read by title only unless required by state statutes that the ordinance is required to be read in full. An emergency ordinance may be enacted as provided for by state law. 
(Sp. Acts, Ch. 65-2328, § 1(2); Sp. Acts, Ch. 67-2138, § 3; Ord. No. 73-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 58-1986, § 1, 9-23-86; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 8, 2-10-98) 
State Law reference— Procedure for adoption of ordinances, F.S. § 166.041.  
Sec. 27. - Independent annual audit. 
Prior to the end of each fiscal year, the council shall designate qualified public accountants who, as of the end of the fiscal year, shall make an independent audit of accounts and other evidences of financial transactions of the city government and shall submit their report to the city council. Such accountants shall have no personal interest, direct or indirect, in the fiscal affairs of the city government or of any of its officers. They shall not maintain any accounts or records of the city business, but within specifications approved by the council, shall post-audit the books and documents kept by the department of finance, and any separate or subordinate accounts kept by any other office, department or agency of the city government. 
State Law reference— Annual audit required, F.S. §§ 166.212, 218.33.  
Sec. 28. - Contracts, materials and supplies with city. 
It shall be unlawful for any council member to directly or indirectly contract with any association, partnership, firm or corporation in which he is financially interested, for the doing of any work or the furnishing of any material or equipment to or for the City of Titusville, Florida, unless after public advertisement or competitive conditions, such association, partnership, firm or corporation shall be the lowest responsible and competent bidder. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 1, 2-10-98) 
State Law reference— Restrictions on doing business with agency, F.S. § 112.311(3), (12).  
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION—CITY MANAGER 
 
Sec. 29. - Qualifications. 
The city manager shall be chosen by the city council solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, with special reference to his actual experience in, or his knowledge of, accepted practices in respect to the duties of his office as hereinafter set forth. At the time of his appointment, he need not be a resident of the city or state, but during his tenure of office he shall reside within the city. The salary of the city manager shall be fixed by the city council.  
Sec. 30. - Powers and duties. 
The city manager shall be the chief executive officer and head of the administrative branch of the city government, except as herein provided. He shall be responsible to the city council for the proper administration of all affairs of the city and to that end, subject to provisions provided for in this Charter, he shall have power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Appoint and, when necessary for the good of the city, remove all officers and employees of the city, except as otherwise provided by this Charter, and except that he may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint and remove subordinates in such department or office; 
(2)  Fix the salary of officers and employees except as otherwise provided in this Charter; 
(3)  Endorse on all contracts, bonds and other instruments in writing in which the municipality is interested his approval of the substance thereof; 
(4)  Prepare the budget annually and submit it to the city council, and be responsible for its administration after adoption; 
(5)  Prepare and submit to the city council, as of the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the city for the preceding year; 
(6)  Keep the city council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the city, and make such recommendations as may seem to him desirable; 
(7)  He shall be purchasing agent of the city, by whom all purchases of supplies shall be made subject to the rules and regulations to be prescribed by the council and he shall approve all vouchers for the payment of same. In the capacity of purchasing agent he shall also conduct all sales of personal property which the council may authorize to be sold as having become unnecessary or unfit for the city's use. All purchases and sales shall conform to such regulations as the city council may from time to time prescribe. 
(8)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by this Charter or required of him by the city council, not inconsistent therewith.  
Sec. 31. - Absence of the city manager. 
To perform his duties during his temporary absence or disability the city manager may designate by letter filed with the city clerk, a qualified administrative officer of the city. In the event of the failure of the city manager to make such designation, or in the event of the failure of such designation to meet the approval of the council, the city council may by resolution appoint an officer of the city to perform the duties of the city manager until he shall return, or his disability shall cease. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 9, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 32. - Administrative departments. 
There may be a police department, finance department, department of fire rescue and emergency services, department of public works, building department, and such other departments as may be established upon recommendation of the city manager. At the head of each department there shall be an officer of the city who shall have supervision and control of the department who shall be appointed by and shall be under supervision and control of the city manager. Except as herein provided, two or more departments may be headed by the same individual. The city manager may head one or more departments. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 10, 2-10-98) 
Cross reference— Fire department, § 45; assessment of taxes, § 66 et seq.  
Sec. 33. - Active participation in political campaign. 
[Editorially deleted] 
Editor's note— This section has been editorially deleted at the direction of the city. 
State Law reference— Restrictions on political activity while not working prohibited, F.S. §§ 104.31(3), 166.031(4).  
ARTICLE IV. - CITY ATTORNEY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 49-1976, § 1, adopted Nov. 30, 1976, provided that the municipal court of the city be abolished. Accordingly, the editors have deleted any references to municipal court in article IV. 
 
Sec. 34. - City attorney—Appointment and qualifications. 
The city council shall appoint a city attorney and such assistant attorneys as may be necessary who shall act as the legal advisor to, and attorney and counselor for, the municipality and all of its officers in matters relating to their official duties. The city attorney shall be a lawyer of at least two (2) years' experience and practice in the courts of the state. He shall prepare all contracts, bonds and other instruments in writing to which the municipality is concerned, and shall endorse on each his approval of the form and correctness thereof, but failure to do so shall not affect its validity. When required to do so by the city council, he shall prosecute and defend for and in behalf of the city all civil complaints, suits and controversies in which the city is a party. He shall furnish the city council, the city manager, the head of any department, or any officer, board, council, or agency not included in any department his opinion on any question of law relating to their respective powers and duties. In addition to the duties specifically imposed under other sections of this Charter, the city attorney shall perform such other professional duties as may be required of him by ordinance, resolution or motion of the city council, or as are prescribed for city attorneys under federal and state laws, which are not inconsistent with this Charter and with any ordinance, resolution or motion which may be passed by the city council. Assistant city attorneys shall work under the supervision of the city attorney, and perform such duties as he shall require of them. In such cases they shall have the same powers as the city attorney. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 65-2328, § 1(3); Laws of Fla., ch. 69-1688, § 1; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 11, 2-10-98)  
Secs. 35—39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 49-1976, § 1, enacted Nov. 30, 1976, provided that the municipal court as created and established pursuant to Laws of Fla., ch. 63-2001, § 35, be abolished as of 12:01 a.m., Dec. 1, 1976. The editors have deleted §§ 35—39 and 41—43, relative to the municipal court and the municipal court judge, and derived from Laws of Fla., ch. 63-2001 and Laws of Fla., ch. 65-2328, § 1(4)—(6).  
Sec. 40. - Salary of city attorney. 
The salary of the city attorney shall be fixed by the city council. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 49-1976, § 1, adopted Nov. 30, 1976, provided that the municipal court be abolished. Accordingly, the editors have deleted that portion of § 40 relative to the salary of the municipal judge.  
Secs. 41—43. - Reserved. 
Note— See the editor's note following § 35.  
ARTICLE V. - CITY CLERK 
 
Sec. 44. - City clerk. 
The city manager shall appoint an officer of the city who shall have the title of city clerk. He or she shall serve at the pleasure of and shall be under the direction and control of the city manager. The city manager shall appoint a deputy city clerk to act for the city clerk in his or her absence. He or she shall give notice of the meetings of the city council; shall keep the minutes of its proceedings; shall authenticate by his or her signature and record in full in a book kept for that purpose all ordinances and resolutions. He or she shall attest to and/or countersign by his or her signature all contracts, bonds and other instruments as required by law; shall perform the duties of registration officer and shall perform any other duties required by this Charter and as may be assigned by the city manager. The city manager may also serve as city clerk in addition to his other duties. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 67-2138, § 4; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 12, 2-10-98)  
ARTICLE VI. - DEPARTMENT OF FIRE RESCUE 
 
Sec. 45. - Department of fire rescue. 
There shall be a department of fire rescue headed by a fire chief who shall be appointed by the city manager, and as many subordinate officers, firefighters and employees as may be necessary to carry on the functions of the department. The fire chief shall be responsible to the city manager for stationing and supervision of all firefighters within the department and have jurisdiction over all areas in the vicinity of a fire or conflagration. The city manager or his designated representative may make mutual-aid agreements with other fire emergency departments to supply and receive fire-fighting and medical assistance when circumstances require such action. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 65-2328, § 1(7); Laws of Fla., ch. 67-2138, § 5; Ord. No. 64-1982, § 1, 10-12-82)  
ARTICLE VII. - DEPARTMENT OF PERSONNEL 
 
Sec. 46. - Merit basis of appointment. 
Appointments and promotions in the service of the city, except as otherwise provided in this Charter, shall be made according to merit and fitness to be ascertained, so far as practicable, by competitive examination.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC WORKS AND UTILITIES 
 
Sec. 47. - Public works. 
The city council shall have the power within and without its corporate limits to construct, condemn, purchase, acquire or lease any interest in any property, and to maintain, conduct, own and operate, within and without the corporate limits, wharves, warehouses, ship canals, breakwaters, reservoirs, sewerage systems, trunk sewers, intercepting sewers, pumping stations, wells, siphons, intakes, pipe lines, distribution systems, purification works, collection systems, treatment and disposal works, transportation systems, cemeteries, gas plants and distribution systems or other public utility, airports and necessary hangars and appurtenances, or facility deemed necessary for the public good, and any buildings or facilities as may be required in connection therewith, and to make a contract of whatever nature in connection therewith; and shall have the right and power to issue bonds or revenue certificates in the manner provided in this Charter, in an amount necessary to carry out any of said powers or purposes. All of the above works are considered as utilities within the meaning of all constitutional or statutory provision, and any existing utility may be combined with another existing utility and revenue bonds or certificates issued as otherwise provided by this Charter.  
Sec. 48. - Lights, heat and power. 
The city council shall have power to purchase or otherwise acquire, establish, maintain and provide facilities for lighting the streets, parks, public buildings and public places of the city; and to operate plants either within or without the corporate limits of the city for sources of power, lighting, heating by electricity, gas, atomic power or other unknown sources of energy or any other method; and to supply the inhabitants of said city with artificial light, heat and power, for domestic, business and other purposes, and to charge and collect reasonable rates, prices and compensation for furnishing and supplying the same.  
Sec. 49. - Waterworks plants. 
The city council shall have the power to construct, establish, maintain and operate waterworks, and to bore and dig wells, construct reservoirs, lay pipes, and do such other things as may be necessary, essential or convenient for procuring and distributing an abundant supply of good and wholesome water to the inhabitants of said city for domestic and other purposes and to protect the property of said city and its inhabitants against fire; and also the power to lay water mains and water distribution systems beyond the city limits for the purpose of supplying water to persons residing outside the city limits, and to collect reasonable rates, prices and compensations for furnishing and supplying same, except for fire protection, which may be provided for in the tax levy. 
State Law reference— Municipal public works, F.S. ch. 180.  
Sec. 50. - Service of utilities to consumers outside of city. 
The city shall have power to supply water, electricity and other sources of power, sewerage [sewage] disposal and gas for domestic and other purposes, to individuals, firms, corporations, and other municipalities outside of said city, and to charge and collect reasonable rates, prices and compensations therefor, but the city may charge rates to be fixed by ordinance higher to such consumers than is charged for a like class of service to a like class of consumers within the city limits.  
Sec. 51. - Sanitary sewerage districts. 
[Editorially deleted] 
Editor's note— This section has been editorially deleted as the home rule powers of a municipality other than extraterritorial powers which shall be by general or special law are derived from the Constitution and F.S. ch. 166. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule powers, F.S. ch. 166; municipal public works, F.S. ch. 180; creation of special districts, F.S. ch. 189.  
Sec. 52. - Compulsory connection to sanitary sewers. 
[Editorially deleted] 
Editor's note— This section has been editorially deleted as the home rule powers of a municipality other than extraterritorial powers which shall be by general or special law are derived from the Constitution and F.S. ch. 166. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule powers, F.S. ch. 166; sewer connections, F.S. § 381.272.  
ARTICLE IX. - ELECTIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Florida election code, F.S. chs. 97—106. 
 
Sec. 53. - Elections. 
The city council shall, by ordinance, make all regulations which it considers needful or desirable, not inconsistent with this Charter, for the conduct of municipal elections, and for the prevention of fraud therein. Inspectors and clerks of elections shall be appointed by the Brevard County Supervisor of Elections. 
(Ord. No. 9-1998, § 13, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 54. - Electors. 
[Editorially deleted] 
Editor's note— This section has been editorially deleted as superseded by F.S. § 98.041.  
Sec. 55. - Registration of voters. 
[Editorially deleted] 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 65-2328, § 1(8); Laws of Fla., ch. 67-2138, § 6) 
Editor's note— This section has been editorially deleted as superseded by F.S. §§ 98.041, 98.051(3)(c), 98.091.  
Sec. 56. - Elections; general; runoff. 
A regular or general election of candidates or nominees to the city council of the City of Titusville shall be held on the dates set forth in section 12 of article 2 of this Charter. Each candidate for council member shall qualify as a candidate from an election seat and no candidate may qualify from more than one election seat in a single election. A candidate to be elected as council member on the first ballot or elected as mayor on the first ballot must receive the majority of the votes cast in his election. In the event a candidate for council member or mayor does not receive a majority of the votes cast in his election, there shall be a "run off" election between the two candidates with the highest number of votes cast. The "run off" election shall be held on the dates specified in section 12 of article 2 of this Charter. In the event that there is a tie in the first election among the candidates receiving the most votes, these candidates shall be in the "run off" election. In the event there is a tie in the "run off" election, subsequent elections shall be held in the same manner as the original "run off" election. The candidates shall be elected in the "run off" election by receiving a plurality of the votes cast in the "run off" election. The exercise by the city council of the City of Titusville of its option to adopt the permanent single voter registration system is hereby ratified, confirmed and approved, and all elections of the City of Titusville shall be conducted by the supervisor of elections of Brevard County in accordance with general state laws governing elections and registration of electors and by such ordinances as the city council of Titusville may from time to time adopt, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in other sections of this Charter, which inconsistent provisions are hereby repealed. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 63-2001, § 56; Laws of Fla., ch. 65-2328, § 1(9); Ord. No. 20-1970, § 1, 9-10-70; Ord. No. 24-1971, § 4, 9-9-71; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 14, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 35-2013, § 3, 12-10-13)  
Sec. 57. - Elections; canvass of returns. 
The polls shall open at seven o'clock a.m. and shall close at seven o'clock p.m. or such other time as established by applicable general law of the state. The result of the voting, when ascertained, shall be certified by the supervisor of elections and the county canvassing board to the city clerk, who shall transmit such returns to the city council at the first regular City Council meeting following the receipt of the official results for the primary election and at the organizational meeting held on the fourth Tuesday of November for the general election or such other date as established by the City Council. At such meeting the city council shall canvass the returns, and the results as shown by such returns shall be declared as the results of the election. 
(Ord. No. 61-1988, § 1, 9-27-88; Ord. No. 9-1998, § 15, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 35-2013, § 4, 12-10-13) 
State Law reference— Hours of opening and closing of polls superseded by state law, F.S. § 100.011.  
Sec. 57-A. - Straw ballots. 
The city council of the City of Titusville, Florida, may, by ordinance passed by a three-fifths ( 3/5 ) vote, submit to the electors of the city on straw ballot or opinion poll any question of public interest at any regular or general election of candidates or nominees to the city council. The results of the straw ballot or opinion poll shall not be binding upon the city council, but shall serve as information to the council on matters of public interest. The straw ballot or opinion poll at the general or regular election of candidates or nominees to the city council shall conform to the following requirements: 
STRAW BALLOT 
Mark a cross mark (x) in the square at the right FOR or AGAINST the proposal. 
(Proposal to be placed upon the ballot.) 
FOR the proposal 	? 
AGAINST the proposal 	? 
 
(Ord. No. 46-1972, § 3, 7-25-72)  
Sec. 58. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the city government shall begin on the first day of October and shall end on the last day of September in each calendar year. Such fiscal year shall also constitute the budget and accounting year, and as used in the Charter, the term "budget year" shall mean the fiscal year for which any particular budget is adopted and in which it is administered. 
State Law reference— Fiscal year mandated by state law, F.S. §§ 166.241, 218.33.  
Sec. 59. - City manager's budget message and recommendations. 
The city manager shall submit to the city council his budget message, estimates and recommendations, together with a proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning October 1st thereafter. The budget message shall contain an outline of the proposed financial policies of the city for the budget year, and shall describe in connection therewith the important features of the proposed budget. He shall estimate receipts and disbursements for the remainder of the current fiscal year, based on information obtained from the various departments. He shall also make an estimate of the expenditures and revenues of the city for the ensuing year; such estimate to be compiled from detailed information, and its arrangement and classification of expenditures shall be as nearly uniform as possible for the main functional divisions and departments of the city. Schedules attached to such budget message shall show the following information: 
(1)  The current budgeted amount for each fund, function, department, division, and for each utility or facility operated by the city and the estimated surplus or deficit of each with recommendations for transfers. 
(2)  The amount of monies which he estimates will be on hand on October 1st, specifying the fund or appropriation to which such monies have been appropriated, after inter-fund transfers. 
(3)  Detailed estimates of anticipated revenues to be derived from all sources other than ad valorem taxes for each fund or appropriation. 
(4)  Estimated amount necessary to be raised by ad valorem taxation. 
(5)  The actual expenditure of funds for the preceding year for each fund, appropriation and utility and in parallel columns, the estimated expenditure of funds for the current fiscal year, and the fiscal year beginning October 1st, to be shown by fund, or appropriation with each fund subdivided into its current classification of functions, departments and divisions. 
(6)  Supporting schedules showing special pledges or dedications of revenues to special funds or appropriations. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 67-2138, § 7)  
Sec. 60. - Annual budget recommended by city manager. 
The city manager shall include in his budget message a recommended annual budget, prepared in proper form, for the next ensuing fiscal year beginning October 1st and ending September 30 following, which proposed budget shall provide a clear financial plan for the ensuing fiscal year.  
Sec. 61. - Publication of notice of public hearing. 
[Editorially deleted] 
(Ord. No. 6-1975, § 1, 1-28-75)

Sec. 63. - Effective date, execution and amendment of budget. 
(a)  [Editorially deleted] 
(b)  From the effective date of the budget, the several amounts stated therein as proposed expenditures shall be and become appropriated to the several objects and purposes therein named. It shall be unlawful for any officer to draw money from the treasury except pursuant to an appropriation. 
(c)  The city manager may, at any time and without formal action by the city council, transfer any unencumbered appropriation balance or portion thereof between general classifications and expenditures within a department or division and shall report said transfer at the next regular meeting. Failure to report said transfer shall not invalidate said expenditure made in reliance on said transfer. At the request of the city manager, by motion recorded in the minutes of the meeting, the city council may authorize at any time the transfer of any unencumbered appropriation balance or portion thereof from one department or division to another. 
(d)  The city council, by motion recorded in the minutes of the meeting, at any time within a fiscal year may amend a budget for that year as follows: 
(1)  Appropriations for expenditures in any fund may be decreased and other appropriations in the same fund correspondingly increased provided that the total of the appropriations of the fund be not changed. 
(2)  Appropriations from any reserve or reserve for contingencies may be made to increase the appropriation for any particular expense in the same fund, or to create an appropriation in the fund for any lawful purpose. 
(3)  A receipt of a nature from a source not anticipated in the budget or received for a particular purpose, including grants, donations, gifts, or other revenues, may be appropriated and expended in addition to the appropriations and expenditures provided for in the budget. 
(4)  Transfers may be made between funds only for the following purposes. 
a.  To correct errors in handling receipts and disbursements. 
b.  Budgeted transfers. 
(5)  To meet a public emergency affecting life, health, property or the public peace, the council may make emergency appropriations. To the extent that there are no available unappropriated revenues to meet such appropriation, the council may authorize an emergency note which may be renewed from time to time until funds are available. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 67-2138, § 8; Ord. No. 6-1975, § 1, 1-28-75) 
Editor's note— Subsection (a) of this section has been editorially deleted as superseded by F.S. § 200.065.
