Cross reference— The mayor may declare certain businesses closed during an emergency, § 8-4; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 11; alcoholic beverages restricted in motion picture theaters, § 11-277. 
State Law reference— Alcoholic beverages, F.S. ch. 561 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Definition of alcoholic beverage. 
All liquors and beverages whether spirituous, vinous or malt, containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume shall be deemed and held to be alcoholic beverages, within the meaning of any and all ordinances of this city relating to alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1963, § 3-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions under the state beverage law, F.S. § 561.01.  
Sec. 4-2. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction be punished as provided by section 1-15. 
(Code 1963, § 3-19)  
Sec. 4-3. - Distance restrictions. 
(a)  Schools: Except as provided herein, per F.S. § 562.45(2)(a), no license or conditional use permit authorizing the on premises consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be granted where the proposed premises is within five hundred (500) feet of the real property that comprises a public or private elementary school or middle school or secondary school. This restriction shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Any real property authorized for the off premises sale of beer and malt beverages as provided for in F.S. § 563.02(1)(a); 
(2)  Any real property within the downtown community redevelopment area; 
(3)  Any real property that is licensed as a restaurant which derives at least fifty-one (51) percent of its gross revenue from sale of food and nonalcoholic beverages pursuant to F.S. ch. 509; and/or; 
(4)  Temporary permits to certain not-for-profit organizations as provided for in F.S. § 561.422. 
(b)  Churches: No license or conditional use permit authorizing the on premises consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be granted where the proposed premises is within three hundred (300) feet of the real property from an established church, and no church shall be authorized to locate, by conditional use permit or otherwise, within three hundred (300) feet from a licensed establishment having on premises consumption of alcoholic beverages. This restriction shall not be applicable to the following: 
(1)  Any church that executes a waiver in writing that the restriction against on premises consumption of alcoholic beverages within three hundred (300) feet shall not apply or be asserted by the church; 
(2)  Any real property authorized for off the premises sale of beer and malt beverages as provided in F.S. § 563.02(1)(a); 
(3)  Any real property within the downtown community redevelopment area; 
(4)  Any real property that is licensed for a restaurant of which derives at least fifty-one (51) percent of its gross revenue from sale of food and nonalcoholic beverages pursuant to F.S. ch. 509. 
(5)  Temporary permits to certain not-for-profit organizations as provided for in F.S. § 561.422; and/or 
(6)  Any church or alcoholic beverage establishment authorized to locate within a shopping center by conditional use permit and/or receipt of an occupational license (business tax license), as applicable, shall be exempt from the above stated distance restriction, as applied within the boundaries of the shopping center. In addition, any church or alcoholic beverage establishment that locates within three hundred (300) feet of a shopping center where an existing church or alcoholic beverage establishment is situated shall also be exempt from the above stated distance requirement. 
(Code 1963, § 3-2; Ord. No. 30-2008, § 1, 10-14-08) 
Cross reference— Commercial district regulations, § 63.00 et seq., Land Development Regulations, Vol. II. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt, F.S. § 562.45; restrictions for off-premises sale of malt beverages, F.S. § 563.02(1)(a).  
Sec. 4-4. - Hours of sale for the consumption and service of alcohol. 
(a)  Any commercial establishment which serves, dispenses, stores or sells liquor, or permits liquor to be consumed on or off its premises, or any person holding a license from the division of beverage, state department of business regulation, or any commercial establishment, bottle club or membership association in which a fee, cover charge or admission fee is collected, shall have hours of operation for the purposes of dispensing, selling, consuming or serving alcoholic beverages as follows: 
(1)  Monday through Saturday: Beginning at 7:00 a.m. and ending at 11:00 p.m. 
(2)  Sunday: Beginning at 1:00 p.m. and ending at 11:00 p.m. 
(b)  Permits required for premises to remain open past 11:00 p.m.; suspension of permits. 
(1)  Permits required. All vendors licensed under the state beverage laws desiring to remain open for business for the purposes of selling, offering for sale, delivering, serving or permitting consumption of alcoholic beverages between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m. on any weekday or Saturday, and between 11:00 p.m. and midnight on Sunday, shall make application with the business tax department for an extended hours of operation permit. An extended hours of operation permit is also available for alcohol sales between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. on Sunday for commercial establishments that are also licensed to prepare and serve food. When December 31 falls on a Saturday, Sunday or other weekday the hours shall be extended until 5:00 a.m. 
For the remainder of the city's fiscal year 2008/2009, vendors shall not be required to obtain an extended hours of operation permit. Commencing with October 1, 2009, and following fiscal years, vendors shall be required to obtain and possess an extended hours of operation permit. 
(2)  The application form shall be provided by the city. The vendor shall complete the application by providing the information requested about the vendor, including, but not limited to, the name and address where notices related to this section are to be mailed. 
(3)  [Review of application.] The city manager or designee shall review the application and, if the application is complete and the vendor is in compliance with the code, a permit shall be issued to the vendor to remain open between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturday or between 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. and midnight on Sunday. 
(4)  [Annual renewal of permit.] Such permit must be renewed annually on or before the thirtieth day of September of each year, unless the permit has been suspended by the City of Titusville or the vendor's state beverage license has been revoked or suspended. In the event that there has been a change in ownership or a change in location of the establishment, the city must be notified immediately and a new application must be processed. Failure to renew the extended hours of operation permit shall be cause for the immediate suspension of extended hours privileges pursuant to subsection (7) below. 
(5)  [After-hours sales prohibited.] No vendor may sell alcoholic beverages after 11:00 p.m. or before 1:00 p.m. on Sunday, unless it has received an extended hours of operation permit from the city. 
(6)  [Open hours not impaired.] The provisions of this section shall not impair or impact an establishment's right to remain open prior to 11:00 p.m. 
(7)  Permit suspension. The ability to sell, offer for sale, deliver or permit to be consumed upon the premises any alcoholic beverage beyond the hour of 11:00 p.m. on any day of the week, or before 1:00 p.m. on Sunday, is hereby declared to be and is a privilege subject to suspension by the city council, and no person may reasonably rely on a continuation of that privilege. As a condition of the continuation of the privilege, vendors are required to take all necessary steps to minimize the negative impacts that their establishment may cause in nearby residential or commercial neighborhoods. The city council shall consider the following in deciding whether to suspend, revoke or condition the privilege: 
a.  Whether there is adequate off-street parking in relation to the demands created during the extra hours of operation, with special regard to any adverse impact on adjacent residential areas of any illegal or hazardous parking that can be traced directly to a particular vendor. For the purposes of this section, sufficient evidence of an adverse impact on adjacent residential areas will exist upon verification by police or code enforcement officials that more than ten (10) patrons of the vendor have parked illegally on public rights-of-way or property, or on private property upon receipt of a complaint by the property owner which has been communicated to the vendor. This provision will only apply if the parking provided by the vendor is at maximum capacity at the time the illegal parking takes place, or is otherwise determined to be inadequate given the size of the crowds that the vendor draws; illegal parking by an individual patron shall not constitute a violation of this subsection; 
b.  Law enforcement activities on the vendor's property during the extra hours of operation, both outside and inside the permitted location, with particular emphasis on illegal activity of the owner, employees, or others associated with the establishment, including use, sale or delivery of controlled substances, allowing underage drinking, violation of open container laws and loitering by intoxicated individuals. The city council shall also consider whether the need for law enforcement involvement was the result of the establishment's failure or inability to maintain proper order and control during the extended business hours; 
c.  Complaints verified by the police, arising from adverse effects extra hours of operation have upon neighboring properties, including the effects of noise, parking, vandalism, generation of trash or garbage, loitering by intoxicated persons or exterior lighting on neighboring residential properties. It shall be a defense to the applicability of this section that the vendor has adequate security personnel and has implemented a policy requiring that security personnel patrol the premises as well as all known parking lots that patrons use, to assure the orderly conduct of patrons as they arrive at the establishment or as they depart. Complaints involving neighboring properties must be traceable to the actions of the owner and/or his employees. Noise complaints shall be traceable to the actions of the vendor or his employees by entertainment provided by the vendor or noise generated from the seating areas or entertainment areas of the vendor and not individual discussions, conversations by patrons within parking areas. Upon a showing of such security precautions, the vendor shall only be held accountable if the conduct complained of constitutes a violation by the vendor of any provision of the City of Titusville Code of Ordinances; 
d.  Violations of any provisions of the City of Titusville Code of Ordinances; specially including, but not limited to, sections 13-101 through 13-105 relating to noise and sound limitations; 
e.  Failure to obtain an extended hours of operation permit, or failure to renew the permit as required by subsections (4) and (5) above; 
f.  Violations of laws relating to the maximum permissible occupancy of vendor; 
g.  Violation of any provisions of the City of Titusville Code of Ordinances, state or federal law. 
In order to invoke the enforcement provisions of this section, the activities described hereinabove must be traceable to the particular vendor against whom action is being taken, and also must be verified by a police report, police officers or code enforcement officers on the scene. Although not required, police officers and code enforcement officers may, at their discretion, issue warnings that shall not be considered a notice of violation, to put the vendor on notice that a particular problem or problems must be addressed and could result in a notice of violation if not corrected. 
In addition, the first violation by a vendor of a city code violation (not state law violation), shall be a written warning and not a notice of violation as provided for in subsection (8). Any subsequent violation of any section of the city code may result in a notice of violation. 
A vendor is encouraged to initiate calls for service to the police department if law violations are occurring on vendor's property. A notice of violation shall not be initiated for vendor initiated calls. 
It is recognized that an incident that may occur during an extended hour period, i.e., between 11:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m., could involve more than one (1) section of the code or violation of law. Any notice of violation that is issued that may involve multiple code or law violations on one (1) incident shall constitute one (1) notice of violation. 
(8)  [Notice of violation.] Notice of violation may be issued by a police officer or code enforcement officer of a violation of this section and shall be issued to any vendor that meets or, where applicable, fails to meet the criteria established in subsection (7)a., b., c., d., e., f., and g. above. The notice of violation shall be left with the owner, proprietor, or highest ranking employee then on the premises. An additional copy of the notice will also be mailed via U.S. mail, certified, return receipt requested, to the vendor at the street address provided in the application. Proof of delivery by either of these two (2) methods (hand delivery or mail) shall be sufficient to establish receipt by the permit holder. Notices sent by mail that are returned or not accepted for any reason shall be deemed proper notice of the violation, provided that the notice is sent to the person and address named on the application. 
(9)  [Consideration by city council.] Should three (3) notices of violation be issued to any vendor within any three (3) consecutive month period, the matter shall be placed on the city council agenda to consider the suspension of the vendor's extended hours permit. 
a.  Such agenda item shall be publicly advertised in a newspaper of general circulation at least fourteen (14) days prior to any hearing of the agenda item, and written notice of the charges against the vendor shall be provided at least fourteen (14) days in advance of the hearing. The notice shall also contain the date, time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall also advise the vendor of the right to be heard, of the right to be represented by counsel, of the right to present sworn testimony on the vendor's behalf, and the right to appeal to circuit court. 
b.  After consideration of the matter and allowing the vendor to be heard, the city council may take no action, suspend or condition the extended hours privilege, as they deem appropriate. Suspensions shall range from one (1) day in length to a maximum of ninety (90) days. The maximum penalty for a first appearance by a vendor before the city council shall be thirty (30) days, sixty (60) days for a second appearance and ninety (90) days for all appearances thereafter. The city council shall base its decision on whether there is substantial, competent evidence presented that supports a finding of noncompliance with the criteria in subsection (7)a., b., c., d., e., f., or g. as stated herein above. 
c.  The city council may require, as a condition of the continuation of the privilege of extra hours of operation, compliance with any reasonable conditions. 
d.  The city council may delegate the responsibility for conducting hearings pursuant to this section to a special magistrate. Any such delegation shall be by resolution. 
(10)  [Vendor name change.] Any vendor that has had an extended hours of operation permit suspended or otherwise conditioned cannot avoid the consequences of the city council's action by changing its name or corporate status. Upon a showing to the city council that there has been a legitimate change in ownership at the location affected by the city council's action(s), the city council may consider allowing an extended hours of operation permit to issue at the site, subject to applicable conditions, if any, to prevent a recurrence of the harms that caused the earlier action. 
(11)  Vendors who were allowed to serve alcohol under previous ordinance. Those vendors in the city who are, as of the effective date of this section, allowed to serve alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption later than that provided in this section ("preexisting late night vendors") shall be treated as having an extended hours of operation permit through and including September 30, 2009, subject to the same conditions and possibility of suspension as set forth above. As of October 1, 2009, such preexisting late night vendors shall be required to apply for an extended hours of operation permit in order to continue to serve alcoholic beverages at hours later than those provided in subsection (a), above, and otherwise are subject to the terms of this section. 
(c)  Liquors, beers and wines hours of sale. No vendors licensed under the state beverage law to sell liquor, beer or wine by the package, bottle or original container for consumption off premises, shall sell or offer for sale or deliver any liquor, beer or wine in the original package, bottle or container for consumption off the premises during any hour prohibited by subsection (a) above. Businesses covered by this section are also required to obtain an extended hours of operation permit, and are subject to all of the requirements of subsection (b). 
(d)  Taking container off premises after hours. It is the intention of this section to prohibit such vendors from permitting anyone purchasing packing goods in the original container to leave the vendor's premises during the prohibited hours, taking with him in any container any beers, wines, liquors, or alcoholic beverages originally purchased by package, bottle or container, so that the same may be consumed off the premises. 
(e)  Sales by employees during prohibited hours. Any employee of a vendor licensed under the state beverage law shall not sell, or offer for sale, any beers, wines, liquors, or alcoholic beverages of any kind during the prohibited hours. 
(f)  Gifts. It shall be deemed a violation of this section for any person, or any agent, servant or employee of any person licensed under the state beverage law, during the hours prohibited under subsection (c) above, to gratuitously give any kind of alcoholic beverage, whether conditioned upon the purchase of any kind of alcoholic beverage or product of any nature, at any inflated price or otherwise, or in the form of a so-called bonus predicated upon another purchase, or as a gift. 
(g)  [Enforcement procedures.] The enforcement procedures contained herein are alternative procedures and the city reserves the right to arrest, prosecute, take action through the code enforcement board or such alternative procedures as the law may authorize. 
(Code 1963, § 3-4; Ord. No. 25-2009, § 1, 8-11-09; Ord. No. 12-2011, § 1, 7-26-11) 
State Law reference— Municipality to prescribe hours of sale within corporate limits, F.S. §§ 561.342, 562.14(3).  
Sec. 4-5. - Certain states of undress prohibited on premises under this chapter. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Areola shall mean the circular colored area which surrounds the nipple of a female breast. 
(2)  Establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages shall mean any business or commercial establishment, whether open to the public at large or where entrance is limited by cover charge or membership requirement, including those licensed by the state for sale or service of alcoholic beverages, and any bottle club; hotel; motel; restaurant; nightclub; country club; cabaret; meeting facility utilized by any religious, social, fraternal or similar organization; business or commercial establishment where a product or article is sold, dispensed, served or provided with the knowledge, actual or implied, that the product or article will be or is intended to be mixed, combined with or drunk in connection or combination with an alcoholic beverage on the premises of the business or commercial establishment; or business or commercial establishment where the consumption of alcoholic beverages is permitted. A private residence, whether permanent or temporary in nature, is not an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  Premises shall mean a building that is under one roof or has common entrances and the area immediately surrounding the building. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, operating or managing an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages to: 
(1)  Suffer or permit any female person to expose to the public view that area of the human breast below the top of the areola; 
(2)  Suffer or permit any female person to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or to simulate that area of a human female breast below the top of the areola; 
(3)  Suffer or permit any person to expose to the public view his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus; or 
(4)  Suffer or permit any person to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or to simulate human genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while on the premises of an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages to: 
(1)  Expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus; or 
(2)  Employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate human genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any female, while on the premises of an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages to: 
(1)  Expose to public view that area of her breast below the top of the areola; or 
(2)  Expose any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate that area of a human female breast below the top of the areola. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or operating an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages to suffer or permit the exposition of any graphic representation, including pictures or the projection of film, which depicts human genitals, pubic area, vulva, anus, anal cleft or cleavage, buttocks, female breasts below the top of the areola, sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, any sexual act prohibited by law, touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals, or any simulation thereof within any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(f)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15 of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 3-5; Ord. No. 47-1990, § 1, 11-13-90; Ord. No. 26-1991, § 1, 8-13-91) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate conduct, F.S. § 561.342(3).  
Sec. 4-6. - Certain types of conduct prohibited on premises. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
Commercial establishment shall mean any establishment which operates for pecuniary gain. 
Lap shall mean the area between a person's knee and waist. 
Patron shall mean any person who is physically present on the premises of a commercial establishment and who is not an owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or an entertainer or performer at the establishment. 
Premises shall mean a building that is under one (1) roof or has common entrances and the area immediately surrounding the building. 
Touching shall include any form of intentional, interpersonal, physical, bodily contact, whether or not exposed or unclothed parts of the body are involved. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, while on the premises of a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are possessed, consumed, purchased, sold, dispensed or given away on the premises, for any owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or for any entertainer or performer at such establishment: 
(1)  To touch the clothed or unclothed breast of any female patron. 
(2)  To touch the clothed or unclothed body of any patron in the region of his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus. 
(3)  To suffer or permit herself to be touched on the breast by any patron if the owner, employee, agent, subcontractor, entertainer or performer so touched is a female. 
(4)  To sit on or in otherwise occupy the lap of any patron of such establishment. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful, while on the premises of a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are possessed, consumed, purchased, sold, dispensed or given away on the premises for any patron of said establishment. 
(1)  To touch the clothed or unclothed breast of any female owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or of any female entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(2)  To touch the clothed or unclothed body of any owner, employee, agent, subcontractor, entertainer or performer in the region of his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus. 
(3)  To suffer or permit herself to be touched on the breast by any owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or by any entertainer or performer at such establishment if the patron is a female. 
(4)  To sit on or in or otherwise occupy the lap of any owner, employee, agent of or subcontractor of such establishment or of any entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, a commercial establishment licensed by the state to dispense alcoholic beverages on the premises shall be rebuttably presumed to be a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are possessed, consumed, purchased, sold, dispensed or given away on the premises. Any establishment which has received an occupational license to operate commercially is presumed to be a commercial establishment. 
(e)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15 of this Code. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, operating or managing a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are possessed, consumed, purchased, sold, dispensed or given away on the premises of that establishment to: 
(1)  Suffer or permit any employee of or entertainer at such establishment to sit on or in or otherwise occupy the lap of any patron of such establishment. 
(2)  Suffer or permit any employee of or entertainer at such establishment to touch the clothed or unclothed breast of any female patron. 
(3)  Suffer or permit any employee of or entertainer at such establishment to touch the clothed or unclothed body of any patron at the point below the waist and above the knee of such patron. 
(4)  Suffer or permit any employee of or entertainer at such establishment to suffer or permit himself or herself to be touched by any patron in either of the following clothed or unclothed areas of the body: 
a.  At any point below the waist and above the knee. 
b.  On the breast, if the employee, entertainer, or performer so touched is a female. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, operating or managing a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are possessed, consumed, purchased, sold, dispensed or given away on the premises of that establishment to: 
(1)  Suffer or permit any patron of or entertainer at such establishment to sit on or in or otherwise occupy the lap of any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(2)  Suffer or permit any patron of such establishment to touch the clothed or unclothed breast of any female employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(3)  Suffer or permit any patron of such establishment to permit himself or herself to be touched by any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment in either of the following clothed or unclothed areas of the body: 
a.  At any point below the waist and above the knee. 
b.  On the breast, if the patron is a female. 
(Code 1963, § 3-6; Ord. No. 47-1990, §§ 2—5, 11-13-90) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate conduct, F.S. § 561.342(3).  
Sec. 4-7. - Possession, consumption, purchase, sale, dispensing or giving away of beverages prohibited on certain premises. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
Areola shall mean the circular colored area which surrounds the nipple of a human breast. 
At or below the areola shall mean the areola, the nipple of a human female breast, or that area of a human female breast below the areola. 
Commercial establishment shall mean any establishment which operates for pecuniary gain. 
Lap shall mean the area between a person's knees and waist. 
Premises shall mean a building that is under one roof or has common entrances, and the area immediately surrounding the building. 
Touching shall include any form of intentional, interpersonal, physical, bodily contact, whether or not exposed or unclothed parts of the body are involved. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume, purchase, sell, dispense or give away alcoholic beverages on the premises of any commercial establishment where such person knows or has reason to believe that: 
(1)  Any person is engaging in the actual or simulated display of his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus. 
(2)  Any female is engaging in the actual or simulated display of the area of the human breast at or below the areola. 
(3)  Within the past two (2) hours, any person has engaged in the actual or simulated display of his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic area, vulva, buttocks or anus. 
(4)  Within the past two (2) hours, any female has engaged in the actual or simulated display of the area of the human breast at or below the areola. 
(5)  Any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment is sitting on or in or otherwise occupying the lap of any patron of such establishment. 
(6)  Any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment is touching the clothed or unclothed breast of any female patron. 
(7)  Any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment is touching the clothed or unclothed body of any patron at any point below the waist and above the knee of such patron. 
(8)  Within the past two (2) hours, any employee of or entertainer or performer has sat on or in or otherwise occupied the lap of any patron of such establishment. 
(9)  Within the past two (2) hours, any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment has touched the clothed or unclothed breast of any female patron. 
(10)  Within the past two (2) hours, any employee of or entertainer or performer at such establishment has touched the clothed or unclothed body of any patron at any point below the waist and above the knee of such person. 
(11)  Any patron of such establishment is sitting on or in or otherwise occupying the lap of any owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or of any entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(12)  Any patron of such establishment is touching the clothed or unclothed breast of any female owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or of any female entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(13)  Any patron of such establishment is touching the clothed or unclothed body of any owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or of any performer below the waist and above the knee of such owner, employee, agent, subcontractor, entertainer or performer. 
(14)  Within the past two (2) hours, any patron of such establishment has sat on or in or otherwise occupied the lap of any owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or of any entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(15)  Within the past two (2) hours, any patron of such establishment has touched the clothed or unclothed breast of any female owner, employee, agent or subcontractor of such establishment or of any female entertainer or performer at such establishment. 
(16)  Within the past two (2) hours, any patron of such establishment has touched the clothed or unclothed body of any owner, employee, agent or subcontractor, entertainer or performer below the waist and above the knee of such owner, employee, agent or subcontractor, entertainer or performer. 
(c)  The following presumptions shall apply to this section: 
(1)  Any establishment which has received an occupational license to operate commercially is presumed to be a commercial establishment. 
(2)  Any person who enters a commercial establishment which displays on the premises, by sign or otherwise, any advertisement that reasonably indicates that nude or seminude activity takes place at the establishment is presumed to be aware that the activity defined in subsection (b) above is taking place in the establishment. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15 of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 3-7; Ord. No. 47-1990, §§ 6, 7, 11-13-90) 
Cross reference— Adult entertainment regulations, § 11-81 et seq.  
Sec. 4-8. - Possession of open containers. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, alcoholic beverage is defined as set forth in section 4-1 of the Code. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, open container means any container which is immediately capable of being consumed from, or the seal of which has been broken. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to consume or possess open containers of beer, wine, alcoholic beverages or intoxicating liquors off the premises of an establishment dealing in or licensed to sell alcoholic beverages or bottle clubs and within three hundred (300) feet of the premises, except within enclosed buildings or on premises occupied solely by residential structures, or by an owner or tenant of a premises which is within three hundred (300) feet. The distance set forth herein shall be measured from the shortest route of ordinary pedestrian travel along public thoroughfares from the principal entrance of the establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages or bottle club to the location of the violation of this section. 
(d)  Each establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages and each bottle club shall, at all times when such establishment is open to the public or is dispensing or selling alcoholic beverages, have located in the interior as well as the exterior portions of the building licensed for sale of such beverages at a location which can be readily seen and read by customers of the establishment, a sign prominently displayed of a size at least one (1) foot by two (2) feet containing the following information: 
"IT IS UNLAWFUL TO CONSUME OR POSSESS AN OPEN CONTAINER OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES WITHIN 300 FEET OF THIS ESTABLISHMENT AND OFF OF THESE LICENSED PREMISES. 
CITY CODE OF ORDINANCES 4-8" 
(e)  The city manager or his designee shall prescribe by rule the location of the signs and the size of the lettering, following as his guidelines the criteria set forth above. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages or any bottle club to fail to comply with this section or for any person to sell, dispense or serve alcoholic beverages in any establishment which is not in compliance with this section. The requirements of this section shall then apply to all establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages or bottle clubs whether or not then licensed or licensed in the future. 
(f)  Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-15 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-1993, § 1, 3-9-93)  
Sec. 4-9. - Purchase, sale, possession, etc., in parks, playgrounds, recreational areas or public parking lots, exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, sell or offer for sale, have in his possession or consume any alcoholic beverage, in or on any playground or recreational area or public park or public parking lot within the corporate limits of the city except as follows: 
(1)  The purchase, sale, possession and consumption of beer and wine shall be permitted at Titusville Memorial Pier and the Titusville Municipal Marina. 
(2)  The sale of alcoholic beverages at golf courses located within the city by a licensed vendor. The purchase, possession and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages by patrons of such golf courses shall be permitted during the hours of operation of such golf courses and/or clubhouse located at such golf courses and club pools, only if such alcoholic beverages being purchased, possessed and/or consumed have been purchased as such course from a licensed vendor. 
(3)  The sale, possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages may be permitted at other locations when specifically authorized by the city council or authorized by a representative of the county pursuant to an agreement between the city and county in the administration of city parks. 
(4)  Prohibition against the sale, possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages at other locations in the city may be temporarily permitted by the city council upon a finding that such permit would be in the best interests of the citizens of the city and upon a consideration by the city council of such factors as the time, date, location and length of the permit requested, the number and average age of the persons expected at the event for which the permit is requested and such other factors as the city council may deem relevant. 
(Ord. No. 10-1993, § 2, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 8-2019, § 1, 3-26-19)  
Sec. 4-10. - Possession or consumption on streets, sidewalks, alleys or other city property prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to consume or possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage or any mixture containing an alcoholic beverage on the streets, sidewalks or alleys within the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to consume or possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage or any mixture containing an alcoholic beverage on the streets, sidewalks or alleys within the city while such person, as operator or passenger, is in/on any vehicle, whether moving or stopped, and such consumption is open to public view. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  A passenger of a vehicle in which the driver is operating the vehicle pursuant to a contract to provide transportation for passengers and such driver holds a valid commercial driver's license with a passenger endorsement or a class D driver's license issued in accordance with the requirements of F.S. ch. 322; 
(2)  A passenger of a bus in which the driver holds a valid commercial driver's license with a passenger endorsement or a Class D driver's license issued in accordance with the requirements of F.S. ch. 322; or 
(3)  A passenger of a self-contained motor home which is in excess of twenty-one (21) feet in length. 
(Ord. No. 10-1993, § 3, 3-9-93)  
Sec. 4-11. - Sale and consumption restricted to licensed building; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any licensed vendor or for any agent, servant or employee of any such vendor, to permit the consumption of any alcoholic beverages in or upon any parking or other areas outside of the building or room mentioned in his license certificate as the address thereof. The foregoing prohibition shall not include areas around swimming pools of hotels or motels. When any part of such parking or other area is adjacent to the building or premises in which the business licensed under such section is operated, and such parking or other area is owned, rented, leased, regulated, controlled or provided, directly or indirectly, by such licensed vendor or by any agent, servant or employee of such licensed vendor, and if such licensed vendor has posted and maintained a legible, painted or printed sign in at least two (2) prominent places on such parking or other area, with sufficient light directed thereon to be visible during the hours of darkness while such place of business is open, in letters of not less than three inches in height, stating: 
"WARNING— 
DRINKING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES ON THIS LOT PROHIBITED—UP TO $500.00 FINE OR 60 DAYS IN JAIL 
CITY ORDINANCE" 
Then in that event, said posting shall constitute prima facie evidence that such vendor is not operating in violation of this subsection. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage in or upon any parking or other area outside of and adjacent to a vendor's licensed premises when such parking or other area is owned, rented, leased, regulated, controlled or provided, either directly or indirectly, by such vendor. The foregoing prohibition shall not apply to areas around swimming pools of hotels or motels. 
(c)  If any licensed vendor mentioned herein be a corporate, then the officers of the corporation shall be regarded as the owners thereof, for the purpose of enforcement of this section. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-1993, § 4, 3-9-93)  
Sec. 4-12. - Removal of alcoholic beverages in open or unsealed container from licensed premises. 
It is unlawful for any vendor or his agents or employees, licensed to sell beer, wine, liquor or other alcoholic beverages within the city, to knowingly allow any person to take from the licensed premises any opened beer, wine, liquor or other alcoholic beverage container, or to knowingly allow any person to take from the premises any glass or other open or unsealed container of an alcoholic beverage or any mixture containing an alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 10-1993, § 5, 3-9-93)  
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning regulations, § 60.00 et seq., Land Development Regulations, Vol. II. 
State Law reference— Damage by dogs, F.S. ch. 767; animal cruelty and control of animals, F.S. ch. 828. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal shall mean any dumb, living creature. 
Animal control officer shall mean any person employed or appointed by the county who is authorized to investigate, on public or private property, violations relating to animal control or cruelty to animals and to issue citations as provided in this chapter, and in accordance with F.S. § 828.27. 
Animal control supervisor shall mean the supervisor of the county animal control. 
At large shall mean off the premises of the owner, and not under the physical control of the owner or keeper by means of a leash, cord, or chain. A police dog or police horse, as defined in F.S. § 843.19, while in use by a law enforcement agency, shall not be deemed at large. 
Board shall mean the board of county commissioners of the county. 
Citation shall mean a written notice issued to a person by an officer who has probable cause to believe that the person to whom the citation has been issued has committed a violation of a duly enacted ordinance or code and that the county court shall hear the charge. The citation shall contain the following: 
(1)  The date and time of issuance. 
(2)  The name and address of the person to whom the citation has been issued. 
(3)  The date and time the violation was committed. 
(4)  The facts constituting probable cause. 
(5)  The number of the ordinance or code section violated. 
(6)  The name and authority of the police officer issuing the citation. 
(7)  The procedure for the person to follow in order to pay the civil penalty, or to contest the citation. 
(8)  The applicable civil penalty, if the person elects to contest the citation. 
(9)  The applicable penalty, if the person elects not to contest the citation. 
(10)  A conspicuous statement that substantially states that if the person fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed or fails to appear in court to contest the citation or fails to provide reasonable cause for nonappearance, the person shall be deemed to have waived his right to contest the citation, and, in such case, judgment may be entered by the court against the person for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty. 
Control shall mean the regulation of the possession, ownership, keeping, care, or custody of animals. 
Cruelty shall mean any act of neglect, torture, or torment that causes unjustifiable pain or suffering to an animal. 
Dangerous animal shall mean any animal that, according to the records of the county animal control: 
(1)  Has aggressively bitten, attacked, or endangered a human being, or has inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property; 
(2)  Has more than once severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property; or 
(3)  Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting or is a dog trained for dog fighting; or 
(4)  Has, without provocation, chased or approached a person upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack, provided that such actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one (1) or more persons, and dutifully investigated by the appropriate authority. 
Domestic animal shall mean any equine, bovine, goat, sheep, swine, dog, cat, poultry, or other domesticated beast or bird. 
Hazardous animal shall mean any animal which, without provocation, has inflicted any minor injury to a human being or domestic animal. 
Insecurely fenced property shall mean real property that an animal can readily enter upon or leave by going over, under, or through an existing fence. 
Keeper shall mean any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, trust, estate, or legal or business entity having possession, custody, or control of an animal. 
Kennel shall mean any enclosure in which an animal is confined and secured. 
License certificate shall mean a county animal license certificate issued pursuant to this chapter. 
License tag shall mean a county animal license tag issued pursuant to this chapter. 
Licensed veterinarian shall mean any person who is licensed to engage in the practice of veterinary medicine in the state, under the authority of F.S. ch. 474. 
Nuisance shall mean disturbing the peace and quiet of any person by habitually or continuously barking, howling, crying, screaming, or making other bothersome noises. 
Officer shall mean any law enforcement officer, as defined in F.S. § 943.10; any veterinarian, as defined in F.S. § 474.02; and any animal control officer, as defined in this section. 
Owner shall mean any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, trust, estate, or any other legal entity, business unit, or organization possessing, harboring, keeping, or having control or custody of an animal, or, if the animal is owned by a person under the age of eighteen (18) years, that person's parent or legal guardian. 
Secure enclosure shall mean: 
(1)  A building in which an animal is confined, such as the owner's dwelling; or 
(2)  A kennel with secure top and secure sides, consisting of at least 11-gauge chainlink wire, which does not share fencing with the perimeter of the premises, and which is secured so as to prevent the animal from escaping, and which provides protection from the elements. 
Severe injury shall mean any physical injury that results in a broken bone or multiple punctures or disfiguring lacerations requiring sutures or cosmetic surgery. 
Unprovoked shall mean that the victim has been conducting himself peacefully and lawfully and has been bitten or chased in a menacing fashion or attacked by an animal. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-3), 4-9-91) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 5-2. - Authority and purpose. 
This chapter is hereby enacted, pursuant to the provisions of F.S. §§ 125.01 and 828.27 and Laws of Fla., ch. 90-180, with the purpose of regulating the possession, ownership, keeping, care and custody of animals, in the interest of the health, safety and welfare of the people of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-1), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-3. - Wildlife sanctuary. 
All property within the limits of the city is hereby declared to be a bird and wildlife sanctuary. The Indian River Audubon Society, an organization organized and promoted by the citizens, is hereby given permission to erect appropriate signs approved by the city manager, on public property designated by the city, stating that the city has been declared to be a bird and wildlife sanctuary and that hunting is prohibited within the corporate limits of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt, shoot or kill birds or wildlife within the city unless written permission is expressly granted to an individual or group by the city manager. 
(Code 1963, § 4-85)  
Sec. 5-4. - Animals creating nuisance prohibited. 
Any person that owns, keeps or harbors any animal which is found to have done any of the following acts shall be deemed in violation of this section, and shall be punished as provided in section 5-7 et seq. The following are the offenses that are deemed to create a nuisance: 
(1)  Any animal or bird which: 
a.  Frequently and for continued duration howls, barks, meows, squawks or makes other sounds; 
b.  Endangers or injures the safety or health of humans; 
c.  Annoys or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities across residential real property boundaries; 
d.  By its own condition or the condition of its confinement creates obnoxious odors. 
(2)  Any animal that chases or runs after persons or vehicles. 
(Code 1963, § 4-28)  
Sec. 5-5. - Disposal of domestic dead animals. 
(a)  By resolution, the board of county commissioners shall establish fees to be charged for disposal by the county of domestic dead animals from private property. 
(b)  The owner of any real property may bury or dispose of any dead animal on such property after notice to the animal control supervisor, unless otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-7), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-6. - Quarantine of animals. 
(a)  The provisions of sections 10D-3.061 through 10D-3.087, Florida Administrative Code, and sections 10D-3.090 through 10D-3.093, Florida Administrative Code, are hereby adopted by reference in this chapter. A copy of chapter 10-3, Florida Administrative Code, has been attached to the ordinance enacting this chapter, and is available for inspection in the office of the clerk to the board of county commissioners. 
(b)  It is a violation of this chapter for any person to commit an act, or cause an act to be committed, which is in violation of any provision of sections 10D-3.061 through 10D-3.093, Florida Administrative Code. 
(c)  If quarantine of a dog or cat cannot be maintained at the owner's home, or at another location permitted under section 10D-3.091(2), Florida Administrative Code, the dog or cat shall be quarantined at a county shelter or other shelter facility or veterinary clinic. It is a violation of this chapter for the owner of a dog or cat to refuse or fail to maintain the dog or cat under rabies quarantine, as required by section 10D-3.091(2), Florida Administrative Code. 
(d)  By resolution, the board shall establish fees to be charged for the quarantine of animals pursuant to this chapter. 
(e)  A police dog, as defined in F.S. § 843.19, with a current rabies vaccination, who bites in the line of duty, shall be exempt from confinement under this section, and allowed to continue in a working capacity. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-8), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-7. - Proceedings for violations. 
(a)  An officer who has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an act in violation of this chapter, may issue a citation to such person. 
(b)  Any citation issued pursuant to this chapter may be contested in the county court. 
(c)  If the person issued a citation elects not to contest the citation, that person shall pay the applicable civil penalty to the clerk of the county court within ten (10) days after issuance of the citation. 
(d)  If a person issued a citation elects to contest the citation, that person shall request a hearing before the county court, within ten (10) days after issuance of the citation. The clerk shall schedule a hearing in the county court and shall provide written notice of the date, time, and location of the hearing to the person issued the citation and the applicable officer. 
(e)  If the person issued a citation fails to pay the applicable civil penalty within the time period allowed or fails to appear in court to contest the citation, that person shall be deemed to have waived his right to contest the citation and, in such case, judgment may be entered against the person for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty provided for such a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-16), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-8. - Penalties. 
(a)  A violation of this chapter shall constitute a civil infraction. 
(b)  The maximum civil penalty for a violation of this chapter shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(c)  If a person who has committed a violation does not contest the citation, the civil penalty shall be less than the maximum civil penalty. 
(d)  By resolution, the board of county commissioners shall establish the amount of any civil penalty for a violation. 
(e)  Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by an officer pursuant to this chapter shall be guilty of a violation punishable as provided by F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083, or 775.084. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-17), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-9. - Alternative remedies. 
In addition to the penalties otherwise provided in this chapter, the city or board of county commissioners shall have the right to enforce, by injunction or any other appropriate legal means, compliance with the regulations and requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-18), 4-9-91)  
Secs. 5-10—5-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Penalties and enforcement of provisions regarding care and control of animals, F.S. § 828.27. 
 
Sec. 5-27. - Contract with county. 
(a)  The city is empowered and authorized to contract with the board of county commissioners for the enforcement of this chapter. Any reference to the county animal control officer shall be deemed to be an animal control officer who is acting pursuant to an agreement between the city and county and such county animal control officer shall have authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The city has entered into an agreement with the county and the provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the county animal control officer. 
(c)  Any police officer of the city may arrest without warrant any person found violating any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, §§ 4-2, 4-83, 4-84)  
Sec. 5-28. - Jurisdiction. 
The county is empowered and authorized to enforce this chapter. Any reference to an animal control officer shall be deemed to be an animal control officer who is acting on behalf of the county. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-2), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-29. - Animal control officers. 
(a)  The county animal control director is authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The board of county commissioners may employ animal control officers to assist in the administration and enforcement of this chapter. Such animal control officers shall successfully complete a training program as provided by county policies and in accordance with F.S. § 828.27. 
(c)  Animal control officers are not authorized to bear arms or make arrests. 
(d)  It is a violation of this chapter for any person to resist, obstruct, hinder, or interfere with the animal control supervisor or an animal control officer in the administration or enforcement of this chapter. 
(e)  The animal control supervisor and animal control officers may enter upon public property, and unfenced or insecurely fenced private property, except residential dwellings, to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. The animal control supervisor and animal control officers shall be immune from prosecution for reasonable, good faith trespass upon such private property, as provided in F.S. § 810.12. 
(f)  The animal control supervisor and animal control officers shall investigate complaints of alleged violations of this chapter. 
(g)  The animal control supervisor and animal control officers are hereby authorized to catch, seize, or pick up: 
(1)  Any sick or injured animal, including any animal subjected to cruelty or in need of immediate medical attention; 
(2)  Any animal infected with, or suspected of carrying, rabies or any other infectious disease; 
(3)  Any dangerous animal not properly confined or restrained; 
(4)  Any hazardous animal not properly confined or restrained; 
(5)  Any animal not properly quarantined; 
(6)  Any animal at large; 
(7)  Any animal causing injury, or threat of injury, to any person by being at large, or chasing persons, or by causing property damage to a person other than the owner of the animal; 
(8)  Any female dog or cat in heat not properly confined; 
(9)  Any dog or cat not vaccinated against rabies; and 
(10)  Any animal deemed in violation of this chapter. 
(h)  The animal control supervisor and animal control officers shall impound any animal caught, seized, or picked up pursuant to this chapter. 
(i)  It is a violation of this chapter for any person to remove, or attempt to remove, an animal from the custody of the animal control supervisor or an animal control officer. 
(j)  It is a violation of this chapter for any person to fail to surrender an animal, or the carcass of a dead animal, upon lawful demand by the animal control supervisor or any animal control officer. 
(k)  The animal control supervisor may declare an animal to be a hazardous animal, or dangerous animal, pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, and shall order the owner or keeper of such animal to confine or restrain such animal as required by this chapter. Animal control officers may inspect the premises of the owner or keeper of such animal to determine compliance with any order of the animal control supervisor under this section, and all other provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-4), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-30. - Impoundment of animals. 
(a)  The board of county commissioners may purchase, construct, lease, operate and maintain county shelters, or contract for other shelter facilities, to maintain any animal authorized to be caught, seized, or picked up by the animal control supervisor or animal control officer. 
(b)  It is a violation of this chapter for any person to remove, or attempt to remove, any animal from a county shelter or other shelter facility. 
(c)  The animal control supervisor may engage the services of a licensed veterinarian to treat any sick or injured animal, including any animal subjected to cruelty, or any animal infected with, or suspected of carrying, rabies, which animal has been impounded pursuant to this chapter. The owner or keeper of such animal shall be liable for payment of all veterinary and shelter expenses, and reimbursement of the county's expenses for treating such animal. 
(d)  By resolution, the board shall establish fees to be charged for impounding, boarding, and feeding animals, pursuant to this chapter. 
(e)  No animal impounded pursuant to this chapter shall be released until: 
(1)  The owner or keeper of an impounded dog or cat which is not vaccinated against rabies or which does not have a valid license certificate or license tag arranges for rabies vaccination and obtains a license certificate and license tag for the dog or cat; 
(2)  The owner or keeper of an impounded animal pays the fees for impoundment, board, and feed, and any additional fees for rabies vaccination, veterinary expenses, and license certificate and license tag; 
(3)  The owner or keeper of an impounded animal provides proof of ownership or custody, such as a license certificate, sales receipt, affidavits of neighbors, photographs or other documentary evidence; 
(4)  If a hazardous or dangerous animal is impounded, the owner or keeper of such animal must comply with all provisions of this chapter applicable to such hazardous or dangerous animal; 
(5)  If an animal which has been subjected to cruelty is impounded, the county court issues a release order, as provided by F.S. § 828.073. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-5), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-31. - Disposition of impounded animals. 
(a)  An animal control officer shall attempt to identify and locate the owner or keeper of an animal impounded pursuant to this chapter. If the owner or keeper is identified and located, the animal control officer shall provide notice to the owner or keeper that the animal has been impounded and may be redeemed within five (5) days of such notice. The five-day period for redemption shall not include the day of impoundment. The last day of such five-day period shall only occur on a day that the county shelter or other shelter facility, at which the subject animal has been impounded, is open for business. 
(b)  An animal impounded pursuant to this chapter shall become the property of the county when: 
(1)  The owner or keeper of such animal is not identified or located within five (5) days after impoundment; 
(2)  The owner or keeper of such animal is notified, but does not redeem the animal within five (5) days after notice; 
(3)  Confinement of a wild or feral animal creates unusual risks to such animal or an animal control officer; or 
(4)  Any animal is examined by a licensed veterinarian who determines that the medical condition of the animal warrants humane destruction. 
(c)  When an animal becomes the property of the county, the animal control supervisor may, without further notice to the former owner or keeper: 
(1)  Transfer ownership of such animal to a humane society, humane agency, law enforcement agency, zoo, or other person, institution, or agency, provided that such person, institution, or agency agrees to record the name and address of the new owner upon subsequent transfer of ownership of the animal; or 
(2)  Destroy such animal in a humane manner. 
(d)  Any animal subjected to cruelty impounded under this chapter shall be disposed of as provided by F.S. ch. 828. 
(e)  Any livestock, as defined in F.S. § 588.13, impounded pursuant to this chapter, shall be disposed of as provided by F.S. ch. 588. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-6), 4-9-91)  
Secs. 5-32—5-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Damage by dogs, F.S. ch. 767. 
 
Sec. 5-46. - Limitation on keeping of dogs and cats in residential zones and vacant property. 
No person shall keep or maintain in connection with any building erected in any land use classification in which residential uses are permitted or in any residential unit of a multiple-family or travel trailer, mobile home and modular home land use classification, five (5) or more cats or dogs or combination thereof, six (6) months or older. No person shall keep or maintain on vacant property or in connection with any building used for business, commercial or industrial purposes, more than four (4) dogs. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to permit the use of land or a building as a dog kennel if the land or building is located in a land use classification in which a dog kennel is a permitted use. 
(Code 1963, § 4-35) 
Cross reference— Residential zoning district regulations, § 62.00 et seq., Land Development Regulations, Vol. II.  
Sec. 5-47. - Rabies vaccination of dogs and cats. 
(a)  The owner or keeper of a dog or cat in the city shall cause such dog or cat to be vaccinated against rabies each year by a licensed veterinarian. 
(b)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of a dog or cat to refuse or fail to have the dog or cat vaccinated against rabies as required by this section; provided, however, that rabies vaccination is not required if: 
(1)  A dog or cat is less than four (4) months of age; 
(2)  A dog or cat has been vaccinated against rabies in another state during a period not to exceed one (1) year from the date of the rabies vaccination, provided that the owner of such dog or cat presents a certificate of rabies vaccination to the animal control supervisor; or 
(3)  A licensed veterinarian examines the dog or cat and certifies in writing that rabies vaccination would endanger the health of such dog or cat due to age, infirmity, disability, illness, or other medical condition; provided, however, the licensed veterinarian presents such certificate to the animal control supervisor within five (5) days after the examination, and that dog or cat is confined in a secure enclosure until a licensed veterinarian properly vaccinates the dog or cat. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-14), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-48. - License certificates and license tags. 
(a)  The owner or keeper of a dog or cat in the city which is vaccinated against rabies shall obtain a license certificate and license tag for such dog or cat each year. 
(b)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of a dog or cat to refuse or fail to obtain a license tag for the dog or cat as provided by this section. 
(c)  A license certificate and license tag are not required if the owner or keeper of the dog or cat has not resided in the city for more than the previous twenty-eight (28) days. 
(d)  The animal control supervisor shall approve the form, content and design of the license certificate and license tag. No other license certificate or license tag shall be valid in the city. 
(e)  By resolution, the board of county commissioners shall establish fees to be charged for the issuance of license certificates and license tags. 
(f)  Any resident of the city who owns or keeps a dog guide, especially trained for such purpose, and is being used to assist a deaf person or totally or partially blind person or physically disabled person, as defined in F.S. § 413.08, may obtain a license certificate and license tag for such dog guide at no charge. 
(g)  A license certificate and license tag shall be issued by: 
(1)  The animal control supervisor or designee; or 
(2)  Any licensed veterinarian who administers the rabies vaccination, and has been authorized by the county to collect the fee for such license certificate and license tag. 
(h)  The license certificate shall be signed by the licensed veterinarian administering the rabies vaccination and shall list the date of rabies vaccination, the type of vaccine, information identifying the owner or keeper, and describing the dog or cat. An identification number shall be printed on the license certificate and shall correspond to the same number on the license tag. 
(i)  If a license tag is lost or destroyed, the owner or keeper of the dog or cat shall obtain a replacement license tag. A replacement license tag may be issued to the owner or keeper of a dog or cat upon presentation of a corresponding license certificate and payment of the applicable fee. 
(j)  The license tag shall be attached to the collar or harness of the dog or cat and shall be worn at all times, except when such dog or cat is confined for treatment in a veterinary hospital or clinic operated by a licensed veterinarian or while competing in an organized animal show, trial, or doing training therefor. 
(k)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of a dog or cat to permit or allow the dog or cat to be without a physically attached license tag as required by this section. 
(l)  Each license certificate and license tag shall be valid for a period of one (1) year from the date of the rabies vaccination. 
(m)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of a dog or cat to permit or allow the dog or cat to wear a license tag which has expired. 
(n)  A license certificate or license tag issued for one (1) dog or cat is not valid for any other dog or cat, and it is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of a dog or cat to allow the dog or cat to wear a license tag which has not been issued for such dog or cat. 
(o)  A police dog, as defined in F.S. § 843.19, shall be exempt from wearing a license tag while being used by a law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-15), 4-9-91)  
Secs. 5-49—5-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CARE AND CONTROL OF ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 5-66. - Hazardous animals. 
When the animal control supervisor declares that an animal is a hazardous animal, the animal control supervisor shall provide written notice to the owner or keeper of such animal. The written notice shall include the basis for declaring the animal hazardous, a description of the animal, and describe the responsibility of the owner or keeper for maintenance of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-9), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-67. - Dangerous animals. 
(a)  When the animal control supervisor declares that an animal is a dangerous animal, the animal control supervisor shall provide written notice to the owner or keeper of such animal by registered mail or certified mail or hand delivery. The written notice shall include the basis for declaring the animal dangerous, a description of the animal, and describe the responsibility of the owner or keeper for maintenance of the animal. 
(b)  Within thirty (30) days after the animal has been declared dangerous, the owner of the dangerous animal must obtain a certificate of registration for the dangerous animal from the county animal control, and a certificate shall be renewed annually. The county is authorized to issue such certificates of registration and the renewals thereof only to persons who are at least eighteen (18) years of age and who present to the county animal control evidence of: 
(1)  A current certificate of rabies vaccination for the animal; 
(2)  A secure enclosure to confine a dangerous animal, and the posting of the premises with a clearly visible warning sign at all entry points that informs both children and adults of the presence of a dangerous animal on the property; 
(3)  Permanent identification of the dangerous animal, such as a tattoo on the inside thigh, or an electronic implantation, as specified by the animal control supervisor; and 
(4)  Payment of the applicable annual fee for the issuance of the certificate of registration required by this section. The annual fee shall be established by the board of county commissioners, by resolution. 
(c)  The owner shall immediately notify the appropriate animal control authority when an animal that has been classified as dangerous: 
(1)  Is loose, at large, or unconfined; 
(2)  Is sold, given away, or dies; or 
(3)  Is moved to an address other than that stated in the certificate of registration. 
(d)  Any animal declared to be dangerous shall be confined in a secure enclosure on the premises of the owner or keeper of such animal. No dangerous animal shall be permitted or allowed off the premises of the owner or keeper, unless such animal receives approval by the animal control supervisor or requires veterinary treatment and remains: 
(1)  Inside a locked animal carrier; or 
(2)  Under the physical control of the owner or keeper, and is securely muzzled and restrained by a chain or lead, with a minimal tensile strength of three hundred (300) pounds and which does not exceed three (3) feet in length; and 
(3)  Subject to such further conditions as established by the animal control supervisor. 
(e)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of a dangerous animal to refuse or fail to confine or restrain such dangerous animal as required by this section. 
(f)  It is a violation of this chapter for any person to release or remove a dangerous animal from a secure enclosure, contrary to the provisions of this section. 
(g)  No dangerous animal impounded pursuant to this chapter shall be released until: 
(1)  The owner or keeper of such dangerous animal presents proof to the animal control supervisor that the animal will be confined as required by this section; and 
(2)  The owner or keeper of such dangerous animal executes a sworn affidavit acknowledging that the animal has been declared dangerous, and agreeing to confine and restrain the animal, and recognizing the county's right to ownership and custody of the animal if the animal bites or injures a human being or another animal after being declared dangerous. 
(h)  The owner or keeper of a dangerous animal shall report, in writing, the name and address of any new owner or keeper of the dangerous animal to the animal control supervisor prior to transfer of ownership or custody of such dangerous animal. 
(i)  The owner or keeper of a dangerous animal shall report, in writing or by telephone, the death of such animal to the animal control supervisor immediately. The death of such animal shall be verified by a licensed veterinarian or an animal control officer. 
(j)  This section does not apply to police dogs, as defined in F.S. § 843.19. 
(k)  Any violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a civil infraction, punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), per violation. 
(l)  If an animal that previously has been declared dangerous under this chapter attacks or bites a person or domestic animal without provocation, the owner of the animal, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided under F.S. § 775.082 or F.S. § 775.083. In addition, the animal shall be immediately confiscated by the county animal control, placed in quarantine, if necessary, for the proper length of time, or impounded and held ten (10) business days, and thereafter destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. This ten-day time period shall allow the owner or keeper to apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for any remedies that may be available. The owner or keeper shall be responsible for payment of all boarding costs and other fees as may be required to humanely and safely keep the animal during any appeal procedure. 
(m)  If an animal that has not been previously declared dangerous under this chapter aggressively attacks and causes severe injury to or death of any human, the owner of the dangerous animal, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in F.S. § 775.082 or F.S. § 775.083. In addition, the animal shall be immediately confiscated by the county animal control, placed in quarantine, if necessary, for the proper length of time, or impounded and held ten (10) business days, and thereafter destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. This ten-day time period shall allow the owner or keeper to apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for any remedies that may be available. The owner or keeper shall be responsible for payment of all boarding costs and other fees as may be required to humanely and safely keep the animal during any appeal procedure. 
(n)  If an animal that previously has been declared dangerous under this chapter attacks or bites a person or domestic animal without provocation, the owner of the animal, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided under F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083, or 775.084. In addition, the animal shall be immediately confiscated by the county animal control, placed in quarantine, if necessary, for the proper length of time, or impounded and held ten (10) business days, and thereafter destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. This ten-day time period shall allow the owner or keeper to apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for any remedies that may be available. The owner or keeper shall be responsible for payment of all boarding costs and other fees as may be required to humanely and safely keep the animal during any appeal procedure. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-10), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-68. - Responsibility for animals. 
(a)  The owner or keeper of any animal shall exercise reasonable care to protect humans, other animals, or property from injury or damage caused by the behavior of such animal. 
(b)  The owner or keeper of any animal shall exercise reasonable care to prevent such animal, while unattended, from leaving the premises of such owner or keeper by: 
(1)  Confinement in a secure enclosure, fence, or pen from which the animal cannot dig, climb, jump, or escape, and which is locked when the animal remains unattended; 
(2)  Restraint by chain, cable and trolley, or other tether of sufficient strength to prevent escape; or 
(3)  Leash and physical control of a person capable of preventing such animal from escaping. 
(c)  The owner or keeper of an animal shall exercise reasonable care to maintain such animal while off the premises of such owner or keeper by: 
(1)  Confinement in a secure enclosure, fence, or pen from which the animal cannot dig, climb, jump, or escape; 
(2)  Confinement in a vehicle from which the animal cannot climb, jump, or escape; or 
(3)  Leash and physical control of a person capable of preventing such animal from escaping. 
(Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1(4-11), 4-9-91)  
Sec. 5-69. - Animals at large; confinement of animals. 
(a)  No animal shall be permitted or allowed to be at large. 
(b)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of an animal to permit or allow the animal to be at large. 
(c)  No animal shall be permitted or allowed to cause injury, or threat of injury, to any person, or cause any property damage to a person other than the owner, as a result of the animal being at large. It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of an animal to permit or allow the animal to violate this subsection. 
(d)  No animal shall be permitted or allowed to defecate or urinate upon any public property, or any private property, without permission of the property owner. It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of an animal to permit or allow the animal to defecate or urinate upon any public property, or any private property, without permission of the property owner. 
(e)  No animal shall be permitted or allowed into or on any public park or beach; provided, however, that an area in public parks may be designated for animals by resolution of the board of county commissioners or by the city. In that event, the area provided for animals must be properly identified and posted by the county or the city. 
(f)  It is a violation of this chapter for the owner or keeper of an animal to permit or allow the animal into or on any public beach or any public park not designated for animals and not properly identified and posted.
