Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
 
Sec. 10-26. - Adoption. 
There is hereby adopted by reference, as published by the latest publication of the Standard Housing Code as it may change from time to time. Such code shall be of the same force and effect as if set forth in full in this article. One (1) copy of the code is on file in the office of the building official. 
(Code 1963, § 12A-1; Ord. No. 26-1995, § 10, 9-12-95)  
Sec. 10-27. - Amendments. 
The housing code adopted in section 10-26 is amended as follows: 
(1)  Section 106, on board of adjustments and appeals, is amended to read as follows: 
The board of adjustments and appeals provided for in section 13.00 of the Land Development Regulations, Volume II of the Code of Ordinances of the Code and shall be the applicable board as set forth in section 106 of the last publication of the Standard Housing Code, to decide all matters within the jurisdiction of the housing board of adjustments and appeals; provided, however, that there shall be no fees charged by the city for appeals from the Standard Housing Code, and the provisions of the Standard Housing Code shall govern such board in its proceedings. 
(2)  Section 303, minimum requirements for electrical systems, is amended as follows: 
(a)  Section 303.1. General. All fixtures, receptacles, equipment, and wiring shall be maintained in a state of good repair, safe, capable of being used and installed and connected to the source of electrical power in a safe manner. All services shall be grounded by connection, securely to the building metallic pipe system or a driven ground. 
(1)  No pull-chain type switches shall be allowed which are within normal reach of any water outlet. 
(2)  All electrical installations shall be protected by a fused main disconnect switch or circuit breaker, which shall be placed in an accessible location. The main disconnect shall not be located inside a closet or above a major appliance. 
(3)  The minimum acceptable electrical service shall be a 60 amp. capacity. 
(4)  All knob and tube systems or installations wired with less than N.M.S. cable are by definition obsolete and in violation of this code. 
(b)  Section 303.2. Additions. When wiring or any added load or additional circuits are installed in a building, the service or services shall also be revised as necessary and sizes increased to carry the new total load. Additional circuit protection shall be added for the additional load or circuits. Any new circuit protection required shall be of a type approved under the electric code adopted in section 10-26 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(1)  All extensions or alterations to existing systems shall be made in accordance with the standards of the current electrical code adopted in section 10-26 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Where more than fifty (50) percent of the existing wiring installation is remodeled or changed, all wiring shall be made to meet the requirements of the electrical code adopted in section 10-26 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  Any requirement found necessary due to the condition or occupancy of the building, to insure the safety and welfare of the inhabitants or the public, shall be necessary as if set out in this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 12A-3; Ord. No. 26-1995, § 10, 9-12-95)  
Sec. 10-28. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who shall violate any provisions of the housing code adopted by this article, or who shall fail to comply with such code, or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, construct, alter, demolish or move any structure, or has erected, constructed, altered, repaired, moved or demolished a building or structure in violation of such code shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of the housing code is committed or continued and upon conviction of any such violation such person shall be punished as provided in section 1-15 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1963, § 12A-1) 
Cross reference— Code enforcement board, §§ 14.10—14.40, Land Development Regulations, Vol. II.  
Secs. 10-29—10-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FAIR HOUSING 
 
Sec. 10-51. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the Fair Housing Ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-1)  
Sec. 10-52. - Declaration of policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city, in keeping with the laws of the United States of America and the spirit of the constitution of the state, to promote through fair, orderly and lawful procedure the opportunity for all persons so desiring to obtain housing of their choice in the city, without regard to race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin; and to that end, to prohibit discrimination in housing by any person. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-2; Ord. No. 29-1996, § 1, 10-8-96)  
Sec. 10-53. - Objectives. 
The objectives of the provisions of this article are to provide a positive means for implementation of the above-declared policy and to discourage and eliminate discriminatory practices. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-3)  
Sec. 10-54. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Director shall mean the city manager or some other person designated as provided for in this article. 
Discriminatory housing practice shall mean an act that is unlawful under this chapter. 
Family includes a single individual and shall mean one (1) or more individuals living as a single housekeeping unit; the presence of one (1) or more children under age eighteen (18) living with a parent or legal custodian or their designee; pregnancy; a person adopting or securing legal custody of a child under eighteen (18) years of age. 
Familial status is established when an individual who has not attained the age of eighteen (18) years is domiciled with a: 
(1)  Parent or other person having legal custody of such individual; or 
(2)  Designee of a parent or other person having legal custody with the written permission of such parent or other person. 
Handicapped person shall mean a person who is determined to: 
(1)  Have, has a record of having, or is regarded as having a physical, mental or emotional impairment which substantially limits one (1) or more major life activities (i.e., self-care, performing manual tasks, walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, breathing, learning, or working); 
a.  Is expected to be of a long-continued and indefinite duration; 
b.  Substantially impedes his or her ability to live independently; and 
c.  Is of such a nature that ability could be improved by more suitable housing conditions; or 
(2)  Have a developmental disability, as defined in section 102(7) of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act (42 U.S.C. 6001—6007); or 
(3)  Be the surviving member or members of any family that had been living in an assisted unit with the deceased member of the family who had a disability at the time of his or her death. 
(4)  Physical or mental impairments entail a lengthy list of infirmities which can include, but are not necessarily limited to, such diseases and conditions as orthopedic, visual, speech and hearing impairments, cerebral palsy, autism, epilepsy, muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis, cancer, heart disease, diabetes, Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV or AIDS) infection, mental retardation, emotional illness, drug addiction (other than addiction caused by current, illegal use of a controlled substance), or alcoholism. 
A landlord cannot make preoccupancy inquiries regarding the nature or severity of a prospective tenant's handicap, nor can the landlord ask an individual questions that would require the applicant or tenant to waive rights of confidentiality regarding medical history. However, the law provides that a dwelling need not be made available to an individual "whose tenancy would constitute a direct threat to the health or safety of other individual(s) or whose tenancy would result in substantial physical damage to the property of others." In this regard, the landlord can make inquiries into a tenant's past rental history, and whether an applicant for a dwelling is a current illegal abuser or addict of a controlled substance and whether the applicant has been convicted of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance. 
In addition, an individual cannot be considered to have a handicap solely because that individual is a transvestite. 
Housing or housing accommodation shall mean any building, structure or portion thereof, mobile home or trailer or other such facility, which is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as a residence by one (1) or more families, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure or portion thereof, mobile home or trailer or other such facility. 
Lending institution shall mean any bank, insurance company, savings and loan association or any other person or organization regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans. 
Owner shall mean any person, including but not limited to a lessee, sublessee, assignee, manager or agent, and also including the city and its departments or other subunits, having the right of ownership or possession or the authority to sell or lease any housing accommodation. 
Person shall mean one (1) or more individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint stock companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers, fiduciaries or public corporations. 
Real estate broker shall mean any person duly licensed as a real estate broker in accordance with the laws of the state. 
Real estate salesperson shall mean any person duly licensed as a real estate salesperson in accordance with the laws of the state. 
Real estate transaction shall mean the sale, purchase, exchange, rental or lease of real property, and any contract appertaining thereto. 
Respondent shall mean any person against whom a complaint is filed pursuant to this article. 
To rent shall include to lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-4; Ord. No. 29-1996, § 1, 10-8-96)  
Sec. 10-55. - Discriminatory housing practices. 
(a)  Sale or rental. Except as provided in section 10-56, it shall be unlawful and a discriminatory housing practice for any owner, or any other person engaging in a real estate transaction, or for a real estate broker or salesperson, because of race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin to: 
(1)  Refuse to engage in a real estate transaction with a person or otherwise make unavailable or deny housing to any person. 
(2)  Discriminate against a person in the terms, conditions or privileges of a real estate transaction or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith. 
(3)  Refuse to receive or to fail to transmit a bona fide offer to engage in a real estate transaction from a person. 
(4)  Refuse to negotiate for a real estate transaction with a person. 
(5)  Represent to a person that housing is not available for inspection, sale, rental or lease when in fact it is so available, or to fail to bring a property listing to the person's attention, or to refuse to permit such person to inspect the housing. 
(6)  Steer any person away from or to any housing. 
(7)  Make, print, publish, circulate, post or mail, or cause to be made, printed, published or circulated any notice, statement, advertisement or sign, or to use a form of application or photograph for a real estate transaction or to make a record or oral or written inquiry in connection with a prospective real estate transaction, which indicates directly or indirectly an intent to make a limitation, specification or discrimination with respect thereto. 
(8)  Offer, solicit, accept, use or retain a listing of housing with the understanding that a person may be discriminated against in a real estate transaction or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith. 
(9)  Induce or attempt to induce any person to transfer an interest in any housing by representations regarding the existing or potential proximity of housing owned, used or occupied by any person protected by the terms of this article. 
(10)  Make any misrepresentation concerning the listing for sale or rental, or the anticipated listing for sale or rental, or the sale or rental of any housing within the effective area as governed by this article for the purpose of inducing or attempting to induce any such listing or any of the above transactions. 
(11)  Retaliate or discriminate in any manner against any person resulting from that person's opposition to a practice declared unlawful by this article or because the person has filed a complaint, testified, assisted or participated in any manner in any investigation, proceeding or conference under this article. 
(12)  Aid, abet, incite, compel or coerce any person to engage in any of the practices prohibited by the provisions of this article, or to obstruct or prevent any person from complying with the provisions of this article, or any conciliation agreement entered into thereunder. 
(13)  Canvass or solicit to encourage an unlawful practice prohibited by the provisions of this article. 
(14)  Otherwise deny to, or withhold, any housing accommodations from a person. 
(15)  Promote, induce, influence or attempt to promote, induce or influence by the use of postal cards, letters, circulars, telephone, visitation or any other means, directly or indirectly, a property owner, occupant or tenant to list for sale, sell, remove from, lease, assign, transfer or otherwise dispose of any housing by referring tenants or prospective buyers of any housing as part of a process or pattern or inciting neighborhood unrest, community tension, or fear of change in the composition of any street, block, neighborhood, or any other area, resulting from anticipated neighbors due to their race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin. 
(16)  Cause to be made any untrue or intentionally misleading statement or advertisement, or in any other manner, attempt as part of a process or pattern of inciting neighborhood unrest, community tension or fear of change in the composition of the race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin in any street, block, neighborhood, or any other area, to obtain a listing of any housing for sale, rental assignment, transfer or other disposition, where such statement, advertisement or other representation is false or materially misleading to where there is insufficient basis to judge its truth or falsity or warrant material misrepresentation in order to obtain such listing, sale, removal from, lease, assignment, transfer or other disposition of such housing. 
(17)  Place a sign or display any other device either purporting to offer for sale, lease, assignment, transfer or other disposition or tending to lead to the belief that a bona fide offer is being made to sell, lease, assign, transfer or otherwise dispose of any housing that is not in fact available or offered for sale, lease, assignment, transfer or other disposition. 
(b)  Block busting. It shall be unlawful and a discriminatory housing practice for a person, for the purpose of inducing a real estate transaction from which that person may benefit financially to: 
(1)  Represent that a change has occurred or will or may occur in composition, with respect to race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin, of the owners or occupants in the block, neighborhood or area in which the housing accommodation is located. 
(2)  Represent that the change referred to in subsection (b)(1) above will or may result in the lowering of property values, and increase in criminal or antisocial behavior, or prompt a decline in the quality of schools in the block, neighborhood or area in which the housing accommodation is located. 
(3)  Make, as part of a process or pattern of discouraging the purchase, rental, occupancy or otherwise of any housing in a particular block, neighborhood or area, any representation to a person known to be a prospective purchaser, that such block, neighborhood, or area may undergo, is undergoing, or has undergone a change in composition with respect to the race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin. 
(4)  Engage in, or hire to be done, or to conspire with others to commit actions or activities of any nature, the purpose of which is to coerce, cause panic, incite unrest or create or play upon fear, with the purpose of either discouraging or inducing, or attempting to induce the sale, purchase, rental or lease or the listing for any of the above as detailed under subsections (a)(1) through (a)(3) above of any housing accommodation. 
(c)  Financing. It shall be unlawful and discriminatory housing practice for any lending institution to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, construction, improving, repairing or maintaining housing, or to discriminate against such person in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration, or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance, because of the race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin of such person or of any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance or the purposes of such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of the housing in relation to which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given; provided, that nothing contained in this subsection shall impair the scope of effectiveness of the exceptions contained in section 10-56. 
(d)  Brokerage services. It shall be unlawful and a discriminatory housing practice to deny any person access to, or membership, or participation in any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization, or facility related to the business of selling, or renting housing, or to discriminate against such person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation because of race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin. 
(e)  Fair Housing Act. It shall be unlawful for any person to discriminate or to otherwise violate any provision contained in the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 (Public Law 100-430). 
(Code 1963, § 8B-5; Ord. No. 29-1996, § 1, 10-8-96)  
Sec. 10-56. - Exemptions and exceptions. 
(a)  Nothing in section 10-55 shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society, or any nonprofit charitable or educational institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society from limiting or from advertising the sale, rental or occupancy of housing which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons. Nor shall anything in this chapter prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members, provided that public funds have not been used for the purpose of construction, maintenance or for other purposes directly related to the upkeep of such property. 
(b)  Nothing in section 10-55 other than subsection (a)(7) thereof shall apply to: 
(1)  Any single-family house sold or rented by an owner, provided, that such private individual owner does not own more than three (3) such single-family houses at any one (1) time; provided further, that in the case of the sale of any such single-family house by a private individual owner not residing in such house at the time of such sale or who was not the most recent resident in such house prior to such sale, the exemption granted by this subsection shall apply only with respect to one (1) such sale within any twenty-four-month period; provided further, that such bona fide private individual owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement title to or any rights to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of, more than three (3) such single-family houses at any one (1) time; provided further, that the owner sells or rents such housing: 
(i)  Without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent, or salesperson, or person; and 
(ii)  Without the publication, posting or mailing, after notice, of any advertisement or written notice in violation of section 10-55(a)(7); but nothing in this provision shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies and other such professional assistance as necessary to perfect or transfer the title; or 
(2)  Rooms or units in housing containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four (4) families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one (1) of such living quarters as his residence, provided that the owner sells or rents such rooms or units: 
(i)  Without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent or salesperson, or of such facilities or services of any person in the business of selling or renting housing or of any employee or agency of any broker, agent, salesperson or person; and 
(ii)  Without the publication, posting or mailing, after notice, of any advertisement or written notice in violation of section 10-55(a)(7), but nothing in this provision shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies, and other such professional assistance as necessary to perfect or transfer the title. For the purpose of subsection (a) above, a person shall be deemed to be in the business of selling or renting housing if: 
a.  Such person has, within the preceding twelve (12) months, participated as principal in providing sales or rental facilities or sales or rental services in three (3) or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any housing or any interest therein; 
b.  Such person has, within the preceding twelve (12) months, participated as agent, other than in the sale of such person's own personal residence, in providing sales or rental facilities or sales or rental services in two (2) or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any housing or any interest therein; or 
c.  Such person is the owner of any housing designed or intended for occupancy by, or occupied by, five (5) or more families. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this article shall preclude the seller, lessor, property owner or that person's authorized agent from setting forth reasonable rules, regulations, terms and conditions pertaining to the sale or lease or disposal of such person's property; provided such rules, regulations, terms and conditions are not based on race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin; and provided there is no conflict with the affirmative action provisions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-6; Ord. No. 29-1996, § 1, 10-8-96)  
Sec. 10-57. - Director. 
(a)  Authority and responsibility. The authority and responsibility for administering this article shall be vested in the director, office of the city manager. 
(b)  Powers and duties. The director shall administer the provisions of this article and shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Receive written complaints as provided in section 10-58 relative to alleged unlawful acts as prohibited under this article. 
(2)  Upon receiving a written complaint, make such investigations as the director deems appropriate to ascertain facts and issues. 
(3)  Utilize methods of persuasion, conciliation and mediation for informal adjustment of grievances. 
(4)  Establish, administer or review programs at the request of the city council and make reports on such programs to the council. 
(5)  Bring to the attention of the city council items that may require the council's notice or action to resolve. 
(6)  Render to the city council annual written reports of activities under the provisions of this article along with such comments and recommendations as deemed appropriate. 
(7)  Cooperate with and render technical assistance to federal, state, local and other public and private agencies, or organizations and institutions which are formulating or carrying on programs to prevent or eliminate the unlawful discriminatory practices covered by the provisions of this article. 
(8)  Issue subpoenas to compel access to or the production or appearance of premises, records, documents, individuals and other evidence or possible sources of evidence relative to written complaint. 
(9)  Issue cease-or-desist orders to compel compliance with this article. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-7)  
Sec. 10-58. - Filing complaints. 
(a)  A person who claims that another person has committed a discriminatory housing practice against the claiming person may report the alleged offense to the director, office of the city manager, by filing a complaint within sixty (60) days after the date of the alleged discriminatory housing practice. Individuals entitled to file a complaint: 
(1)  Person who claims to have been injured; or 
(2)  Person who believes that he or she will be injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur. 
(3)  Both the seller/landlord and the purchasing/renting family are aggrieved and can file a complaint when a third party, acts unlawfully to prevent the sale or rental of a unit due to an individual's race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin. (i.e., a homeowner association's refusal to rent or sell a unit to a family with children; or a person refused rent/sell who is associated with another person that is handicapped that may reside or intend to reside in the dwelling after it is sold, rented or made available.) 
(b)  The director shall treat a complaint referred by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development or the Attorney General of the United States under the Fair Housing Act of 1968, Public Law 90-284, as a complaint filed under this article. 
(c)  A complaint must be filed within one (1) year after the alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred, in writing, verified or affirmed, on a form to be supplied by the director and shall contain the following: 
(1)  Identity of the respondent. 
(2)  Date of the alleged offense and date of filing the complaint. 
(3)  General statement of acts of the alleged offense including the basis of the discrimination in regard to race, color, religion, sex, familial status, handicap or national origin. 
(4)  Name and signature of complainant. 
(d)  Within ten (10) days after the filing of the complaint, the director shall transmit a copy of the same to each respondent named therein by certified mail, return receipt requested. Thereupon the respondent may file a written, verified answer to the complaint within ten (10) days of the date of receipt of the complaint from the director. 
(e)  A complaint or answer may be amended at any time when it would be fair and reasonable to do so, and the director shall furnish a copy of each amended complaint or answer to the respondent or complainant, respectively, as promptly as practicable. 
(f)  The director shall assist complainant or respondent when necessary in the preparation and filing of complaints or answers or any amendments thereto. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-8; Ord. No. 29-1996, § 1, 10-8-96)  
Sec. 10-59. - Processing complaints. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days after the filing of a complaint, the director shall make such investigation as deemed appropriate to ascertain facts and issues. If the director shall deem that there are reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this article has occurred and can be resolved by conciliation, the director shall attempt to conciliate the matter by methods of initial conference and persuasion with all interested parties and such representatives as the parties may choose to assist them. 
(b)  If the parties desire to conciliate, the terms of the conciliation shall be reduced to writing in the form approved by the director and must be signed and verified by the complainant and respondent and approved by the director. The conciliation agreement is for conciliation purposes only and does not constitute an admission by any party that the law has been violated. 
(c)  If the director deems that there is not sufficient evidence to form a belief that a violation of this article has occurred, the director shall take no further action with respect to the alleged offense. 
(d)  If the director, with respect to any matter which involves a violation of this article, does not dismiss the complaint and (i) fails to conciliate a complaint after the parties have in good faith attempted such conciliation, or (ii) fails to effect an informal conciliation agreement or formal consent agreement, or (iii) determines that a complaint is not susceptible of conciliation, the director shall, upon the expiration of thirty (30) days after the date of filing the complaint, schedule a public hearing to determine the facts, such hearing to be held not more than forty-five (45) days after the date of filing the complaint. At least ten (10) days prior to the hearing date, the director shall serve upon all interested parties a notice of the time and place of the hearing. The respondent or his authorized counsel may file such statements or affidavits with the director prior to the hearing date as he deems necessary in support of its position. The hearing shall be open to the public. The complainant and the respondent shall appear before the director in person and may have the assistance of an attorney. They may present testimony and evidence, and the right to cross-examine witnesses shall be preserved. All testimony and evidence shall be given under oath or by affirmation. The director shall not be bound by strict rules of evidence. The director shall keep a full record of all hearings. A copy of the hearing record shall be available to any person at such costs as the director deems appropriate. 
(e)  If at any time after the filing of a complaint alleging an unlawful practice in violation of this article, the director determines that the respondent is doing or procuring to be done any act tending to render ineffectual any order the director has entered in such proceeding, the director may request the city attorney to apply to the circuit court for an order temporarily restraining the respondent's activities relating to the subject matter of the complaint, pending final disposition of the complaint, or for such other relief as is necessary for the director to carry out its duties and responsibilities. 
(f)  If the director determines that the complainant has been subjected to an unlawful discriminatory practice, the director shall state its findings of fact and conclusions of law and shall issue an order requiring the respondent to cease and desist from the unlawful practice and to take such affirmative action as in the judgment of the director will carry out the purposes of this article. If the respondent fails to comply with the order, the director may take such other action to compel compliance. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-9)  
Sec. 10-60. - Enforcement. 
If the director cannot resolve the violation, the director shall provide the complainant full and complete information as to the alternatives available to him under local, state and federal law. The director shall include within the information provided to the complainant, a statement indicating that the city will provide free legal counsel to the complainant if he wishes to bring a private suit for relief in a local, state or federal court. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-10)  
Sec. 10-61. - Additional remedies. 
The procedures prescribed by this article do not constitute an administrative prerequisite to another action or remedy available under other law. Further, nothing in this article shall be deemed to modify, impair or otherwise affect any right or remedy conferred by the Constitution or laws of the United States or of the state, and the provisions of this article shall be supplemental to those provided by such other laws. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-11)  
Sec. 10-62. - Untruthful complaints or testimony. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any person knowingly and willfully to make false or untrue statements, accusations or allegations in a complaint or to give false testimony concerning violations of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-12)  
Sec. 10-63. - Penalty. 
This article shall not be covered by section 1-15 of this Code of Ordinances. It is the intention that violations of this article shall be resolved by the procedures provided for within this article or by application of the laws and constitution of the state and the United States. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-13)  
Sec. 10-64. - Severability. 
If any provision of this article or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this article and the application of the provisions to other persons not similarly situated or to other circumstances shall not be affected thereby. 
(Code 1963, § 8B-14)  
ARTICLE IV. - STATE HOUSING INITIATIVE PARTNERSHIP (SHIP) PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 10-65. - Adoption. 
There is hereby adopted by reference, as published by the latest publication of the State Housing Initiative Partnership (SHIP) program in F.S. § 420.9072 and 67-37 FAC, as it may change from time to time. Such code shall be of the same force and effect as if set forth in full in this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-66. - Definitions. 
Adjusted for family size means adjusted in a manner which results in an income eligibility level that is lower for households having fewer than four (4) people, or higher for households having more than four (4) people, than the base income eligibility determined as provided in [this section], based upon a formula established by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Students as defined herein are to be included in the calculation of family size. 
Administrative expenditures means those expenditures directly related to implementation of the local housing assistance plans. 
Affordable means that monthly rent and utilities or mortgage payments, insurance, property taxes, utilities, and homeowner's association fees, where applicable, do not exceed thirty (30) percent of that amount which represents the percentage of the median income for households qualifying under [this section]. 
Annual gross income means the gross amount of wages, income from assets, regular case or non-cash contributions, and any other resources and benefits determined to be income by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. This is the amount of income anticipated to be received by all adults in a household during the twelve (12) months following the effective date of the determination. Anticipated income is generally determined by annualizing current income for the next twelve (12) months. 
Annual report or Form SHIP-AR/07 means a report required to be completed and submitted to the Corporation by September 15 of each year pursuant to F.S. § 420.9075(10). 
Award means a loan, grant, or subsidy funded wholly or partially by the local housing distribution. 
Catalyst means the Affordable Housing Catalyst Program as described in F.S. § 420.531. 
Committee means the affordable housing advisory committee appointed by the City of Titusville City Council to meet the objectives of the affordable housing committee created by F.S. § 420.9072. The committee shall abide by all SHIP rules pursuant to F.S. § 420.907 and will also review the established policies and procedures, ordinances, land development regulations, and adopted local government comprehensive plan, and shall recommend specific actions or initiatives to encourage or facilitate affordable housing while protecting the ability of the property to appreciate in value. 
Debt service means the amount required in any fiscal year to pay the principal of, redemption premium, if any, and interest on bonds and any amounts required by the terms of the documents authorizing, securing, or providing liquidity for bonds necessary to maintain in effect any such liquidity or security arrangements. 
Default means the failure to make required payments on a financial loan secured by a first mortgage which leads to foreclosure and loss of property ownership. 
Deferred payment loan means funds provided to a borrower under terms that calls for repayment to be delayed for a certain length of time, until certain circumstances change, or a certain threshold is met. 
Department means the neighborhood services department. 
Eligible housing means any real and personal property located within the city or the eligibility municipality which is designated and intended for the primary purpose of providing decent, safe, and sanitary residential units that are designed to meet the standards of F.S. ch. 553, for homeownership or rental for eligible persons as designated in the local housing assistance program. Housing must be within the maximum purchase price limitations as established by the United States Department of Treasury in accordance with revenue proclamation 92-34 and must meet affordability requirements in order to qualify as eligible. 
Eligible person means one (1) or more natural persons, a family, or persons who have been determined by the city or eligible municipality to have special housing needs who have been determined to be very low-income, low-income, or moderate-income according to the adjusted gross income of the resident with adjustment made for family size. 
Eligible sponsor means a community-based organization, a private or public for profit or non-profit entity that applies for assistance under the City of Titusville Local Housing Assistance Program for the purpose of providing eligible housing for eligible persons. 
Encumbered means that deposits made to the local affordable housing trust fund have been committed by contract, purchase order, letter of commitment or award in a manner that obligates the county, eligible municipality, or interlocal entity to expend the amount upon delivery of goods, the rendering of services, or the conveyance of real property by a vendor, supplier, contractor, or owner. 
Essential service personnel means pursuant to Chapter 2006-69, Laws of Florida, persons in need of affordable housing who are employed in occupations or professions in which they are considered essential service personnel, as defined by each county and eligible municipality within its respective local housing assistance plan pursuant to F.S. § 420.9075(3)(a). 
Expended or Spent means the affordable housing activity is complete and funds deposited to the local affordable housing trust fund have been transferred from the local housing assistance trust fund account to pay for the cost of the activity. 
Extremely low-income household or ELI means one (1) or more natural persons or a family that has a total annual gross household income that does not exceed thirty (30) percent of the area median income adjusted for family size for households within the metropolitan statistical area, the county, or the non-metropolitan median for the state, whichever is greatest. 
Foreclosure means the legal action by a mortgage holder to require repayment of a loan through the sale of the subject property. 
Forgivable loan means a loan with no repayment obligation if program requirements are met for a specified period of time. 
Grant means as defined in F.S. § 420.9071(12). 
Home ownership activities means the use of local affordable housing trust fund moneys for the purpose of providing owner-occupied housing. Such uses include construction, rehabilitation, purchase, and lease-purchase financing where the primary purpose is the eventual purchase of the housing by the occupant within twenty-four (24) months from initial execution of a lease agreement or within twenty-four (24) months of the applicable fiscal year, whichever occurs first, to meet the requirement of [this section]. 
Interlocal entity means an entity created pursuant to the provisions of F.S. chapter 163, Part I, for the purpose of establishing a joint local housing assistance plan pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 420.9072(5). 
Loan means loan as defined in F.S. § 420.9071(13). 
Low-income person means one (1) or more natural persons or a family, not including students, which have total annual anticipated gross income for the household that does not exceed eighty (80) percent of the median annual income for households, within the city. While occupying a rental unit, a low-income person's annual anticipated gross income may increase to an amount not to exceed one hundred forty (140) percent of eighty (80) percent of the applicable median income adjusted for family size for purposes of meeting the requirements of 67-37.007(9). 
Moderate-income person means one (1) or more natural persons or a family, not including students, which has a total annual anticipated gross income for the household that does not exceed one hundred twenty (120) percent of the median annual income for households within the city. While occupying a rental unit, a low-income person's annual anticipated gross income may increase to an amount not to exceed one hundred forty (140) percent of one hundred twenty (120) percent of the applicable median income adjusted for family size for purposes of meeting the requirements of 67-37.007(9). 
Rehabilitation means repairs or improvements which are needed for safe and sanitary habitation, correction of substantial code violations, or the creation of additional living space. 
Review committee means the committee established pursuant to F.S. § 420.9072(3)(a). 
SHIP or SHIP program means the state housing initiatives partnership program created pursuant to the State Housing Initiative Partnership Act, F.S. § 420.907.9079. 
State means the State of Florida. 
Student means a person not living with his or her parent or guardian who is eligible to be claimed by the person's parent or guardian under the Federal Income Tax Code and who is enrolled at least half time in a secondary school, vocational-technical school, community college, or university. The term does not include a person participating in a job training program approved by the city or eligible municipality. 
Sub recipient means a person or non-state organization contracted by a SHIP eligible local government and compensated with SHIP funds to provide administration of any portion of the SHIP program. 
Very-low income person means one (1) or more natural persons or a family, not including students, which have total annual anticipated gross income for the household that does not exceed fifty (50) percent of the median annual income for households, within the city. While occupying a rental unit, a low-income person's annual anticipated gross income may increase to an amount not to exceed one hundred forty (140) percent of fifty (50) percent of the applicable median income adjusted for family size for purposes of meeting the requirements of 67-37.007(9). 
Welfare transition program means a program pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 445.006. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-67. - Creation of the local housing assistance trust fund. 
(1)  The local housing assistance trust fund is hereby created and established. 
(2)  All monies received from the state pursuant to the State Housing Initiative Partnership Act and any other funds received or budgeted to provide funding for the City of Titusville Housing Assistance Program shall be deposited into the local housing assistance trust fund. Administration of the local housing assistance trust fund shall comply with Rule 67-37.007, Florida Administrative Code. 
(3)  Expenditures other than for the implementation and administration of the Local housing assistance program shall not be made from the local housing assistance trust fund. 
(4)  Amounts on deposit in the local housing assistance trust fund shall be invested as provided by law. All investment earnings shall be retained in the local housing assistance trust fund and used for the purposes thereof. 
(5)  Until utilized for the purposes thereof, monies in the local housing assistance trust fund shall be held in trust by the city solely for use pursuant to the local housing assistance program. All local housing assistance program income, including investment earnings, shall be retained in the local housing assistance trust fund and used for purposes thereof. 
(6)  The City agrees that the local housing assistance trust fund shall be separately stated as a special revenue fund in the city's audited financial statements. Copies of such audited financial statements shall be forwarded annually to the Florida Housing Finance Corporation no later than June 30 of the following fiscal year. 
(7)  Local governments which have an audit review or investigation involving SHIP funds will send the Corporation a copy of any related report within ten (10) days of the issuance of such report. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-68. - Intent and purpose of the local housing assistance program. 
(1)  The intent of the local housing assistance program is: 
(a)  Increase the availability of affordable housing units by combining local resources and cost-saving measures into a local housing partnership and using private and public funds to reduce the cost of housing; 
(b)  Promote innovative design of eligible housing that provides cost savings, flexible design options for housing and development such as the combination of architectural styles, building forms, and development requirements; and positive design features such as orientation towards the street and pedestrian access, without compromising the quality of the eligible housing; 
(c)  Promote mixed-income housing in urban, suburban, and rural areas so as to provide increased housing and economic opportunities for persons who have special housing need, very low-income, low-income, or moderate-income; and 
(d)  Build the organizational and technical capacity of community-based organizations so as to optimize the role of community-based organization in the production of affordable housing. 
(2)  The purpose of this article is to aid in achieving the intent of the local housing assistance program while providing for: 
(a)  Protection of natural resources; 
(b)  Enhancement of viability of public transit, pedestrian circulation, and nonmotorized modes of transportation; 
(c)  Community development and economics growth; and 
(d)  Strong sense of community through increased social and economic integration. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-69. - Establishment of the local housing assistance program. 
(1)  The local housing assistance program is hereby created and established. This program shall apply to the incorporated area of the City of Titusville. 
(2)  Pursuant to Resolution 14-2007, the city hereby specifically finds the cost of administering the local housing assistance program shall exceed five (5) percent of the funding received from the state pursuant to the State Housing Initiative Partnership Act, and authorizes the use of up to ten (10) percent of the SHIP funds and five (5) percent of any program income received from investment of the housing distribution received by the city in a fiscal year for administration of the housing assistance program. 
(3)  The city shall use the funds received from the state pursuant to the State Housing Initiative Partnership Act to implement the local housing assistance program. The detailed design specifications for the use of the trust fund monies will be adopted in the City of Titusville Local Housing Assistance Plan, after review of the statutory requirements and the local needs. The city council will, after giving due consideration to the recommendations of the affordable housing advisory committee, and considering the advice of the department and the comments from the public, adopt the local housing assistance plan. 
(a)  A percentage of the funds may be used by the city to implement the following locally designed strategies: 
1.  Implementation of the local housing assistance plan and incentive strategies that create or preserve affordable housing; 
2.  Supplement corporation programs, for example: the state apartment incentive loan (SAIL) program established under F.S. § 420.5087, the community workforce housing innovation pilot (CWHIP) program, and home ownership assistance program (HAP) established under F.S. § 420.5088, with the SHIP local housing distribution directed to uses within the local government jurisdiction; 
3.  Provide local match to obtain federal housing grants or programs, such as HOME, established by 24 CFR, Part 92; 
4.  Fund emergency repairs by existing service providers under weatherization programs, pursuant to F.S. §§ 409.509—409.5093. 
5.  To further the housing element of the local government comprehensive plan adopted pursuant to F.S. § 163.3184, specific to affordable housing; and 
6.  Home ownership and rental housing activities; however, at least sixty-five (65) percent of each local government's local housing distributions must be used for home ownership activities. 
(4)  The local housing assistance program shall include all other lawful objectives not previously listed if said objectives have been adopted into the local housing assistance plan in the manner provided for by F.S. §§ 420.907—420.9079 and Rule 67-37, Florida Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-70. - Creation of the local housing partnership. 
(1)  The local housing assistance program shall combine City of Titusville resources and cost saving measures into a Titusville Housing Partnership by using private and public funds in order to reduce the cost of housing. 
(2)  The local housing partnership includes, but is not limited to, the City, community-based organizations, for-profit housing developers, lending institutions, providers of professional services relating to affordable housing, and service organizations working on behalf of person with special housing needs. The partnership shall be represented by members of the affordable housing advisory committee created in Section VII of this article in the implementation of the local housing assistance program. 
(3)  The local housing partnership shall implement the local housing assistance program in a manner that provides support services for housing program beneficiaries such as training to prepare persons for the responsibility of homeownership, and counseling of tenants, and the establishment of support services such as day care, health care, and transportation. Such implementation shall be consistent with this article, F.S. §§ 420-970—420.9079, and Rule 67-37, Florida Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-71. - Designation of responsibility for administration and implementation of the local housing assistance program. 
(1)  The neighborhood services department shall be responsible for implementation and administration of the local housing assistance program. 
(2)  The neighborhood services department responsibilities shall be: 
(a)  To work with the committee to: implement the incentive strategies in the local housing assistance plan (LHAP) that create or preserve affordable housing; monitor the success of the local housing assistance program; provide advice and suggestions as to whether and in what ways the local housing assistance program might be improved from year to year; and to develop proposals to initiate and modify, when necessary, the local housing assistance plan. 
(b)  To supplement Florida Housing Finance Corporation programs with the SHIP local housing distribution funds directed to uses within the local government jurisdictions; 
(c)  To provide local match to obtain federal housing grants or programs, such as HOME, established by 24 CFR, Part 92; 
(d)  To fund emergency repairs by existing service providers under weatherization programs, pursuant to F.S. §§ 409.509—409.5093; 
(e)  To further the housing element of the local government comprehensive plan adopted pursuant to F.S. § 163.3184, specific to affordable housing; and 
(f)  To coordinate with City of Titusville programs such as community loan funds, inclusionary housing programs, linkage programs, and with federal programs such as, the community development block grant (CDBG) program, home investment partnership program (HOME), low income rental housing tax credit (LIHTC) program, and section 8 rental assistance so as to maximize the production of eligible housing through the local housing assistance program. 
(3)  The total amount paid for any administrative expenses in connection with the local housing assistance program will not exceed ten (10) percent of the proceeds of the City of Titusville housing distribution and five (5) percent of any program income received from investment of the housing distribution. 
(4)  The city shall not treat as administrative expenses any costs previously borne by another funding source which could continue to be available at the time the local housing assistance plan is submitted. 
(5)  In implementing the local housing assistance program, the department shall: 
(a)  Advertise the availability of a housing assistance program in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and periodicals serving ethnic and diverse neighborhoods, at least thirty (30) days before the beginning of any application period. 
(b)  Adopt a maximum award schedule or system of awards to comply with the following criteria: 
1.  At least sixty-five (65) percent of the funds shall be reserved for homeownership for eligible persons; 
2.  At least seventy-five (75) percent of the funds shall be reserved for construction, rehabilitation, or emergency repair of affordable eligible housing; 
3.  The sales price or value of new or existing eligible housing shall not exceed ninety (90) percent of the median area purchase price in the area where the eligible housing is located as established by the United States Department of Treasury in accordance with subsection 3(b)2 of the United States Housing Act of 1937; 
4.  All units constructed, rehabilitated, or otherwise assisted with program funds shall be occupied by extremely low-, very low-, low-, or moderate-income persons. At least thirty (30) percent of funds must be expended for the benefit of very low-income persons and at least another thirty (30) percent by low-income persons. 
5.  The amount of monthly mortgage payments or the amount of monthly rents charged by the eligible sponsor or its designee must be affordable to eligible persons; 
6.  Loans shall be provided for periods not exceeding thirty (30) years except for deferred payment loans (DPL) or loans that extend beyond thirty (30) years which continue to provide eligible housing for eligible persons; 
7.  Eligible owner-occupied housing constructed, rehabilitated, or otherwise assisted from proceeds provided from the local housing assistance program shall be subject to subsidy recapture provisions which are provided for in the plan; 
8.  Eligible rental housing constructed, rehabilitated, or otherwise assisted from proceeds provided from the local housing assistance program shall be reserved for eligible persons for the greater of fifteen (15) years or the term of the assistance. Eligible sponsors who offer eligible rental housing for sale before fifteen (15) years or that have remaining mortgages funded under the local housing assistance program must give a first right of refusal to eligible non-profit organizations for purchase for continued occupancy by eligible persons; 
9.  The maximum sales price or value per unit and the maximum award per unit for eligible housing benefiting from awards made pursuant to the local housing assistance program shall be established in the approved local housing assistance plan; 
10.  A qualification system for applicants for awards consistent with the intent of the local housing assistance program and F.S. §§ 420.907—420.9079, shall be established by the local housing partnership; 
11.  The department shall annually monitor the local housing assistance plan to determine compliance with the eligibility and affordability provisions (including the amount of subsidy) of this article, and state and federal laws; 
12.  The department shall monitor and determine tenant eligibility and the amount of subsidy pursuant to the provisions of this article, F.S. §§ 420.907—420.9079, and Rule 67-37, Florida Administrative Code. 
(6)  The city, the council, the department, the partnership, and all eligible sponsors shall not discriminate in the provisions of affordable housing and loan application process of eligible persons on the basis of race, creed, religion, color, age, sex, marital status, family status, national origin, or handicap. 
(7)  The city shall comply with all rules and regulations of the Florida Housing Finance Corporation in connection with required reporting by the city of compliance with its local housing assistance program. 
(8)  Prior to receiving an award, all eligible persons or eligible sponsors shall enter into an agreement to comply with the affordable housing criteria provided under F.S. §§ 420.907—420.9079, and this article. All eligible persons or eligible sponsors shall include in the deed transferring ownership of the property to the eligible person or eligible sponsor a covenant agreeing to comply with terms of the above-described laws which covenant will run with the land or in the alternative, the agreement shall be made a part of the mortgage agreement. Failure to comply with the covenant in the mortgage shall result in the default of the mortgage with all remedies and rights for enforcement ensuring to the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-72. - Creation of the affordable housing advisory committee. 
(1)  The affordable housing advisory committee (AHAC) is hereby created and established. The members of the committee shall be appointed by resolution of the city council. 
(2)  The AHAC shall consist of eleven (11) voting members. A simple majority of the appointed voting members shall constitute a quorum. The committee may not take formal actions unless a quorum is present, but may meet to hear presentations if duly noticed. The AHAC shall include the following: 
(a)  One (1) citizen who is actively engaged in the residential home building industry in connection with affordable housing; 
(b)  One (1) citizen who is actively engaged in the banking or mortgage banking industry in connection with affordable housing; 
(c)  One (1) citizen who is a representative of those areas of labor actively engaged in home building in connection with affordable housing; 
(d)  One (1) citizen who is actively engaged as an advocate for low-income persons in connection with affordable housing; 
(e)  One (1) citizen who is actively engaged as a for-profit provider of affordable housing; 
(f)  One (1) citizen who is actively engaged as a non-profit provider of affordable housing; 
(g)  One (1) citizen who is actively engaged as a real estate professional in connection with affordable housing; 
(h)  One (1) citizen who actively serves on the local planning agency pursuant to F.S. § 163.3174; 
(i)  One (1) citizen who resides within the jurisdiction of the local governing body making the appointments; 
(j)  One (1) citizen who represents employers within the jurisdiction; 
(k)  One (1) citizen who represents essential services personnel, as defined in the local housing assistance plan. 
(3)  Members shall serve for a two-year term and may be reappointed for subsequent terms. Vacancies shall be filled within sixty (60) days of the meeting at which the resignation (vacancy) is accepted. Appointments shall be made whenever the terms of appointees expire, and in accord with the regulations set forth herein. All members shall serve until their respective successors have been appointed and qualified. Each appointment to fill a vacancy shall be for the unexpired term and shall be made by the mayor, with approval of the majority of the city council. 
(4)  The AHAC shall comply with the government in the sunshine law, the public records law, and the special provisions regarding notice of affordable housing incentive plan considerations found in F.S. § 420.9076. Minutes of the meeting shall be kept by the department. 
(5)  An organizational meeting of the committee shall be held as soon as practical after the creation by the city council. The AHAC shall annually elect a chairperson, vice-chairperson, secretary, and such other offices as it deems necessary. The chairperson is charged with the duty of conducting meetings in a manner consistent with law. The committee shall adopt reasonable rules of procedures to govern the conduct of its business and the holding of hearings. Meetings of the committee shall be held as needed and may be called by the chairperson upon due notice. All meetings shall be open to the public, announced in advance, and shall provide for public inspection of prepared agendas in advance of all meetings. 
(6)  It is intended that members of the AHAC will be persons of knowledge, experience, judgment and background, and have personal or professional interest or experience in affordable housing. They will have the ability and desire to act in the public interest and represent, insofar as possible, the various special personal and professional interests required to make informed and equitable decisions concerning the provisions of housing which is affordable for all economic segments of the community. 
(7)  Staff, administrative and facility support for the AHAC shall be provided by the department. 
(8)  Triennially, the AHAC shall review the established policies and procedures, ordinances, land development regulations, and adopted comprehensive plan of the City of Titusville, and shall recommend specific actions or initiatives to encourage or facilitate affordable housing while protecting the ability of the property to appreciate in value. The recommendations may include the modification or repeal of existing policies, procedures, ordinances, regulations; the creation of exceptions applicable to affordable housing, or adoption of new policies, procedures, regulations, ordinances, or plan provisions, including recommendations to amend the Titusville Comprehensive Plan and corresponding regulations, ordinances, and other policies. At a minimum, the AHAC shall submit a written report to the city council that includes recommendations on, and triennially thereafter, evaluate the implementation of affordable housing incentives in the following areas: 
(a)  The processing of approvals of development orders or permits, as defined in F.S. §§ 163.3164(7) and (8), for affordable housing projects is expedited to a greater degree than other projects; 
(b)  The modification of impact-fee requirements, including reduction or waiver of fees and alternative methods of fee payment for affordable housing; 
(c)  The allowance of flexibility in densities for affordable housing; 
(d)  The reservation of infrastructure capacity for housing for very low-income, low-income, and moderate-income persons; 
(e)  The allowance of affordable accessory residential units in residential zoning districts; 
(f)  The reduction of parking and setback requirements for affordable housing; 
(g)  The allowance of flexible lot configurations, including zero-lot-line configurations for affordable housing; 
(h)  The modification of street requirements for affordable housing; 
(i)  The establishment of a process by which the City of Titusville considers, before adoption, policies, procedures, ordinances, regulations, or plan provisions that increase the cost of housing; 
(j)  The preparation of a printed inventory of city-owned public lands suitable for affordable housing; 
(k)  The support of development near transportation hubs and major employment centers and mixed use developments. 
The AHAC recommendations may also include other affordable housing incentives identified by the committee. Local governments that receive the minimum allocation under the SHIP program shall perform the initial review but may elect to not perform the triennial review. 
(9)  The AHAC shall be cooperatively staffed by the local government department or division having authority to administer local planning or housing programs to ensure an integrated approach to the work of the committee. 
(10)  The approval by the AHAC of its local housing incentive strategies recommendations and its review of the implementation of local governments previously recommended strategies must be made by affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the AHAC taken at a public hearing. Notice of the time, date, and place of the public hearing of the AHAC to adopt final local housing incentive strategies recommendations must be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice must contain a short and concise summary of the local housing incentives strategies recommendations to be considered by the AHAC. The notice must state the public place where a copy of the tentative AHAC recommendations can be obtained by interested persons. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-73. - Adoption of the affordable housing incentive plan. 
(1)  Within ninety (90) days after the date of receipt of the local housing incentive strategies recommendations from the AHAC, the city council shall adopt an amendment to its local housing assistance plan to incorporate the local housing incentive strategies it will implement within its jurisdiction. The amendment must include, at a minimum, the local housing incentive strategies required under F.S. § 420.9071(16); expedited permit process and ongoing review process. The city council must consider the strategies specified in Section VII paragraph (h)(1)-(11) as recommended by the committee. 
(2)  Upon adoption of the affordable housing incentive plan, the department shall so notify the corporation by certified mail of its adoption of an amendment of its local housing assistance plan to incorporate local housing incentives strategies. The notice shall include a copy of the approved amended plan. 
(3)  The AHAC may perform other duties at the request of the city, including: 
(a)  The provision of mentoring services to affordable housing partners including developers, banking institutions, employers, and others to identify available incentives, assist with applications for funding requests, and develop partnerships between various parties. 
(b)  The creation of best practices for the development of affordable housing in the community. 
(4)  Committee members shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(5)  Committee members shall abide by and be subject to the provisions of F.S. chapter 112, part III, pertaining to the Code of Ethics for Public Officers and Employees. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 10-74. - Severability. 
If any phrase or portion of this article, or the particular application thereof, shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by any court, administrative agency, or other body with appropriate jurisdiction, the remaining sections, subsection, sentences, clauses, or phrases of this article and their application shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Chapter 11 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1]
