No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a taxicab as passengers than the normal seating capacity for which the vehicle was constructed. At no time shall such number exceed four (4) persons in the rear seat nor three (3) (including the driver) in the front seat, where the driver is located. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(Code 1963, § 25-17; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 7, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-39. - Passengers—Refusal to carry orderly passengers prohibited. 
No driver shall refuse or neglect to carry any orderly person, upon request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this chapter to do so. 
(Code 1963, § 25-18; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 7, 6-9-09)  
Secs. 22-40—22-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TAXICAB DRIVER'S PERMIT 
 
Sec. 22-56. - Required. 
No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the streets within the city, and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit it to be so driven, and no taxicab holding a business tax receipt by the city shall be so driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of such taxicab shall have first obtained and shall have then in force a taxicab driver's permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 25-7; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-57. - Application. 
An application for a taxicab drivers' permit shall be filed with the administrator on forms provided by the city. Such application shall be verified under oath and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name, permanent address, current address, birth date and citizenship of the applicant. 
(2)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers. 
(3)  The educational background of the applicant. 
(4)  A concise history of his employment. 
(5)  Current state driver's license number applicable to for-hire drivers with date of expiration. 
(6)  The names and addresses of three (3) people who have known the applicant for a period of at least one (1) year and who will vouch for the sobriety, honesty and general good character of the applicant. 
(7)  The name and address of the liability insurance carried or surety company providing liability coverage on the taxicab to be driven by the applicant. 
(Code 1963, § 25-8; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-58. - Application fee, photograph. 
At the time the application for a taxicab drivers' permit is filed, the applicant shall pay to the administrator the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00), which sum shall be nonrefundable and attach thereto two (2) passport-size photographs of a good likeness of the applicant. 
(Code 1963, § 25-8; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-59. - Police investigation of applicant. 
The applicant for a taxicab drivers' permit shall be required to report to the police department to submit to being fingerprinted on one (1) applicant fingerprint card to be supplied by the police department. The applicant shall also submit two (2) passport-size photographs of a good likeness of the applicant to be attached to the fingerprint card. 
(Code 1963, § 25-9; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-60. - Investigation. 
The administrator shall forward the completed application for a taxicab drivers' permit to the police department who shall, with the aid of the completed fingerprint card, conduct an investigation of the applicant. A report of such investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application which shall then be returned to the administrator. 
(Code 1963, § 25-9; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-61. - Consideration of application. 
(a)  The administrator shall, upon receipt of the application for a taxicab drivers' permit and investigation from the police department, forward the same to the administrator for consideration. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby given authority to reject any application for a taxicab drivers' permit to operate a motor vehicle for the transportation of persons for hire within the city when the applicant is incapacitated by reason of infirmities due to age, physical defects or is addicted to the use of narcotics or the habitual use of intoxicating liquors which would render such person unfit to operate a motor vehicle for hire within the city, and the city manager, in determining whether such person is addicted to the habitual use of intoxicating liquors, may consider any applicant's reputation for sobriety as reflected by the record of the applicant's convictions before any court having jurisdiction in the city as disclosed by the records of such court. 
(c)  The city manager shall also have the authority to reject any such application when it appears to him, as reflected in the police investigation and court records of the applicant, that the applicant has been convicted of any crime which would be considered hazardous to any prospective passenger who may be transported in a taxicab driven by the applicant. 
(d)  If the application is rejected, the applicant may request a personal appearance before the city council in appeal of the city manager's decision, to offer evidence why his application should be accepted. The city manager shall, after the city council's decision upon the appeal, act in concurrence therewith and issue the permit if so decided by the city council. 
(Code 1963, § 25-10; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09)  
Sec. 22-62. - Issuance, duration and annual fee. 
(a)  Upon approval of an application for a taxicab drivers' permit, the administrator shall issue a permit to the applicant which shall bear the name, address, age, signature and photograph of the applicant. 
(b)  Such permit shall be in effect after issuance and shall be due and payable on September 30 of each year and shall expire on September 30 of the succeeding year. Any permit that is issued on or after April 1 of the current receipt year shall be required to pay one-half (½) of the amount of the permit for the applicable classification under the provisions of this chapter and shall expire on September 30 of the current year, unless the permit for the preceding year has been revoked or suspended. If September 30 falls on a weekend or holiday, the tax shall be due and payable on or before the first working day following September 30. 
(c)  Such permit shall be issued and/or renewed by the administrator upon the payment of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(Code 1963, § 25-11; Ord. No. 24-2009, § 8, 6-9-09; Ord. No. 55-2018, § 2, 12-11-18)  
Sec. 22-63. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The city manager is vested with the power and authority to suspend the taxicab drivers' permit of any operator who shall have been convicted before any court of competent jurisdiction for the offense of operating a vehicle negligently or at a speed or in such a manner as to endanger or to be likely to endanger the life, limb, or property, of a person or driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. The permit of any persons so suspended or revoked by the city manager by reason of conviction of the offenses named in this subsection shall be suspended for a period not exceeding six (6) months. 
(b)  The city manager is further vested with the power and authority to suspend or revoke the permit of any operator who shall have been convicted before any court of competent jurisdiction for any crime which would be considered hazardous to any prospective passenger who may be transported in a taxicab by the operator. The permit of any persons so suspended or revoked by the city manager by reason of such conviction for the offenses described in this subsection shall be suspended or revoked for a period of not less than six (6) months. Such period of suspension or revocation shall be set by the city manager who shall have discretion in the same as the nature of the crime shall dictate. 
(c)  The city manager is further vested with the power and authority to suspend and reject for a period of six (6) months the permit of any persons granted for the operation of a motor vehicle for the transportation of persons for hire within the city upon the conviction of such person before any court having jurisdiction in the city of the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or of any of the ordinances of the city regulating the operation of motor vehicles for hire. 
(d)  A permit may not be suspended or revoked unless the driver has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence in his behalf. 
(Code 1963, § 25-12)  
ARTICLE III. - HORSE-DRAWN VEHICLES OR CARRIAGES 
 
Sec. 22-64. - Definitions. 
Applicant means any person who makes an application to the City of Titusville for a horse-drawn vehicle for hire permit. 
Business tax receipt shall mean a business tax receipt issued annually by the city in accordance with section 11-31 of the Code of Ordinances. The business tax receipt shall apply to the operation of the horse-drawn vehicle business, and each horse-drawn vehicle for hire shall obtain an individual permit in accordance with this article. 
City manager shall mean the city manager or his/her designee. 
Horse-drawn vehicle shall mean any vehicle or carriage which is drawn or pulled by a horse, mule or any other beast of burden which may be hired for the transportation of passengers and which is operated within the limits of the City of Titusville. 
Operate or operation shall include operation by the business owner or any agent of the business owner or by any person with the business owner's knowledge, consent or permission, expressed or implied. 
Permit means the grant by the city to operate an individual horse-drawn vehicle upon the streets of the City of Titusville. 
Person shall include an individual, a firm, a co-partnership, a corporation, a company or any others whatsoever owning, controlling, or having charge or possession of a horse-drawn vehicle for hire in the City of Titusville. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-65. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a horse-drawn vehicle in or upon any street in the City of Titusville unless and until such person shall have first obtained a horse-drawn vehicle permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article and from the State of Florida a driver's license. 
(b)  An individual permit is required for each horse-drawn vehicle under this section, in addition to a business tax receipt required in accordance with section 11-31 of the Code of Ordinances. Said permit shall be of a type provided by the city manager, shall be affixed to the horse-drawn vehicle in a manner prescribed by the city manager, and shall be non-transferable from the vehicle for which the same was issued except as may be authorized by the city. The city manager is hereby authorized to establish a fee for each transfer. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-66. - Business tax receipt required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or carry on the business of operating a horse-drawn vehicle or carriage for transportation of passengers for hire, either with or without drivers, within the city, without first obtaining a business tax receipt from the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-67. - Application for permit; approval, denial of application; appeal; permit fee; lost, destroyed permits; renewal of permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain a permit to operate a horse-drawn vehicle in the City of Titusville shall submit to the city a written application which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number, driver's license number with date of expiration, and form of business of the applicant. The trade name, if any, under which the applicant has been issued a business tax receipt by the City of Titusville. 
(2)  The business tax receipt for owning and operating the business of horse-drawn vehicles. 
(3)  At the time the application for a horse-drawn vehicle driver's permit is filed, the applicant shall pay to the administrator the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00), which sum shall be nonrefundable and attach thereto two (2) passport-size photographs of a good likeness of the applicant. 
(4)  A thorough description including photographs of the proposed horse-drawn vehicle business to be operated; the manner in which the applicant proposes to operate the business; the proposed hours of operation; proposed location from which the business is to be operated; the proposed route or routes to be served or utilized, together with a map or maps describing the proposed routes; the type of animal or beast of burden to be used to draw any vehicle; the kind, make and model of the vehicles to be used in the business. City approval of proposed routes shall not substitute any required owners authorization. 
(5)  A thorough description of the proposed manner and location in which the applicant proposes to feed, shelter, quarter and stable and otherwise care for the animal to be used in the business, and the method to be used in transporting the animals within and without the city. 
(6)  An individual certificate of soundness identifying each animal that will be pulling a permitted vehicle that is issued by an equine veterinarian licensed in the State of Florida. The certificate of soundness must specify that the inspected animal is free from infectious disease and is fit for service. Each animal shall thereafter be re-inspected at intervals of no more than twelve (12) months, and a certificate of soundness shall be issued by such veterinarian and filed with the city in order for each such animal to remain in service. No animal shall be used to draw a horse-drawn vehicle without such certificate of soundness certified and dated within any preceding six-month period from the date of permit application. 
(7)  An insurance certificate proving that the applicant has met the insurance requirements of section 22-69. 
(8)  A notarized statement acknowledging the applicant's familiarity with and eligibility under the provisions of this section and any rules and regulations promulgated hereunder, and the applicant's intention to abide by the same. 
(9)  A thorough description of the proposed manner and location in which the applicant proposes to dispose of animal waste together with the safety and sanitation devices and methods to be employed. 
(10)  A sworn written statement as to whether or not the applicant has been either charged or convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the disposition or penalty assessed therein. 
(11)  A copy of an Equine Infectious Anemia (EIA) Laboratory Test form issued by an equine veterinarian licensed in the State of Florida for each individual horse to be used in a horse-drawn vehicle service, and which form indicates a negative test result within the past six (6) months. 
(12)  Any such supplementary information the city shall at any time demand in order to reasonably determine whether the request for a permit should be granted. 
(b)  Upon receipt and acceptance of a complete application for a permit, city staff shall evaluate the application for public health, safety and welfare concerns as pertains to his or her area of regulation. If the applicant's plan for service meets with the approval of the reviewing official, the official shall report said approval in writing to the city manager. If said plan or application does not meet the approval of the reviewing official, the official shall report said disapproval to the city manager with reasons for disapproval listed in writing. If the application is disapproved by the city manager, the application for permit shall be denied, and no permit to operate horse-drawn vehicles shall be issued to the applicant. 
(c)  Once the application is approved, the city shall issue an operating permit to the applicant in accordance with this article. Said permit shall be renewed or expire annually in accordance with the associated business tax receipt. 
(d)  If the application is denied, or if the permit is revoked under the enforcement of this article, an appeal may be taken to the city manager by any applicant or individual affected by any decision of the city. Such appeals shall be made within thirty (30) days after a decision by the city, by filing in writing with the city a notice of appeal, and specifying the grounds thereof. 
(e)  If a permit issued under this section is lost or destroyed, the permit holder may obtain a duplicate upon payment of ten dollars ($10.00) administrative charge. 
(f)  Any person to whom a permit has been issued, under the provisions of this article, shall be entitled to renew such permit from year to year; provided, however, that such person shall fully comply with the provisions of this article and such other ordinances, rules and regulations as shall be enacted or adopted from time to time by the city; provided further, renewal of said permit shall be issued by the city manager upon payment of the annual fifteen dollar ($15.00) permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-68. - Adherence to plan submitted in application. 
Permittees must adhere to the routes and vehicle number and design as specified in their application for permits. Any deviance from said application without the approval of the city shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-69. - Liability and indemnification. 
(a)  A permittee shall pay, and by its acceptance of a permit specifically agrees to pay, any and all damages or penalties which the city may be legally required to pay as a result of the permittee's operation or maintenance of a horse-drawn vehicle under this article, whether or not the acts or omissions complained of are authorized, allowed or prohibited by the city. 
(b)  A permittee shall also pay all expenses incurred by the city in defending itself with regard to any and all damages and penalties mentioned in subsection (1) above. The expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses, including a reasonable attorney's fee and the reasonable value of services rendered by any employee of the city. 
(c)  The permittee shall maintain, throughout the term of the permit, liability insurance insuring the city and the permittee with regard to all damages mentioned in subsection (1) above caused by the grantee or its agents, in the minimum amounts of: 
(1)  Workers' and unemployment compensation insurance as provided by the laws of this state. 
(2)  One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any one (1) person within the limit, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for bodily injury or death resulting from any one (1) accident, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one (1) accident. 
(d)  The insurance policies obtained by a permittee in compliance with this section shall be insured by a company or companies acceptable to the city and a current certificate or certificates of insurance, along with written evidence of payment of all required premiums, shall be filed and maintained with the city during the term of the permit. The policies shall name the city as an additional insured and shall contain a provision that written notice of cancellation or reduction in coverage of the policy shall be delivered by registered mail to the city at least thirty (30) days in advance of the effective date thereof. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-70. - Compliance with traffic regulations. 
(a)  A permittee, having been issued a permit under this article to engage in the business of operating horse-drawn vehicles, shall be subject to all traffic provisions of this Code and all other ordinances, rules and regulations now in effect in the city or the State of Florida and all traffic ordinances and rules and regulations which may pertain to the operation of horse-drawn vehicles, hereafter enacted or adopted by the city or the State of Florida, and such rules and regulations formulated and promulgated under authority of this article, and as set forth in chapter 20 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a horse-drawn vehicle to take on or discharge passengers while the vehicle is in motion. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-71. - Sanitation. 
All permittees shall comply with the following sanitation requirements: 
(a)  All horses, mules and other animals shall be equipped with adequate devices to prevent manure and other excrement from falling upon the streets of the city. Any excrement which remains upon the streets of the city shall be removed at the expense of permittee. 
(b)  All animal waste for disposal shall be promptly transported to a site designated for waste disposal. The city reserves the right to approve or disapprove sites taking into account routes within the city, and the rules and regulations of the governmental body having jurisdiction over said sites or facilities. 
(c)  A permittee shall further comply with all applicable health and sanitation provisions of the Sanitary Code of Florida and all rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-72. - Condition and inspection of horse-drawn vehicles. 
(a)  Each horse-drawn vehicle shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition at all times. The city shall have the right to inspect or cause to be inspected any horse-drawn vehicle as often as may be necessary for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any unsafe or unsanitary conditions or any violations of this article or any other rule, regulation, ordinance or law relating to the operating of such horse-drawn vehicles. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby authorized to establish a fee for each such inspection, and is further authorized to establish and promulgate rules and regulations and minimum standards for the inspection and condition of horse-drawn vehicles. 
(c)  If any horse-drawn vehicle shall fail to pass such inspection, it shall be removed from service on the day of inspection, and shall remain out of service until it has passed inspection. 
(d)  All horse-drawn vehicles used by a permittee shall have conspicuously displayed on the exterior of the vehicle the name of the business under which such permittee operates. A copy of the permit shall be displayed inside the vehicle or carriage at all times. 
(e)  Equipment and safety requirements. 
(1)  Every animal-drawn vehicle in service shall have the following equipment on the vehicle, which equipment shall be maintained in good repair: 
a.  Body condition. 
b.  Reflectors, front and rear. 
c.  Grab handles. 
d.  Traces. 
e.  Harness. 
f.  Seats. 
g.  Rubber surfaced wheels. 
h.  Horn. 
i.  Shafts. 
j.  Steps. 
k.  Lights on any vehicle licensed to operate at night. 
l.  Brakes. 
m.  Sign located on the rear of the vehicle indicating that the vehicle is "slow moving." 
n.  Equine emergency supplies. 
(2)  An animal-drawn vehicle shall be maintained in a clean well-painted manner and provide a generally good appearance. 
(3)  Failure to comply with this section of the Code shall be considered a violation subject to penalty. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-73. - Animal safety. 
(a)  Animals shall not engage in work with harnesses or bits which harm or are unsafe to the animal. 
(b)  Harnesses, bridles, bits and padding shall be properly fitted and kept oiled, clean and in good repair. 
(c)  Harnesses shall be kept free of makeshift materials like wire, rope and rusty chain. 
(d)  Trace chains shall not put pressure on the collar and shoulders of the animal when it starts pulling the vehicle or carriage resulting in a jolting start versus a smooth start with a snug collar already in place. 
(e)  Breeching shall fit so that it will not rub or hinder the hind leg movement of the animal. 
(f)  Service with horse-drawn vehicles shall terminate during adverse weather conditions. When either the ambient temperature reaches ninety-five (95) degrees Fahrenheit or the heat index reaches one hundred five (105) degrees Fahrenheit, as determined by the weather station at the Titusville Weather Station (KFLTITUS13) the operators and drivers shall discontinue working their animals and pull them off the street until the temperature decreases below the above-stated temperatures as directed by the city manager or the fire department. 
(g)  Permittee is responsible for seeing that the animals used shall be adequately cared for and are not overworked. Any abuse or neglect of these animals shall be grounds for the revocation of permit(s). Adequate records to determine the hours the animal worked must be maintained by each permittee. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-74. - Revocation of permits. 
Whenever there is reasonable cause to believe that a person holding a permit to operate a horse-drawn vehicle is violating the provision of this article, the city manager may, upon written, certified notice of said violation to the permittee, suspend the permits issued to such person until such time as the violations are corrected to the satisfaction of the city or within a period of thirty (30) days, whichever is less. If said violation is not corrected within thirty (30) days the permit will be automatically revoked. Any permittee whose permits have been revoked under this subsection may within thirty (30) days after said revocation, appeal to the board of adjustments and appeals. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-75. - Enforcement; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. Each day the violation exists shall constitute a separate violation for the purposes of this article and shall be punishable as such and/or said violation may be processed as a code violation pursuant to F.S. Ch. 162 and the municipal code enforcement board. 
(b)  The City of Titusville City Attorney's Office is authorized to pursue temporary or permanent injunctive relief or any other legal or equitable remedy authorized by law in courts of competent jurisdiction to cure, remove or end any activity which violates this article. 
(c)  Permittees shall have a private right of action to pursue all legal and equitable remedies necessary to ensure full compliance with this article against any other permittee, including, but not limited to, injunctive relief. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)  
Sec. 22-76. - Conflict with state law. 
Nothing in this article is intended to conflict with the provisions of the Florida Constitution or the State Uniform Traffic Control Law, Ch. 316, F.S. In the event of a direct and express conflict between this article and either the Florida Constitution or F.S. Ch. 316, then the provisions of the Florida Constitution or F.S. Ch. 316, as applicable, control. 
(Ord. No. 13-2015, § 2, 4-14-15)

ADOPTING ORDINANCE-1990 CODE 
ORDINANCE NO. 20-1990 
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF TITUSVILLE, FLORIDA AMENDING THE CODE OF ORDINANCES BY ADOPTING VOLUME II OF THE CODE ENTITLED CITY OF TITUSVILLE LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS PROVIDING FOR AUTHORITY, PURPOSE, DEFINITIONS, ADMINISTRATION OF REGULATIONS, ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMITTEES AND BOARDS, PROVIDING PROCEDURES AND PROCESSES FOR FILING FOR PERMITS, SITE PLANS, SUBDIVISION APPROVAL, ZONING, CONDITIONAL USES, VARIANCES, APPEALS, ENFORCEMENT, FEES AND OTHER PROCESSES, ESTABLISHING PERFORMANCE STANDARDS FOR REMOVAL OF TREES, LANDSCAPING, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, PROTECTION OF NATURAL TOPOGRAPHY, FLOOD DAMAGE, WETLANDS, THREATENED AND ENDANGERED PLANTS AND WILDLIFE; ESTABLISH PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS FOR STREETS, SIDEWALK, BIKEWAYS, PARKING, UTILITIES, SIGNS, ARCHITECTURAL CONTROL, HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC MANAGEMENT, CONCURRENCY MANAGEMENT AND OTHERS; ESTABLISHING ZONING DISTRICTS AND CLASSIFICATIONS FOR RESIDENTIAL, COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL, GOVERNMENTAL AND OTHER DISTRICTS; ESTABLISHING OVERLAY DISTRICTS OF PUD, PIP, COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT, TITUSVILLE SHORELINE; AIRPORT IMPACT, CONSERVATION, AREA OF CRITICAL CONCERN, FLOOD PLAINS, HISTORIC PRESERVATION, PUBLIC USES AND CONDITIONAL USES, ESTABLISHING REQUIREMENTS FOR SUBDIVISIONS PROCESSING AND PROCEDURES, ADOPTING CERTAIN APPENDIXES, ILLUSTRATIONS AND EXHIBITS; PROVIDING FOR AN EFFECTIVE DATE; PROVIDING VESTED RIGHTS ESTABLISHING PROCEDURES FOR SUBMITTING CLAIMS, PROCEDURES FOR CHALLENGING DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS AND OTHERWISE PROVIDING FOR AN EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, Florida is a municipal corporation organized and existing pursuant to Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963, Article VIII, Section 2 of the Constitution of the State of Florida, and Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville possesses certain governmental, corporate, and proprietary powers to conduct and perform municipal functions; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, pursuant to its Home Rule Powers, possesses full governmental authority to manage and determine growth within its corporate limits subject to and only limited by applicable law; and, 
    WHEREAS, the legislature of the State of Florida has enacted the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act commonly referred to as Sections 163.3161 through 163.3243, Florida Statutes (1989); and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, pursuant to its governmental and proprietary powers, and Home Rule Powers and pursuant to Chapter 163, Florida Statutes, prepared a comprehensive plan together with certain elements and maps; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville on September 27, 1988, adopted a Comprehensive Plan to preserve, promote, protect, and improve the public health, safety, and welfare of its citizens; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville's Comprehensive Plan was adopted, pursuant to Section 163.3177, consisting of certain elements, capital improvements element, future land use element, traffic circulation element, sanitary sewer, solid waste, drainage, potable water, and natural groundwater, aquifer recharge element, conservation element, recreation and open space element, coastal management element, intergovernmental coordination element, and housing element; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville desires to implement said Comprehensive Plan by adopting certain Land Development Regulations as authorized by Section 163.3202, Florida Statutes, and as authorized by Article VIII, Section 2, Constitution of the State of Florida and Chapter 166, Florida Statutes, and Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville has provided for public participation in the formulation and development of these regulations and has received input from the Local Planning Agency and a Special Committee known as LDR Ad Hoc Committee and the general public; and, 
    WHEREAS, the Planning and Zoning Commission on April 25, 1990 has made a recommendation to the City Council as to the consistency of the Land Development Regulations with the Comprehensive Plan; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City Council, pursuant to Chapters 163 and 166, Florida Statutes, held a public hearing on said Land Development Regulations on May 10, 1990 and May 24, 1990 after due public notice and received public input; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City Council desires to adopt the attached Land Development Regulations with the effective date specified in this Ordinance; 
    WHEREAS, the City Council finds the regulations to be consistent with the City of Titusville Comprehensive Plan. 
    NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY OF TITUSVILLE, FLORIDA as follows: 
Section 1. Authority. 
    This Ordinance is being adopted pursuant to Article VIII, Section 2, Constitution of the State of Florida; Chapter 163, Florida Statutes; Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963; Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 163, Florida Statutes entitled Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act. 
Section 2. Purpose and Intent. 
    The City hereby declares that the purpose and intent of this Ordinance is to provide for the City of Titusville Land Development Regulations which will guide future growth and development; encourage the most appropriate use of land, water and other resources consistent with the public interest; preserve, promote, and protect the public health, safety, comfort, good order, appearance, convenience, and general welfare; preserve the residential or historical character of neighborhoods, prevent the overcrowding of land, avoid undue concentration of population; provide adequate and energy-efficient transportation, water, sewage, drainage, fire protection, law enforcement, schools, parks, recreation facilities, housing and other services, facilities and resources; enhance the aesthetic appeal of the community; and conserve and protect natural resources within the City of Titusville, while protecting private property rights. 
Section 3. Adoption of Land Development Regulations. 
    That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Titusville, Florida, is hereby amended by adopting by reference as Volume II of the Code of Ordinances the attached City of Titusville Land Development Regulations which reads as set forth in said volume. 
Section 4. Effective Date. 
    That Part I, General Provisions , Sections 1-5, Part II, Sections 10-18, Part III, Procedures and Process , Sections 20-33, Part IV, Environmental Protection and Conservation , Sections 40-46, Part V, General Performance Requirements , Sections 50, 51, 52, 53, 57, Part VI, Zoning , Sections 60, 62.10, 62.20, 64 and 65, Sections 67.20, 67.30, 67.40, 67.50, 67.60, 67.70, 67.80, 67.90, Part VII, Subdivisions , Sections 70, 72, 73 and Part VIII, Appendixes/Illustrations/Exhibits , Sections 83, 83.10, 83.20, 83.30, 83.40, 83.50, 83.60, 83.70, 83.71, 83.72, 83.73, 83.74, 84, 84.10, 84.20, 84.30, 84.60, 84.70, 84.80 and 84.90 is hereby adopted effective July 1, 1990. All other remaining Parts or Sections not expressly adopted as of July 1, 1990 shall become effective on December 17, 1991. All future development shall comply with these regulations in accordance with the above effective date provisions unless said development is entitled to Vested Rights. 
(Ord. No. 5-1991, § 4, 1-22-91; Ord. No. 14-1991, § 1, 5-28-91) 
Section 5. Grandfather Provision. 
    All lawful existing development to the extent of any conflict with these regulations shall be entitled to be continued as provided for in Part III, Section 31, of the Land Development Regulations. 
Section 6. Vested Rights. 
    In the event any provision of these regulations would limit or modify the rights of any person to complete any development that has been previously authorized, then in that event, the City may recognize said right to complete said development as provided herein. The City hereby recognizes the right of any person to complete the following development: 
a.  Development that has received a building permit; 
b.  Development that has received final plat approval or final site plan; 
c.  Development that has received preliminary plat approval, preliminary subdivision approval, preliminary PUD approval or preliminary site plan approval provided said development has secured a permit to construct all or any phase of said development and is continuing said development in good faith; 
d.  Any development that has on file with the City completed application for building permit and required exhibits and continues to process and obtain a building permit within sixty (60) days. 
    Any person who has a right to complete said development and has secured a building permit, final plat approval, final site plan approval, or preliminary approval as provided above shall lose its right to complete said development if said development does not maintain a current building permit, or current site plan or development approval as provided for by the Code of Ordinances of the City. Once a development has lost its current approval, then in that event, future development shall comply with applicable regulations. 
    The City may recognize other applications for vested rights in accordance with the following procedure: 
1.  Any property owner who claims to have vested rights based upon a prior approval from the City other than as provided above, may submit to the City Manager, within one hundred twenty (120) days after the effective date of this Ordinance, a written request for recognition of said vested rights. 
2.  The applicant shall submit such information as he deems appropriate to demonstrate his claim of vested rights including legal description of property, dates of any recent rezoning, preparation of any plans, approval of any plans, any action of the City upon which applicant has relied, facts showing substantial reliance or change in position. 
3.  Within ninety (90) days after receipt of said application, the City Council shall either recognize or reject the applicant's claim of vested rights. In reviewing the application, the City Council shall be guided by the case of Hollywood Beach Hotel v. City of Hollywood , 329 So.2d 10 (Fla. 1976) and other applicable law. If this City fails to act upon said request within ninety (90) days, then said application shall be deemed to be denied. No suit shall be filed by the applicant unless prior thereto the applicant has made a request of the City prior to said litigation. 
Section 7. Constitutional Claims. 
    In the event any person claims that any provision of the Land Development Regulations constitute a taking of the land owner's property without due process of law and the payment of just compensation as provided for in the Florida Constitution and the Constitution of the United States of America, then in that event, said person shall first present said claim to the City of Titusville. 
    Any person claiming said taking shall: 
1.  Submit said claim in writing identifying the name and address of the property owner. 
2.  The present use of the property. 
3.  The present land use designation and zoning classification. 
4.  The particular provision of the LDR that said person believes to have constituted a taking. 
5.  The remedy requested. 
6.  Documentation or other evidence demonstrating the economic deprivation. 
7.  Case law or authority, if any, which demonstrates the taking. 
8.  Such other information demonstrating how said LDR constitutes a taking. 
    After the City has received said request, it shall have ninety (90) days to review and act upon said request. Due public notice as required by Chapters 163 and 166 shall be provided prior to granting any relief under this Section. The City reserves its full legislative function to act upon requests under this Section and said actions shall be presumed to be fairly debatable. 
Section 8. Administrative Revisions of LDR. 
    The City hereby adopts by reference the provisions of Section 163.3213, Florida Statutes (1989). All challenges to any land development regulations by any substantially affected person shall first be presented to the City of Titusville and reviewed and acted upon in accordance with said statutes prior to any court action. 
Section 9. Repeal. 
1.  The following Sections of the Code of Ordinances are hereby repealed simultaneous with the adoption of comparable provisions in the Land Development Regulations, Chapter 2, Article II, Sections 2-41 to 2-43, Chapter 4B, Sections 4B-1 to 4B-15, Chapter 5, Article V, Sections 5-66 to 5-86, Chapter 6C, Sections 6C-1 to 6C-8, Chapter 8A, Article I, Sections 8A-1 to 8A-8, Article 1A, Landscaping, Sections 8A-9 to 8A-15, Article III, Sections 8A-23 to 8A-43, Article IV, Sections 8A-44 to 8A-52, Chapter 12B, Sections 12B-1 to 12B-28, Chapter 12C, Sections 12C-1 to 12C-15, Chapter 19, Sections 19-1 to 19-5, Chapter 22, Sections 22-4, 22-7 to 22-12 and 22-14, Chapter 23, Sections 23-1 to 23-36, Chapter 29, Sections 29-1 to 29-34 and 29-50. 
2.  In the event any Section of the Code is repealed and said section is referenced in another section of the Code, then for purposes of that section not repealed, the referenced section shall remain in full force and effect. 
3.  These Land Development Regulations shall supersede any other regulations or Codes of the City to the extent of any conflict. In the event of any doubt as to which regulation prevails, the more restrictive regulation shall prevail. 
Section 10. Effective date. 
    This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon adoption. 
    PASSED AND ADOPTED this 22nd day of January, 1991. 
(Ord. No. 5-1991, § 10, 1-22-91) 
/s/ Thomas R. Mariani 
      THOMAS R. MARIANI, Mayor   ATTEST: 
/s/ Janet R. Camacho 
      JANET R. CAMACHO, City Clerk   ADOPTING ORDINANCE-1992 CODE 
ORDINANCE NO. 7-1992 
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF TITUSVILLE, FLORIDA, PROVIDING FOR AUTHORITY, PURPOSE AND INTENT; AMENDING THE CODE OF ORDINANCES BY AMENDING VOLUME II OF THE LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS BY AMENDING SECTION 5 BY CHANGING AND ADDING CERTAIN DEFINITIONS; AMENDING SECTIONS 25.20(C) BY REQUIRING PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION TO SUBMIT A REPORT MAKING CERTAIN FINDINGS; AMENDING THE CODE BY ADOPTING REGULATIONS REGARDING SIGNAGE; ADOPTING SECTION 61 BY ESTABLISHING CERTAIN ZONING DISTRICTS; ADOPTING SECTIONS 62.00 THROUGH 62.09, ESTABLISHING GENERAL REGULATIONS OF RESIDENTIAL ZONING DISTRICTS; AMENDING SECTIONS 62.10 THROUGH 62.17, RESIDENTIAL ESTATE DISTRICTS (RE); AMENDING SECTIONS 62.20 THROUGH 62.27, RURAL RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS (RR); ADOPTING SECTIONS 62.30 THROUGH 62.37, SINGLE FAMILY LOW DENSITY (R-1a); SECTIONS 62.40 THROUGH 62.47, SINGLE FAMILY MEDIUM DENSITY (R-1b); SECTIONS 62.50 THROUGH 62.57, SINGLE FAMILY HIGH DENSITY (R-1c); SECTIONS 62.60 THROUGH 62.68, MULTIFAMILY MEDIUM DENSITY RESIDENTIAL, (R-2); SECTIONS 62.70 THROUGH 62.78, MULTIFAMILY HIGH DENSITY RESIDENTIAL (R-3); SECTIONS 62.80 THROUGH 62.88, RESIDENTIAL MANUFACTURED HOUSING (RMH-1); SECTIONS 62.90 THROUGH 62.99, RESIDENTIAL MANUFACTURED HOUSING PARK (RMH-2); SECTIONS 63.00 THROUGH 63.18, COMMERCIAL DISTRICT - GENERAL PROVISIONS; SECTIONS 63.10 THROUGH 63.18, HOSPITAL-MEDICAL (HM); SECTIONS 63.20 THROUGH 63.28, TOURIST (T); SECTIONS 63.30 THROUGH 63.39, NEIGHBORHOOD COMMERCIAL (NC); SECTIONS 63.40 THROUGH 63.49, COMMUNITY COMMERCIAL (CC); SECTIONS 63.50 THROUGH 63.59, REGIONAL COMMERCIAL (RC); SECTIONS 63.60 THROUGH 63.69, OFFICIAL-PROFESSIONAL (OP); SECTIONS 63.70 THROUGH 63.79, COMMERCIAL MARINE (CM); AMENDING SECTION 64 BY REPEALING SECTIONS 64.01 THROUGH 64.42 AND ADOPTING SECTIONS 64.00 THROUGH 64.07, GENERAL PROVISIONS, SECTIONS 64.10 THROUGH 64.19, LIGHT INDUSTRIAL SERVICES AND WAREHOUSING (M-1), SECTIONS 64.20 THROUGH 62.29, INDUSTRIAL, (M-2), SECTIONS 64.30 TROUGH 64.39, HIGHWAY INDUSTRIAL (M-3), SECTIONS 64.40 THROUGH 64.49, PLANNED INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT (PID); AMENDING SECTIONS 65.00 THROUGH 65.05 BY ESTABLISHING GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR SPECIAL DISTRICTS; AMENDING SECTION 65.10 THROUGH 65.15 BY CHANGING GENERAL USE (GU) DISTRICT REGULATIONS AND ADOPTING SECTIONS 65.10 THROUGH 65.18; AMENDING SECTIONS 65.20 THROUGH 65.25 BY REPEALING SAID SECTIONS AND ADOPTING NEW SECTIONS 65.20 THROUGH 65.28, OPEN SPACE AND RECREATION (OR) REGULATIONS; ADOPTING SECTIONS 65.30 THROUGH 65.39, DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT (DMU) REGULATIONS, DISTRICT AND STANDARDS; ADOPTING SECTIONS 65.40 THROUGH 65.49, URBAN MIXED USE (UMU) DISTRICT AND STANDARDS; ADOPTION SECTION 65.50 THROUGH 65.59, SHORELINE MIXED USE (SMU); ADOPTING SECTIONS 65.60 THROUGH 65.69, RHP DISTRICTS; ADOPTING SECTIONS 67.10 THROUGH 67.19, PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT OVERLAY DISTRICT (PUD); REPEALING SECTIONS 67.20 THROUGH 67.23; REPEALING SECTIONS 67.30 THROUGH 67.39; AMENDING SECTION 70 BY REPEALING SAID SECTION AND ADOPTING SECTIONS 70 THROUGH 70.40, GENERAL SUBDIVISION REQUIREMENTS AND STANDARDS; ADOPTING SECTIONS 71.00 THROUGH 71.60, PROVIDING FOR MINOR SUBDIVISION AND REGULATIONS; AMENDING SECTIONS 72.00 THROUGH 72.34 BY CHANGING REQUIREMENTS FOR MAJOR SUBDIVISIONS; PROVIDING FOR AN EFFECTIVE DATE, GRANDFATHERING PROVISION, VESTED RIGHTS, CONSTITUTIONAL CLAIMS, ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW OF LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS, REPEAL OF CERTAIN PROVISIONS; AND PROVIDING FOR AN EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, Florida is a municipal corporation organized and existing pursuant to Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963, Article VIII, Section 2 of the Constitution of the State of Florida, and Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville possesses certain governmental, corporate, and proprietary powers to conduct and perform municipal functions; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, pursuant to its Home Rule Powers, possesses full governmental authority to manage and determine growth within its corporate limits subject to and only limited by applicable law; and, 
    WHEREAS, the legislature of the State of Florida has enacted the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act commonly referred to as Chapter [Sections] 163.3161 through 163.3243, Florida Statutes (1989); and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, pursuant to its governmental and proprietary powers, and Home Rule Powers and pursuant to Chapter 163, Florida Statutes, prepared a comprehensive plan together with certain elements and maps; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville on September 27, 1988, adopted a Comprehensive Plan to preserve, promote, protect, and improve the public health, safety, and welfare of its citizens; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville's Comprehensive Plan was adopted, pursuant to Chapter [Section] 163.3177, consisting of certain elements, capital improvements element, future land use element, traffic circulation element, sanitary sewer, solid waste, drainage, potable water, and natural groundwater, aquifer recharge element, conservation element, recreation and open space element, coastal management element, intergovernmental coordination element, and housing element; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville desires to implement said Comprehensive Plan by adopting certain Land Development Regulations as authorized by Chapter [Section] 163.3202, Florida Statutes, and as authorized by Article VIII, Section 2, Constitution of the State of Florida and Chapter 166, Florida Statutes, and Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville has provided for public participation in the formulation and development of these regulations and has received input from the Local Planning Agency and a Special Committee known as LDR Ad Hoc Committee and the general public; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville on June 19, 1990 adopted certain Land Development Regulations and desire to adopt additional Land Development Regulations; and, 
    WHEREAS, the Planning and Zoning Commission on March 18, 1992, has made a recommendation to the City Council as to the consistency of the Land Development Regulations with the Comprehensive Plan; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City Council, pursuant to Chapters 163 and 166, Florida Statutes, held a public hearing on said Land Development Regulations on April 2, 1992 and April 16, 1992 after due public notice and received public input; and, 
    WHEREAS, the City Council desires to adopt the attached Land Development Regulations with the effective date specified in this Ordinance; 
    WHEREAS, the City Council finds the regulations to be consistent with the City of Titusville Comprehensive Plan. 
    NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY OF TITUSVILLE, FLORIDA as follows: 
Section 1. Authority. 
    This Ordinance is being adopted pursuant to Article VIII, Section 2, Constitution of the State of Florida; Chapter 163, Florida Statutes; Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963; Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 163, Florida Statutes entitled Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act. 
Section 2. Purpose and Intent. 
    The City hereby declares that the purpose and intent of this Ordinance is to provide for the City of Titusville Land Development Regulations which will guide future growth and development; encourage the most appropriate use of land, water and other resources consistent with the public interest; preserve, promote, and protect the public health, safety, comfort, good order, appearance, convenience, and general welfare; preserve the residential or historical character of neighborhoods, prevent the overcrowding of land, avoid undue concentration of population; provide adequate and energy-efficient transportation, water, sewage, drainage, fire protection, law enforcement, schools, parks, recreation facilities, housing and other services, facilities and resources; enhance the aesthetic appeal of the community; and conserve and protect natural resources within the City of Titusville, while protecting private property rights. 
Section 3. Adoption of Land Development Regulations. 
    That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Titusville, Florida, is hereby amended by adopting by reference the attached changes or amendments to Volume II of the Code of Ordinances Land Development Regulations which reads as set forth in the attachments. 
Section 4. Effective Date. 
    The provisions of this Ordinance shall become effective immediately upon adoption. All future development shall comply with these regulations unless said development is entitled to Vested Rights. 
Section 5. Grandfather Provision. 
    All lawful existing development to the extent of any conflict with these regulations shall be entitled to be continued as provided for in Part III, Section 31, of the Land Development Regulations. Any property or development which is currently zoned in a zoning district repealed by this Ordinance (i.e. BR) shall be entitled to be continued to be used or developed under the former zoning district until such time as the property is administratively rezoned in a new zoning district. Once administratively rezoned, new development shall conform to the new zoning district and these Regulations. Existing development shall be entitled to continue as provided for in Part III, Section 31, of the Land Development Regulations. 
Section 6. Vested Rights. 
    In the event any provision of these regulations would limit or modify the rights of any person to complete any development that has been previously authorized, then in that event, the City may recognize said right to complete said development as provided herein. The City hereby recognizes the right of any person to complete the following development: 
a.  Development that has received a building permit; 
b.  Development that has received final plat approval or final site plan; 
c.  Development that has received preliminary plat approval, preliminary subdivision approval, preliminary PUD approval or preliminary site plan approval provided said development has secured a permit to construct all or any phase of said development and is continuing said development in good faith; 
d.  Any development that has on file with the City completed application for building permit and required exhibits and continues to process and obtain a building permit within sixty (60) days. 
    Any person who has a right to complete said development and has secured a building permit, final plat approval, final site plan approval, or preliminary approval as provided above shall lose its right to complete said development if said development does not maintain a current building permit, or current site plan or development approval as provided for by the Code of Ordinances of the City. Once a development has lost its current approval, then in that event, future development shall comply with applicable regulations. 
    The City may recognize other applications for vested rights in accordance with the following procedure: 
1.  Any property owner who claims to have vested rights based upon a prior approval from the City other than as provided above, may submit to the City Manager, within one hundred twenty (120) days after the effective date of this Ordinance, a written request for recognition of said vested rights. 
2.  The applicant shall submit such information as he deems appropriate to demonstrate his claim of vested rights including legal description of property, dates of any recent rezoning, preparation of any plans, approval of any plans, any action of the City upon which applicant has relied, facts showing substantial reliance or change in position. 
3.  Within ninety (90) days after receipt of said application, the City Council shall either recognize or reject the applicant's claim of vested rights. In reviewing the application, the City Council shall be guided by the case of Hollywood Beach Hotel v. City of Hollywood , 329 So.2d 10 (Fla. 1976) and other applicable law. If this City fails to act upon said request within ninety (90) days, then said application shall be deemed to be denied. No suit shall be filed by the applicant unless prior thereto the applicant has made a request of the City prior to said litigation. 
Section 7. Constitutional Claims. 
    In the event any person claims that any provision of the Land Development Regulations constitute a taking of the land owner's property without due process of law and the payment of just compensation as provided for in the Florida Constitution and the Constitution of the United States of America, then in that event, said person shall first present said claim to the City of Titusville. 
    Any person claiming said taking shall: 
1.  Submit said claim in writing identifying the name and address of the property owner. 
2.  The present use of the property. 
3.  The present land use designation and zoning classification. 
4.  The particular provision of the LDR that said person believes to have constituted a taking. 
5.  The remedy requested. 
6.  Documentation or other evidence demonstrating the economic deprivation. 
7.  Case law or authority, if any, which demonstrates the taking. 
8.  Such other information demonstrating how said LDR constitutes a taking. 
    After the City has received said request, it shall have ninety (90) days to review and act upon said request. Due public notice as required by Chapters 163 and 166 shall be provided prior to granting any relief under this Section. The City reserves its full legislative function to act upon requests under this Section and said actions shall be presumed to be fairly debatable. 
Section 8. Administrative Revisions of LDR. 
    The City hereby adopts by reference the provisions of Chapter [Section] 163.3213, Florida Statutes (1989). All challenges to any land development regulations by any substantially affected person shall first be presented to the City of Titusville and reviewed and acted upon in accordance with said statutes prior to any court action. 
Section 9. Repeal. 
1.  The following Sections of the Code of Ordinances are hereby repealed simultaneous with the adoption of comparable provisions in the Land Development Regulations, Sections 16A, 20-21 through 20-29, 27-1, 27-2(b) and (d), 27-3, through 27-8, 27-10 through 27-21, 29-35, 29-36, 29-50 through 29-56, 29-58, 29-60, 29-61, 29-63, 29-64 through 29-67, 29-69, 29-75 through 29-94, 29-109, 29-116, 29-155 through 29-197, 29-199 through 29-231, 29-244, 29-270 through 29-279, 67.20 through 67.23, and 67.30 through 67.39. 
2.  In the event any Section of the Code is repealed and said section is referenced in another section of the Code, then for purposes of that section not repealed, the referenced section shall remain in full force and effect. 
3.  These Land Development Regulations shall supersede any other regulations or Codes of the City to the extent of any conflict. In the event of any doubt as to which regulation prevails, the more restrictive regulation shall prevail. 
Section 10. Effective date. 
    This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon adoption. 
    PASSED AND ADOPTED this 16th day of April, 1992. 
/s/ Thomas R. Mariani 
      THOMAS R. MARIANI, Mayor   ATTEST: 
/s/ Janet R. Camacho 
      JANET R. CAMACHO, City Clerk   ADOPTING ORDINANCE-2017 CODE 
ORDINANCE NO. 27-2016 
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF TITUSVILLE, FLORIDA, AMENDING THE CODE OF ORDINANCES AND LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS; SPECIFICALLY AMENDING AND REFORMATTING VOLUME II "LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS"; SPECIFICALLY AMENDING CHAPTER 27 "GENERAL PROVISIONS" BY REMOVING ARTICLE II "DEFINITIONS" AND RENUMBERING ARTICLE III "INTENT" TO ARTICLE II "INTENT", ADDING ARTICLE III "FUTURE LAND USE MATRIX" AND ARTICLE IV FUTURE LAND USE I ZONING COMPATIBILITY MATRIX; RENUMBERING CHAPTER 59 "ZONING" TO NEW CHAPTER 28 "ZONING", AMENDING PROVISIONS RELATED TO DISTRICT BOUNDARIES, ADDING A ZONING USE TABLE, CONSOLIDATING AND AMENDING ZONING DISTRICT STANDARDS, DELETING INDUSTRIAL PERFORMANCE STANDARDS TO BE RELOCATED TO OTHER CODE SECTIONS, ADDING DEFINITIONS, ESTABLISHING REGULATIONS RELATED TO ACCESSORY DWELLING UNITS AND MINIMUM CONDITIONS RELATED TO CHURCHES, REMOVING THE CONDITIONAL USE REQUIREMENTS FOR ASSISTED LIVING FACILITIES AND REFERENCES TO STATE REQUIREMENTS RELATED TO RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT FACILITIES, ADDING ANIMAL KENNEL USE TO CERTAIN COMMERCIAL ZONING DISTRICTS, AMENDING REGULATIONS RELATED TO ACCESSORY USES IN CERTAIN ZONING DISTRICTS, ADDING REGULATIONS RELATED TO OUTDOOR DISPLAY OF MERCHANDISE IN COMMERCIAL ZONING DISTRICTS, REMOVING THE COMMERCIAL MARINA (CM) ZONING DISTRICT, DELETING THE COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT WAIVER SUBCOMMITTEE; ADDING NEW CHAPTER 29 "SPECIAL DISTRICTS AND OVERLAYS", AMENDING TITUSVILLE SHORELINE AREA OVERLAY BE CORRECTING THE TERM MEAN HIGH WATER LINE, CONSOLIDATING AIRPORT IMPACT OVERLAY DISTRICT REGULATIONS AND ADDING REFERENCED MAPS, REMOVING STATE REGULATIONS FROM WETLAND AND CONSERVATION DISTRICT, REPLACING HISTORIC PRESERVATION OVERLAY LANGUAGE WITH LANGUAGE FROM EXISTING LANGUAGE RELATED TO HISTORIC RESOURCES FROM CHAPTER 48, REMOVING LANGUAGE RELATED TO PLANNED INDUSTRIAL PARK OVERLAY, ADDING EXISTING STANDARDS RELATED TO ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY DISTRICTS, AREA OF CRITICAL CONCERN OVERLAY AND SPECIAL LAND USE STANDARDS, AMENDING REGULATIONS RELATED TO VILLAGE CENTERS, CONSERVATION SUBDIVISIONS, AND PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICTS; CREATING CHAPTER 30 "DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS", ESTABLISHING ADMINISTRATIVE EXCEPTIONS AND OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE STANDARDS, AMENDING DEFINITIONS AND STANDARDS RELATING TO TREES AND VEGETATION, REMOVING REGULATIONS SUPERCEDED BY FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS RELATED TO HABITAT OF PROTECTED SPECIES, REFERENCING STANDARDS FOR WETLANDS AND RIPARIAN BUFFERS, AMENDING BULKHEAD/DREDGE AND FILL PERMITS REQUIREMENTS, RENUMBERING SECTIONS RELATED TO TOPOGRAPHY AND FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT, ESTABLISHING INTENT FOR REGULATION OF HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC MATERIALS; AMENDING CHAPTER 31 "ADMINISTRATION" BY RENAMING TO "AGENCIES AND BOARDS", ESTABLISHING A DEVELOPMENT REVIEW COMMITTEE TO REVIEW AND APPROVE CERTAIN DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS; RENUMBERING AND CONSOLIDATING EXISTING CODE SECTIONS TO CREATE CHAPTER 32 "SIGNS", REMOVING REFERENCES TO COMMERCIAL BUSINESS DISTRICT (CBD) ZONING DISTRICT, AMENDING REGULATIONS RELATED TO BUSINESS LICENSES AND SIGN REGULATIONS, COMMERCIAL ACCESSORY STRUCTURES AND USES, PENNANT SIGNS, AND SIGNS WITHIN THE DOWNTOWN MIXED USE DISTRICT; RENUMBERING AND AMENDING SECTIONS OF CHAPTER 59 "ZONING" TO CREATE NEW CHAPTER 33 "DEVELOPMENT OPTIONS" TO INCLUDE REGULATIONS RELATED TO PLANNED DEVELOPMENT (PD), PLANNED INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT (PID), PLANNED OFFICE PARK (POP), REGIONAL MIXED USE (RMU), URBAN VILLAGE (UV), NEIGHBORHOOD VILLAGE, CLUSTER SUBDIVISION, CONSERVATION SUBDIVISION DESIGN, AND TRANSFER OF DEVELOPMENT RIGHTS; RENUMBERING AND CONSOLIDATING EXISTING CODE SECTIONS TO CREATE NEW CHAPTER 34 "PROCEDURES" RELATING TO PROCEDURES FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL FOR OBTAINING COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AMENDMENTS, REZONINGS, MASTER PLANS, CONDITIONAL USE PERMITS, SUBDIVISIONS, MINOR DIVISIONS, SMALL SCALE PLATS, PLATS AND SITE PLANS, ADDING ENABLING LANGUAGE RELATED TO DEVELOPMENT REVIEW PROCEDURES MANUALS, SETTING FORTH PROCEDURES RELATED TO VARIANCES, APPEALS, WAIVERS, ENFORCEMENT, NONCONFORMING USES, STRUCTURES/VESTED RIGHTS AND ESTABLISHING CERTIFICATE OF NONCONFORMING USE; RENUMBERING PORTIONS OF CHAPTER 27 "GENERAL PROVISIONS" TO CREATE NEW CHAPTER 37 "DEFINITIONS" AND ADDING NEW DEFINITIONS; CONSOLIDATING EXISTING CODE FROM CHAPTER 34 "PROCEDURES" INTO A PROCEDURES MANUAL; CONSOLIDATING EXISTING CODE AND CREATING TECHNICAL MANUALS ENTITLED "ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION", "HAZARDOUS MATERIALS", "LANDSCAPING", "STORMWATER MANAGEMENT", "TRANSPORTATION" AND "CONCURRENCY"; DELETING CHAPTER 35 "ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION", CHAPTER 39 "GENERAL PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS", CHAPTER 43 "MOBILE AND MODULAR HOUSING", CHAPTER 47 "PROCEDURES AND PROCESSES, CHAPTER 48 "PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC RESOURCES, ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES AND ZONES", CHAPTER 51 "SUBDIVISIONS", CHAPTER 55 "WATERWAYS", CHAPTER 59 "ZONING", AND CHAPTER 63 "APPENDICES/ILLUSTRATIONS/ EXHIBITS AND INCORPORATING PROVISIONS WITHIN THE REFORMATTED CODE; PROVIDING FOR AUTHORITY; PURPOSE AND INTENT; SEVERABILITY; REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES; INCORPORATION INTO THE CODE; GRANDFATHERING; AND AN EFFECTIVE DATE. 
WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, Florida is a municipal corporation organized and existing pursuant to Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963, Article VII, Section 2 of the Constitution of the State of Florida, and Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; and 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville possesses certain governmental, corporate, and proprietary powers to conduct and perform municipal functions; and 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville, pursuant to its Home Rule Powers, possesses full governmental authority to manage and determine growth within its corporate limits subject to and only limited by applicable law; and 
    WHEREAS, the City of Titusville has adopted an comprehensive plan consistent with Chapter 163, Florida Statutes; and 
    WHEREAS, on June 19, 1990 the Titusville City Council adopted certain Land Development Regulations and additional Land Development Regulations on April 16, 1992; and 
    WHEREAS, the Titusville City Council has subsequently amended the Land Development Regulations as needed to address changing conditions as well as correct errors and omissions; and 
    WHEREAS, the Titusville City Council desires to make corrections as needed and update the current Land Development Regulations for ease of use, and so directed staff to undergo a process to update the current Code; and 
    WHEREAS, the Planning and Zoning Commission have considered the proposed Code amendments on numerous occasions, and on October 5, 2016 made a recommendation to the City Council as to the adoption of the Land Development Regulations amendments; and 
    WHEREAS, the City Council, pursuant to Chapter 163 and 166, Florida Statutes, and after due public notice held a public hearing to receive public input on said Land Development Regulations on October 11, 2016 and October 25, 2016, and 
    WHEREAS, the City Council desires to adopt the attached Land Development Regulations with the effective date specified in this Ordinance. 
    NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ENACTED by the City of Titusville, Florida as follows: 
Section 1. Authority. 
    This ordinance is being adopted pursuant to Article VII, Section 2, Constitution of the State of Florida; Chapter 163, Florida Statutes; Chapter 63-2001, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1963; Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 163, Florida Statutes entitled "Growth Policy; County and Municipal Planning; Land Development Regulation." 
Section 2. Purpose and intent. 
    The City hereby declares that the purpose and intent of this Ordinance is to provide for the City of Titusville Land Development Regulations which will guide future growth and development; encourage the most appropriate use of land, water and other resources consistent with the public interest; preserve, promote, and protect the public health, safety, comfort, good order, appearance, convenience and general welfare; preserve the residential or historical character of neighborhoods; provide adequate and energy-efficient transportation, water, wastewater treatment, stormwater treatment, fire protection, law enforcement, schools, recreational facilities, housing and other services, facilities and resources; enhance the aesthetic appeal of the community; and conserve and protect natural resources within the City of Titusville, while protecting private property rights. 
Section 3. That the Land Development Regulations of the City of Titusville, Volume II, is hereby repealed and replaced by reference the attached exhibit "A", which reads as set forth in the attachments. 
Section 4. SEVERABILITY. If any provisions of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Ordinance. 
Section 5. REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES. All ordinances or parts of ordinances, and all resolutions and parts of resolutions, in conflict herewith are hereby repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
Section 6. INCORPORATION INTO CODE. This ordinance shall be incorporated into the City of Titusville Code of Ordinances and any section or paragraph, number or letter, and any heading may be changed or modified as necessary to effectuate the foregoing: Grammatical, typographical, and like errors may be corrected and additions, alterations, and omissions, not affecting the construction or meaning of this ordinance and the Code may be made. 
Section 7. GRANDFATHERING. All lawful existing development to the extent of any conflict with these regulations shall be entitled to be continued as provided for in the Land Development Regulations. 
Section 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be become in full force and effect upon adoption by the City Council in accordance with the Charter of the City of Titusville, Florida. Adoption of this ordinance provides a hiatus of the effective date by 180 days from the adoption date of this ordinance. This hiatus period will allow for an evaluation period to determine how the ordinance can be modified to be implemented. This hiatus period can be extended an additional 180 days at the discretion of the City Council. 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 25 th day of October, 2016. 
/s/ James H. Tulley, Jr. 
      JAMES H. TULLEY, JR., Mayor   ATTEST: 
/s/ Wanda F. Wells 
      WANDA F. WELLS, City Clerk

TITUSVILLE LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS 
Chapter 27 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - PREFACE 

Sec. 27-1. - Short title. 
    This ordinance shall be known as the "Land Development Regulations" or the "LDRs" of the City of Titusville. 
Sec. 27-2. - Authority. 
(a)  These Land Development Regulations are adopted pursuant to the provisions of the Constitution of the State of Florida and Chapters 163 and 166 of the Florida Statutes and pursuant to the Charter of the City of Titusville. 
(b)  Whenever any provision of this ordinance refers to or cites a section of the Florida Statutes and that section is later amended or superseded, this ordinance shall be deemed amended and refer to the amended section or the section that superseded the original section. 
Sec. 27-3. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  These regulations are applicable within the corporate limits and planning jurisdiction of the City of Titusville, as generally shown on the Future Land Use Map (FLUM) adopted as part of the Comprehensive Plan of the City of Titusville, as most recently amended. A copy of the FLUM is available for public inspection in the Community Development Department located in City Hall. 
(b)  These regulations shall be applicable to all development within the City of Titusville. These regulations shall apply to all applications submitted to the City by an applicant pursuant to securing approval of any development order within the corporate limits as now and hereafter established by the City of Titusville, Florida, which shall include, but not be limited to, industrial parks, planned developments, subdivisions, mobile home parks, travel trailer parks, townhouses, multifamily or motel hotel units, or any other development projects of any kind and nature whatsoever, except those that are specifically excluded herein from any or part of these regulations. 
Sec. 27-4. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  As used in this ordinance, words denoting the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter. 
(b)  Words used in the singular in this ordinance include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. 
Sec. 27-5. - Remedies. 
    Any person found to have violated any provision of this Code may: 
(a)  Be punished as provided in Section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances (original volume). 
(b)  Be prosecuted before the Code Enforcement Board (see Chapter 31, Article 5 of these regulations). 
(c)  Be enjoined by the City from violating these regulations. 
(d)  Be denied future permits until Code compliance is achieved by the violator. 
(e)  Be denied a certificate of occupancy or permit reasonably related to the violation. 
(f)  Be issued a citation by the Code Enforcement Officer (see Chapter 34, Article VI). 
    The above remedies are in the alternative and the City Manager through his Code Enforcement Officer shall have the authority to determine which remedy or remedies shall be pursued by the City. In the event litigation is filed by the City against said violator, the City shall be entitled to assess its reasonable attorney's fees and costs against said violator. 
Secs. 27-6-27-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INTENT 

Sec. 27-11. - Intent. 
    The general intent of this ordinance is to establish procedures and standards for the development of land within the corporate limits and planning jurisdiction of Titusville in an effort to: 
(a)  Ensure proper legal description, identification, monumentation, and recordation of real estate properties. 
(b)  Provide for the harmonious development of the City. 
(c)  Realize a coordinated design pattern of streets, sidewalks and other transportation facilities. 
(d)  Encourage sufficient recreational facilities. 
(e)  Preserve water resources. 
(f)  Provide for flood prevention, proper storm drainage, and appropriate utility systems. 
(g)  Conserve valuable and scenic natural features, with provision for adequate open space. 
(h)  Promote the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(i)  Encourage a high degree of quality and aesthetics in developments. 
Sec. 27-12. - Relationship to the Comprehensive Plan. 
    It is the intention of the City Council and Local Planning Agency that this ordinance serve to implement the requirements of the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, Chapter 163 of the Florida Statutes, that requires the adoption of Land Development Regulations. These Land Development Regulations specifically address the following provisions: 
(a)  The subdivision of land, including provisions that meet the statutory requirements of Chapter 177, Part I, Florida Statutes, including review procedures, design and development standards, provisions for adequate public facilities, mitigation of development impacts, land dedications, fees and administrative provisions; 
(b)  The regulation of the use of land and water for the use categories included in the Titusville Comprehensive Plan as implemented by a set of zoning districts and a zoning map; 
(c)  The protection of potable water supply sources through the control of land uses and activities within the identified cones of influence and general areas of influence for the City of Titusville's wells and wellfields; 
(d)  The regulation of the areas subject to seasonal and periodic flooding and the provision of drainage and storm water management through the control of the type, location, density and intensity of land uses located within these areas; 
(e)  The protection of environmentally sensitive lands designated in the Comprehensive Plan, particularly the wetlands areas identified in the conservation land use category; 
(f)  The regulation of signage; 
(g)  The provision of public facilities and service concurrent with the impacts of development based upon adopted levels of service (LOS); 
(h)  The provision of safe and convenient on site traffic flow, considering the need for vehicle parking and pedestrian movement; and 
(i)  The implementation of the regulations specifically stated in the adopted policies of the Titusville Comprehensive Plan. 
(j)  In the event of a conflict between these regulations and the Comprehensive Plan, the Comprehensive Plan shall prevail. It is the intent of the City to have the more stringent regulations prevail in the event of any conflict. 
Sec. 27-13. - Severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the City Council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of this Ordinance are severable, and if such section, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction in a valid judgment or decree, such unconstitutionally or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases of this Ordinance since the same would have been enacted without the incorporation into this Ordinance of such unconstitutional or invalid section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase. 
(Ord. No. 31-2017, § 4, 10-24-17) 
Sec. 27-14. - Computation of time. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, the time within which an act is required to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day. If the last day is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, that day shall be excluded, making the next regular working day the last day. 
(b)  Saturday, Sunday and City legal holidays shall be excluded from time computation (working day basis). 
(c)  Unless otherwise provided, whenever a person has the right or is required to perform an act within a prescribed period of time after the service of a notice or other paper upon him and the notice of paper is served by mail, five (5) days shall be added to the prescribed period. 
(Ord. No. 31-2017, § 5, 10-24-17) 
Sec. 27-15. - No use or sale of land or building except in conformity with the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(a)  No person may use, occupy or sell any land or building, or authorize, or permit the use, occupancy or sale of land or buildings under this control except in accordance with all applicable provisions of this Ordinance. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the "use" or "occupancy" of a building or land relates to anything and everything that is done to, on or in that building or land. 
(Ord. No. 31-2017, § 6, 10-24-17) 
Sec. 27-16. - Relationship to existing zoning, subdivision and environmental regulations, including flood control ordinances. 
    To the extent that the provisions of this Ordinance are the same in substance as the previously adopted provisions that were contained in the City of Titusville Code, 1963, Chapters 1 through 29, these provisions shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments unless otherwise specified. In particular, if a situation did not constitute a lawful nonconforming situation under the previously adopted ordinances, it does not achieve lawful nonconforming status under this Ordinance merely by the repeal of the prior ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 31-2017, § 7, 10-24-17) 
Secs. 27-17-27-20. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - FUTURE LAND USE/ZONING MATRIX STANDARDS 

Sec. 27-26. - Commercial zoning districts located in the Low Intensity Commercial land use category. 
    In addition to the restrictions and requirements of each zoning district established in the Chapter 28, "Zoning", commercially zoned property identified on the adopted Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map as Low Intensity Commercial shall be developed according to the criteria set forth in Chapter 29, Special Districts and Overlays, Article VIII, Special Land Use Standards, Division 1, "Commercial Zoning Districts in the Commercial Low Intensity Future Land Use." 
Sec. 27-27. - Community Commercial (CC) zoning district. 
    Sites zoned Community Commercial (CC) must either be located at the intersection of two (2) collector roadways or have frontage on an arterial or higher classification roadway. Community Commercial (CC) districts may only be located in a Commercial Low Intensity or Commercial High Intensity land use designation on the Future Land Use Map. 
Sec. 27-28. - Light Industrial Services and Warehousing (M-1) zoning. 
    In addition to the restrictions and requirements of the Light Industrial Services and Warehousing (M-1) zoning district established in Chapter 28, Zoning, properties zoned M-1 but identified on the adopted Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map not designated with the Industrial land use shall be developed according to the criteria set forth in Chapter 29, Special Districts and Overlays, Article VIII, Special Land Use Standards, Division 2, "Light Industrial Services and Warehousing (M-1) Zoning District." 
Sec. 27-29. - Wetland and Conservation Overlay (WCA) and the Conservation future land use category. 
(a)  The Conservation Area Overlay District shall conform to the Conservation Land Use designation noted on the City of Titusville Future Land Use Map. 
(b)  An illustration of the areas affected by the Conservation Area Overlay District is to be found in Chapter 29 - Special Districts and Overlays. 
Sec. 27-30. - Additional requirements for zoning districts consistent with Downtown Mixed-Use land use. 
    In addition to the applicable requirements contained elsewhere in these regulations, all property developed after the date of adoption of this section [October 26, 2010] and zoned R-1C, R-3, T, NC, CC, OP, CM, M-1 and P, that is located in a Downtown Mixed-Use Land Use as shown on the adopted Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map shall comply with the additional requirements set forth per Chapter 28, Zoning, Article I, General Provisions, Section 28-7, "Additional requirements for zoning districts consistent with Downtown Mixed-Use Land Use", and Chapter 29, Special Districts and Overlays, Article VIII, Special Land Use Standards, Division 3, Downtown Mixed-Use Future Land Use. 
Sec. 27-31. - Neighborhood Commercial (NC) zoning district. 
    The Neighborhood Commercial (NC) district is designed as a Commercial Low Intensity land use category on the Future Land Use Map. 
Secs. 27-32-27-40. - Reserved. 
Chapter 28 - ZONING 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 28-1. - Designation of district boundaries. 
    The maps delineating the boundaries of the various zoning districts, together with all items shown on such maps, are adopted and approved by the City Council. These documents collectively constitute the "official zoning map." The official zoning map is incorporated by reference and made a part of the Land Development Regulations.
