a.  A greenbelt of thirty-five (35) feet along the front setback or abutting the highway and fifteen (15) feet along the remaining perimeter of the site. Larger greenbelts are encouraged. 
(e)  Planned Industrial Development (PID). 
(1)  Common open space: A minimum of twenty (20) percent of the total site area, exclusive of rights-of-way, shall be set aside as common open space and dedicated for public use or held in common by the owners of the industrial park, subject to maintenance provisions in deed restrictions approved by the City Council. Said common open space area may include required greenbelts and areas designated for stormwater retention or detention requirements Provided that they are utilized for passive recreation, nature observation or other accessible recreational activity. Regulatory wetlands may be credited for up to a fifty (50) percent credit to the required common open space at a 2:1 ratio. 
(2)  Greenbelt: Within a Planned Industrial Development, a greenbelt shall be required as follows: 
a.  Where the project abuts a major collector or higher classification roadway or nonindustrial/planned industrial land uses - fifty (50) feet. 
b.  Remaining perimeter - twenty-five (25) feet. Improvements within the required greenbelt shall be limited to underground utilities and irrigation systems, required rights-of-way perpendicular to the greenbelt, pedestrian and bicycle paths, stormwater management systems, and passive recreation areas. The required greenbelt, excepting identified wetlands, may be included in calculating the open space required by Section 30-164(f)(1). 
(f)  Planned Development (PD). 
(1)  A five (5) percent credit will be given towards the minimum required common open space requirement if public art or a community feature is provided in a publicly accessible outdoor park or urban plaza. 
(2)  Urban plazas are an improved, landscaped, or paved type of open space which are usually surrounded by streets and buildings, having amenities such as seating, drinking and ornamental fountains, art, trees, and landscaping for use by the public. 
(3)  Common open space includes both passive recreation (e.g. picnic areas or walking trails) and active recreation (e.g. playgrounds or basketball courts) areas. Private waterbodies and stormwater retention or detention areas that are designed to be used for passive recreation (i.e. improved with fountains, benches, and walkways) may be counted towards the common open space minimum requirement. 
(4)  All common open space shall be preserved for its intended purpose as expressed in the master development plan. The developer shall choose one (1) or a combination of the methods of administering common open space set forth per Article I, General provisions, Division 3, Operation and maintenance. 
(5)  All common open space as well as public and recreational facilities, shall be specifically included in the development schedule and be constructed and fully improved by the developer at an equivalent or greater rate than the construction of residential structures, or the development order will be in default. 
(g)  Regional Mixed-Use (RMU). 
Table 30-3 Regional Mixed-Use Park and Recreation Minimum Required Park and Recreation Use Overall Regional Mixed-Use (RMU) Development Fifteen (15) percent RMU-200 (Residential Tract) Ten (10) percent RMU-300 (Residential Tract) RMU-400 (Residential Tract)  
(1)  Public use and park and recreation uses. 
a.  Public uses. Examples of public uses are public recreation facilities, public schools, public parks, public emergency services, public libraries, and public government offices. 
b.  Park and recreation use. 
1.  Open space. Any unencumbered space, park, or public or private spaces otherwise committed to preservation or recreation (active or passive) but not including areas required for stormwater management (retention or detention) unless expressly permitted herein (Chapter 37, Definitions). The minimum open space for the overall RMU development shall be twenty (20) percent. 
2.  Park and recreation. A space focusing on passive or active outdoor recreation areas and having few structures. The minimum park and recreation for residential in any individual tract within RMU-200, RMU-300 or RMU-400 sub-districts shall be ten (10) percent. The minimum park and recreation for the overall RMU development shall be fifteen (15) percent. 
3.  Examples of active-park and recreation areas include: playgrounds, basketball courts, tennis courts, baseball fields, soccer fields and other similar participatory sports uses. 
4.  Examples of passive-park and recreation areas include: preserved environmentally sensitive areas with walking trails, general walking trails woven through the RMU development, amphitheaters or picnic areas. Walking trail area dedicated to park and recreation use shall be calculated as the actual trail width plus five (5) feet from both trail edges, times the total trail length (see Chapter 33, Development options, Article IV, Regional Mixed-Use, Section 33-45(d), Graphic illustration, for additional information). 
5.  If RMU development is phased, then open space and park and recreation area development shall be phased to meet the requirements of 1. and 2. above in each phase. 
6.  Commercial recreation activities and/or for fee commercial activities shall not be used to meet the required park and recreation uses. 
c.  Public uses shall not be counted toward park and recreation uses. 
(2)  Open space, park and recreation. The minimum open space for the overall RMU development shall be twenty (20) percent. The minimum park and recreation for residential in any individual tract within RMU-200, RMU-300 or RMU-400 sub-districts shall be ten (10) percent. The minimum park and recreation for the overall RMU development shall be fifteen (15) percent. 
(h)  Urban Village. 
(1)  Common open space includes both passive recreation (e.g. picnic area or walking trail) and active recreation (e.g. playground or basketball court) areas, which provide quality recreational amenities such as fountains, benches, and lighting. Stormwater retention areas that are designed to be used for passive recreation, by including three (3) or more park amenities (e.g. benches, gazebos, and fountains), may be counted towards the common open space minimum requirement. 
(2)  Urban plazas are an improved, landscaped, or paved type of open space, which are usually surrounded by streets and buildings, having three (3) or more amenities such as seating, drinking and ornamental fountains, art, trees, and landscaping for use by the public. 
(3)  All common open space shall be preserved for its intended purpose as expressed in the master development plan. The developer shall choose one (1) or a combination of the following methods of administering common open space set forth per Article I, General provisions, Division 3, Operation and maintenance: 
a.  All common open space as well as public and recreational facilities, shall be specifically included in the development schedule and be constructed and fully improved by the developer at an equivalent or greater rate than the construction of residential structures, or the development order will be in default. 
(i)  Cluster Development and Conservation Subdivision. 
(1)  Open space may consist of wetlands and uplands with not less than twenty-five (25) percent of the set aside total lands, consisting of upland vegetation. 
(2)  As a part of the open space requirement, a thirty-foot buffer of preserved native upland or wetland vegetation along adjacent public roadways and twenty-foot buffer between adjacent parcels shall be required to qualify for the cluster development. The buffer open space area may count towards the fifty (50) percent open space for conservation areas. 
(3)  To the extent possible, the open space area shall be a contiguous parcel in order to preserve the nature habitat for wildlife. 
(4)  The stormwater management: 
a.  Stormwater management system shall be designed to preserve, to the extent practical and possible, the native vegetation and may be located within the fifty (50) percent open space and conservation area in a Cluster Development provided compliance is achieved in accordance with other applicable land development regulations. 
b.  Stormwater management (retention or detention) may not be counted towards the minimum open space requirements in a Conservation Subdivision. 
(5)  The open space area shall be set aside in a conservation easement dedicated for the benefit of the residents of the subdivision or to the public. 
Sec. 30-164. - Dedication procedures. 
    Provisions for the dedication of open space are found in the operation and maintenance standards of this Chapter (Article I, General provisions, Division 3, Operation and maintenance). 
Secs. 30-165-30-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FENCES/WALLS 

Sec. 30-181. - General provisions. 
(a)  Intent. This division is intended to provide minimum standards for fences/walls. The intent is to allow fences/walls where appropriate for security or screening purposes. These regulations will increase public safety and security of personal property. 
(b)  Within the Downtown Mixed-Use Land Use District, fences, walls, and/or screens exceeding thirty (30) inches in height shall be prohibited forward of the front or street side facade of the principal structure. (See Chapter 29, Special Districts and Overlays.) 
(c)  Fences shall be measured on the exterior surface and include any berm, retaining wall, or other manmade improvement which would artificially circumvent the intent of this section. 
(d)  All walls and fences shall be constructed so that all support posts/poles/members are facing the interior of the yard on which the wall/fence is placed. The good side (i.e. side with no bracing or support members) shall be required to face the neighboring property and/or rights-of-way abutting the property where a fence is being erected, except as follows: 
(1)  Abutting conservation or open recreation lands. 
(2)  Abutting bodies of water, including retention ponds. 
(3)  Abutting commercial uses. 
(4)  Abutting public lands. 
(e)  Fences and walls shall be fabricated from wood, aluminum, wrought iron, vinyl, brick or other approved materials manufactured specifically for fences and walls. Non-traditional fence materials such as tires, muffler, hubcaps, galvanized roofing, and corrugated metal, are prohibited. 
(f)  Except as specifically noted in this article, no wall or fence shall be constructed either wholly or in part, of barbed wire, razor wire, electrified wire, glass shards, or other similarly dangerous material. 
(g)  Barbed wire may be used in conjunction with, or accessory to, a permitted agricultural use. 
(h)  No fence shall encroach into a visibility triangle at an intersection or a driveway, as determined by the City. 
(Ord. No. 33-2018, § 2, 7-24-18) 
Sec. 30-182. - Height and location requirements. 
(a)  Single-family residential uses. 
(1)  Front yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required front yard setback shall be four (4) feet. 
(2)  Side or rear yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side or rear yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(3)  Side corner yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side corner yard setback shall be six (6) feet. Within the side corner yard of a corner lot, a fence in excess of four (4) feet in height shall be set back a minimum of thirty-five (35) feet from the property line to ensure adequate visibility for pedestrian and vehicle traffic. The graphic below illustrates this regulation. Any side corner yard setback abutting a collector or arterial roadway shall be limited to a maximum of four (4) feet within the minimum side corner yard setback established by the zoning district. 

(4)  No high security fence or wall may be permitted with a single-family residential use. 
(b)  Multifamily residential uses. 
(1)  Front yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required front yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(2)  Side or rear yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side or rear yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(3)  Side corner yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side corner yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(4)  No high security fence or wall may be permitted with a multi-family residential use. 
(c)  Commercial uses. 
(1)  Front yard: No fence or wall shall be permitted in any required front yard setback, except as noted in this section. 
(2)  Side or rear yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side or rear yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(3)  Side corner yard: No fence or wall shall be permitted in any required side corner yard setback, except as noted in this section. 
(4)  Where security requirements of a commercial development are determined to exceed the aforementioned provisions of this section, a high security fence or wall may be permitted by the Administrator pursuant to the requirements of Section 30-183 of this article. 
(5)  The following type of fence or wall shall be exempt from the placement requirements: 
a.  Fences that are placed a distance greater than ten (10) feet from a property line. 
b.  Fences that are replacing an existing or part of an existing fence. 
c.  Fences that are installed interior to an existing fence. 
d.  Fences installed to meet screening requirements, when abutting the property line of residential zoning would be installed "good side facing the residential zoning." When a screening fence would be highly visible to a major roadway or street, the Building Official may waive the "good side out" requirement, when there would not be any adverse effect to the residential area. 
e.  Fences facing the Indian River, a lake or pond, or enclosing a retention pond may be installed with the structural supports towards the water. 
(d)  Industrial uses (applicable to the M-1, M-2, and M-3 zoning districts). In the Highway Industrial Infill (M-3) zoning district, the site should be planned to accomplish a smooth transition from adjacent properties that differ in land use and/or design philosophy by the use of site breaks such as screens, berms, fences and walls for aesthetic appearance. 
(1)  Front yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required front yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(2)  Side or rear yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side or rear yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(3)  Side corner yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side corner yard setback shall be six (6) feet. 
(4)  Where security requirements of industrial development are determined to exceed the provisions of this section, a high security fence may be permitted by the Administrator pursuant to the requirements of Section 30-183 of this article. 
(5)  The following type of fence or wall shall be exempt from these placement requirements: 
a.  Fences that are placed a distance greater than ten (10) feet from a property line. 
b.  Fences that are replacing an existing or part of an existing fence. 
c.  Fences that are installed interior to an existing fence. 
d.  Fences installed to meet screening requirements, when abutting the property line of residential zoning would be installed "good side facing the residential zoning." When a screening fence would be highly visible to a major roadway or street, the Building Official may waive the "good side out" requirement, when there would not be any adverse effect to the residential area. 
e.  Fences facing the Indian River, a lake or pond, or enclosing a retention pond may be installed with the structural supports towards the water. 
(e)  Planned Industrial Development (applicable to the PID zoning district). 
(1)  Front yard: No fence or wall shall be permitted in any required front yard setback. 
(2)  Side or rear yard: The maximum height of a fence or wall in any required side or rear yard setback shall be eight (8) feet. 
(3)  Side corner yard: No fence or wall shall be permitted in any required side corner setback. 
(4)  Where security requirements of planned industrial developments are determined to exceed the provisions of this section, an interior high security fence may be permitted by the Administrator pursuant to the requirements of Section 30-183 of this article. There shall be a minimum clear zone of fifteen (15) feet between an exterior fence and any interior high security fence. The use of barbed wire, razor wire, or electric wire is permitted on any interior high security fence; however, if electric wire [is] used, an "electrified fence" sign of at least two (2) square feet shall be posted at least every fifty (50) feet within the clear zone. The interior high security fence shall be illuminated during darkness and over low light hours. The interior high security fence shall not exceed twelve (12) feet in height, including any barbed wire, razor wire, or other fencing material. 
(5)  The following type of fence or wall shall be exempt from these placement requirements: 
a.  Fences that are placed a distance greater than ten (10) feet from a property line. 
b.  Fences that a replacing an existing or part of an existing fence. 
c.  Fences that are installed interior to an existing fence. 
d.  Fences installed to meet screening requirements, when abutting the property line of residential zoning would be installed "good side facing the residential zoning." When a screening fence would be highly visible to a major roadway or street, the Building Official may waive the "good side out" requirement, when there would be any adverse effect to the residential area. 
e.  Fences facing the Indian River, a lake or pond, or enclosing a retention pond may be installed with the structural supports towards the water. 
(Ord. No. 38-2017, § 2, 11-14-17; Ord. No. 33-2018, § 3, 7-24-18) 
Sec. 30-183. - High security fences. 
(a)  Where security requirements are determined to exceed the provisions of other sections of this article, a high security fence may be permitted by the Administrator. Allowance of these types of fences/walls shall be on a case-by-case basis and allowance of a high security fence/wall at one (1) location shall not be considered as precedence for the allowance of such a fence/wall at any other location. 
(1)  All high security fences/walls shall be subject to review by the City's Site Plan Review Committee and the Community Redevelopment Agency within the Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning district to ensure compatibility with the surrounding buildings and/or walls. 
(2)  Use of high security fences/walls shall only be considered at locations where the City's Land Development Regulations permit the outdoor storage and display of goods and materials, or as required by a Federal or State regulation or program. Where high security fences/walls are used around outdoor display areas, said fence/wall does not have to be one hundred (100) percent opaque. High security fences/walls used around outdoor storage areas must be one hundred (100) percent opaque. 
(3)  High security fences/walls shall be defined as follows: 
a.  High security fences: A substantially built fence (including any gates in said fence) not less than six (6) feet nor more than eight (8) feet in height above grade. Such fence may be chain-link or woven wire fencing materials, with or without slats. There may be three (3) strands of barbed wire on barbed wire arms on top of these fences as long as the barbed wire arms are angled forty-five (45) degrees of the fence, and do not extend beyond the property line. 
b.  High security walls: A constructed barrier of concrete, stone, brick, tile, wood, or similar type of material, not less than six (6) nor more than eight (8) feet in height above grade. Barbed wire may be used in conjunction with a high security wall as long as the barbed wire meets the requirements detailed in Section 30-183(a)(3)a., above. The barbed wire arms must be installed on the property side of the wall. Said walls do not have to be one hundred (100) percent opaque as long as physical access to the attendant property is prevented. 
(4)  Wherever a high security fence/wall is used, the following landscape elements are required. Exceptions to this section may be granted, on a case-by-case basis, by the Administrator, for those properties that do not front on roadways classified by Article III, Improvements, Division 7, Streets, of this article as either a principal or minor arterial roadway. 
a.  All high security fences shall be located in a landscape strip that is ten (10) feet in width. A continuous hedge shall run along the entire length of the fence. Said hedge shall be maintained at a height of at least thirty-six (36) inches. One (1) tree shall be planted every forty (40) feet along the entire length of the fence. Said hedge and trees shall meet the requirements of Division 10, Landscaping, Subdivision 3, Landscape yard of this article of these [Land Development] Regulations. These landscape requirements should be placed along the exterior of the fence but can be located along the interior of fences that are not required to be one hundred (100) percent opaque pursuant to Section 30-183(a)(2) above. 
b.  All high security walls shall be located in a landscape strip that is ten (10) feet in width. A continuous hedge shall run along the entire length of the wall. One (1) tree shall be planted every forty (40) feet along the entire length of the wall. Said hedge and trees shall meet the requirements of Division 10, Landscaping, Subdivision 3, Landscape yard of this article of these regulations. These landscape requirements must be placed along the exterior of the wall. 
(Ord. No. 38-2017, § 3, 11-14-17) 
Secs. 30-184-30-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LIGHTING 

Sec. 30-191. - Intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards for site lighting improvements. The intent is to allow lighting within parking lots, secured areas, walkways, and site features while protecting neighboring properties from intrusive lighting projections. These regulations will increase public safety and security for personal property. 
Sec. 30-192. - Site lighting standards. 
(a)  Lighting shall not be directed onto another lot or obscure driver's vision on public streets. All freestanding and building mounted light fixtures shall be down-lit. 
(b)  No lighting fixture shall create more than two (2) footcandles of light density at the property line. 
(c)  No freestanding light fixture shall be higher than forty (40) feet. 
(d)  Off-street parking areas shall be illuminated to a minimum of one (1) footcandle at eye level over the entire surface of the parking area during operating hours. 
Sec. 30-193. - Other site lighting standards. 
(a)  Light timers/cutoff switches are required for all outdoor non-security lighting fixtures. 
(b)  Low voltage, low intensity walkway light (i.e. bollard lighting) are permissible and are not required to be down-lit. 
(c)  The City encourages all developments to utilize low power consumptions fixtures (i.e. LED), in the site's lighting design. All site lighting permit fees will be waived as an incentive for developments to utilize low power consumption fixture lighting designs. Other site fees and all buildings fees applicable to the projects are still enforced. 
(d)  Lighting directed upward may be permitted when directed toward flag poles, fountains, building facades, landscaping or like items and directed away from adjacent properties and/or rights-of-way as approved by the Administrator. 
Sec. 30-194. - Planned Industrial Development (PID) lighting standards. 
(a)  Artificial lighting utilized to illuminate the premises shall be directed away from adjacent properties and streets, shining only on the subject site. 
(b)  No free-standing light fixtures shall extend higher than twenty-five (25) feet. Such fixtures shall be approved by the administrator to assure design compatibility with principal buildings and the planned industrial business park. 
(c)  Although parking lot lighting is encouraged for the protection of employees that work after-hours, parking lot lighting is only required if multiple shifts are proposed between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. If multiple shifts are not proposed then an after-hours lit parking area may be designated to address employee security. Required lighting should be brought up to code standards if necessitated by a change of use. 
Secs. 30-195-30-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND AQUIFER PROTECTION 
Subdivision 1. - Stormwater Management and Erosion Control 

Sec. 30-201. - Intent. 
(a)  It is the intent of this section to protect and enhance surface and groundwater resources by ensuring that stormwater runoff peak rates and volumes after development are no more than predevelopment conditions; that groundwater tables are not artificially lowered; and that precautions are taken to prevent erosion, sedimentation, flooding and water pollution. It is the further intent of this section to: 
(1)  Provide additional protection for the freshwater resources within, and in the proximity of, the existing and proposed well fields in the City of Titusville. 
(2)  Protect and/or enhance the quality of ground and surface waters including the Indian River Lagoon, St. Johns River, Fox and South Lakes. 
(3)  Ensure that there is no erosion after development. 
(4)  Maintain and enhance groundwater levels and groundwater recharge. 
(5)  Protect the beneficial functioning of wetlands, such as swamps, bogs, marshes, estuaries, sloughs and floodplains, for the natural storage of surface waters and the biological reduction and assimilation of pollutants. 
(6)  Minimize saltwater intrusion by adhering to applicable best management practices. 
(7)  Minimize injury to vegetation, fish and wildlife habitat and otherwise help to attain the objectives of this section. 
Sec. 30-202. - Stormwater management permit. 
(a)  The following activities alter or disrupt existing stormwater runoff patterns or affect aquifer recharge areas and will require a permit prior to the initiation of any project except as exempted in Section 30-203. 
(1)  Filling, clearing and/or drainage of land as an adjunct to construction. 
(2)  Clearing, filling and/or draining of nonagricultural land for agricultural purposes. 
(3)  Converting agricultural lands to nonagricultural uses. 
(4)  Subdividing land. 
(5)  Replatting recorded subdivisions and the development of recorded and unrecorded subdivisions. 
(6)  Changing the use of land and/or the construction of a structure including the construction of parking areas or impervious surfaces or a change in the size of one (1) or more structures. 
(7)  Altering the shoreline or bank of any surface water body. 
(8)  Altering of any ditches, dikes, terraces, berms, swales, or other water management facility. 
(9)  Removal of earth or moving of earth on a parcel. For all activities that require a permit. 
(10)  Construction or size modification of a structure including parking areas or impervious surfaces. 
(11)  Site and subdivision development requiring City approval of all new construction including buildings, parking, new impervious area accessory structures. 
(b)  Site and subdivision development requiring city approval all new construction including buildings, parking, new impervious area accessory structures, etc. 
Sec. 30-203. - Stormwater management permit-Exemptions. 
(a)  The following activities shall be exempt from formal stormwater permitting procedures: 
(1)  Single-family residences, additions and accessory structures, upon determination by the Administrator that such construction will not adversely impact the aquifer or the stormwater management system. 
(2)  Bona fide agricultural pursuits except where an artificial drainage system will be used to increase the flow of surface water from the applicant's land or the land is in the area of critical concern. 
(3)  Maintenance work performed by a public or established private utility on drainage canals for the purpose of public health and welfare. 
(4)  Any construction or improvement to an existing parcel not exceeding one thousand (1,000) cumulative square feet of new impervious area and not changing or affecting the quality, rate, volume or location of stormwater discharge as determined by the Administrator. 
(5)  Repaving or resurfacing of existing impervious surfaces. 
(6)  Any development within a subdivision if each of the following conditions has been met: 
a.  Stormwater management provisions for the subdivision were previously approved and remain valid as part of a final plat. 
b.  The development is conducted in accordance with the stormwater management provisions submitted with the final plat. 
c.  The impervious coverage per lot does not exceed the maximum impervious area as defined in the final plat. If the final plat does not specify the maximum impervious area, these regulations will apply. 
Sec. 30-204. - Stormwater management plan process. 
(a)  The owner/applicant of any project as defined in Section 30-202 shall submit a Stormwater Management Plan as part of the development approval process as set forth in Chapter 34, Procedures, Article IV, Subdivision and Article V, Site plan of the Land Development Regulations. 
(b)  Upon receipt, the Administrator shall review said Stormwater Management Plan based upon the criteria and performance standards identified in this article and in accordance with the time provisions for review of projects in accordance with other appropriate sections of the Land Development Regulations. 
Sec. 30-205. - Stormwater management plan, required information and exhibits. 
    A stormwater management plan shall be submitted per the requirement set forth in the Stormwater Management Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-206. - Stormwater management criteria. 
    Stormwater management systems and erosion control measures shall adhere to the criteria set forth in the Stormwater Management Technical Manual. 
Subdivision 2. - Area of Critical Concern 

Sec. 30-207. - Area of critical concern performance. 
(a)  For properties, any portion of which is located within the Area of Critical Concern (See Chapter 29, Special districts and Overlay), no certificate of occupancy, building permit, development permit, clearing permit, site plan approval, or any other permit or development approval shall be issued by the City unless the land use or permit shall comply with the following performance standards in addition to the other requirements of this section. 
(1)  Primary stormwater management facilities are to be designed as dry bottom facilities. 
(2)  Retention and discharge requirements: 
a.  For a development site located above twenty-five (25) feet mean sea level (msl), the post-development runoff volume resulting from the ten-year/twenty-four-hour storm event shall be retained on site. The retention area required for the ten-year/twenty-four-hour storm shall be based on the percentage of impervious surface on the site. The rate of discharge over the retained ten-year/twenty-four-hour storm volume shall be restricted to the predevelopment rate of discharge for a twenty-five-year/twenty-four-hour storm event. One-half (1/2) foot of freeboard shall be required above the overflow elevation. The area needed for the freeboard is extra, above the area calculated above. Engineering calculations, using approved methods, showing that the ten-year, twenty-four-hour storm retention requirements have been met shall be required. 
b.  For development sites below twenty-five (25) feet msl, retention and discharge requirements shall be as provided in Sections 30-206 and 30-210 for developments located outside the area of critical concern. This includes the use of wet detention. 
c.  For development sites having elevations both above and below twenty-five (25) feet msl, those portions of the site which are above twenty-five (25) msl shall conform to the performance in paragraph (a)(1) of this section, and all required retention ponds and improvements shall be located in the areas above twenty-five (25) feet msl. 
(3)  Removal of soil from a development site within the area of critical concern shall be prohibited unless otherwise approved by the Administrator. Importing clean fill on a site for the purpose of creating additional recharge shall be encouraged. 
(4)  Reduction of natural topography shall be minimized. The reduction of natural topography shall be limited eight (8) feet above the seasonal high water table (with the exception of drainage conveyances or retention ponds) or eight (8) feet below existing land surface, whichever is more restrictive. This section shall not apply to excavation beneath a structure for the purpose of providing a basement except that in no case shall such excavation be within eighteen (18) inches of the seasonal high water table. The limitations on the extent of the above cut of the natural topography shall not be construed as an automatic authorization to alter the natural topography. The project shall be designed to minimize the change in natural topography. 
(5)  Within the area of critical concern the total of all impervious surfaces shall not exceed forty (40) percent of the total area of a development excluding publicly dedicated right-of-way and jurisdictional wetlands. If pervious concrete pavement is used in the development of the site, a credit for the use of pervious concrete pavement will be as stated in Section 30-208. (See Section 7.6.1.1 of the Stormwater Technical Manual for performance calculations.) 
(6)  For sites adjacent to existing municipal potable water wells total impervious surfaces shall not exceed the following (see Stormwater Technical Manual for performance calculations): 
a.  Twenty (20) percent if the site is within three hundred (300) feet of an active municipal production well site. 
b.  Twenty-five (25) percent if the site is between three hundred (300) feet and seven hundred fifty (750) feet of an active municipal production well site. 
c.  Thirty (30) percent if the site is between seven hundred fifty (750) feet and fifteen hundred (1500) feet of an active municipal production well site. 
(7)  Impervious parking lot requirements may be waived for uses located within the area of critical concern provided that erosion control measures are approved by the Administrator. However, any accessway onto a public right-of-way shall be paved a minimum distance of twenty (20) feet into the property in order to provide for public safety and drainage. 
(8)  Development shall be designed to minimize the reduction of recharge to the surficial aquifer. The groundwater level and fluctuations shall be no worse than under predevelopment conditions. 
(9)  For private wells in excess of two (2) inches in diameter, licensed well drillers installing private wells in the area of critical concern, shall first notify the Administrator and supply information concerning owners name, address, property locations, depth and diameter of well and pumping capacity. 
(10)  Only one (1) black water septic tank permitted per acre, not to exceed one thousand two hundred (1,200) gallon capacity, shall be allowed. 
(11)  Home fuel oil storage tanks are prohibited within the area of critical concern. 
(12)  The minimum lot size for all future single-family developments shall be ten thousand (10,000) square feet, excluding retention ponds. A conservation subdivision as specified in Chapter 33, Development options, Article VIII, Conservation subdivision design may be utilized to allow lots less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet in area provided all conditions of the conservation subdivision design are met. 
(13)  Preservation of predevelopment topography, grades, soils and vegetation shall be encouraged. 
(14)  That each site/subdivision must calculate the maximum impervious area for each lot(s). This information must be included on site plan and/or plat. 
(Ord. No. 49-2017, § 1, 12-12-17) 
Sec. 30-208. - Pervious pavement standards in the area of critical concern. 
    Pervious pavement standards in the area of critical concern are set forth in Section 7.7 of the Stormwater Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-209. - Exemptions in the area of critical concern. 
(a)  The following properties located within the area of critical concern shall be exempt from the provisions of this section except for Sections 30-207(a)(9) and (10) to the extent provided herein: 
(1)  All single-family lots in existing platted single-family subdivisions and those for which preliminary plat approval was obtained prior to July 15, 1986 (effective date). 
(2)  Any existing parcel or lot which is one-half (1/2) acre in size or less, regardless of the zoning classification, shall be exempt from the impervious surface limitations prescribed in Section 30-207(a)(5). To be entitled to this exemption, the property in question must have been deeded, subdivided or otherwise created prior to July 15, 1986 (effective date). 
Subdivision 3. - Hydraulic, Maintenance and Enforcement 

Sec. 30-210. - Hydraulic design criteria stormwater conveyance system. 
    This section of the City of Titusville's Stormwater Design Criteria Manual shall be utilized in the design of the collection and conveyance portion of any stormwater management facility to be constructed and to be maintained by the City and shall be designed per City of Titusville Specifications. 
Sec. 30-211. - Conflicts with other ordinances and codes. 
    In case of conflict between this article or any part thereof, and the whole part of any other existing or future ordinance or code, the most restricted in each case shall apply. 
Sec. 30-212. - Review fees. 
    Review fees shall be in accordance with Chapter 34, Procedures, Article IX, Fees of the Code. 
Sec. 30-213. - Maintenance and inspections. 
(a)  The installed system(s) required by this article shall be maintained by the owner. 
(b)  The owner shall maintain the installed system(s) required by this article. 
(c)  At the time of issuance of a development order the city can inspect all erosion control measures to ensure effective control. 
(d)  Inspection fee(s) shall be paid at the time of issuance of a stormwater construction permit. The applicant shall schedule with the Administrator the following inspections: 
(1)  Erosion and sediment control inspections: As necessary to ensure effective control of erosion and sedimentation. 
(2)  Burial inspections: Prior to the burial of any underground drainage structure. 
(3)  Final inspection: Upon completion of work, the Enforcement Officer shall either approve the completed work or notify the applicant in writing in that there has been a failure to comply with the requirements of the approved permit. 
Sec. 30-214. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  When work for which a permit is required by this article is commenced prior to obtaining said permit, the fees herein specified shall be double but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this article in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed in the Land Development Regulations. 
(b)  The applicant shall be required to adhere strictly to the plan as permitted. Any changes or amendments to the plan must be approved by the Administrator. Enforcement officials shall be granted inspection rights and right-of-way privileges in order to ensure compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(c)  If the Enforcement Official determines that the project is not being carried out in accordance with the approved plan or if any project is being carried out without a permit, he is authorized to: 
(1)  Issue written notice to the applicant specifying the nature and location of the alleged noncompliance; with a description of the remedial actions necessary to bring the project into compliance within three (3) working days. 
(2)  Issue a stop-work order directing the applicant or persons in possession to cease and desist all or any portion of the work which violates the provisions of this article, if the remedial work is not completed within the specified time. The applicant shall then bring the project into compliance or be subject to immediate revocation of their permit and penalties. 
(3)  The person(s) named in (1) or (2) above may request, in writing, a hearing before the Code Enforcement Board no later than fourteen (14) days after the date of such action. Any order issued in (1) or (2) above shall, remain in effect until a final decision of the Board. 
(d)  Any person who violates or causes to be violated any provision of this article or permits any such violation or fails to comply with any of the requirements hereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the County Jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day upon which such violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to any other remedies, whether civil or criminal, the violation of this article may be restrained by injunction, including a mandatory injunction, and otherwise abated in any manner provided by law. 
(e)  All persons and entities shall maintain private stormwater management systems in full compliance with applicable codes and ordinances. Any person or entity that fails to maintain the stormwater management systems shall be considered as a violation of this code and enforcement action may be initiated and enforced through the Municipal Code Enforcement Board. Fines and liens may be imposed as authorized by Chapter 162, Florida Statutes (as amended from time to time) and applicable codes and ordinances. If any entity has been dissolved or no longer owns said private stormwater management systems, then, in that event, the property owners utilizing said stormwater management systems or properties that are benefited by said stormwater management systems shall be financially responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of said stormwater management systems. For example, if stormwater management systems are to be owned and maintained by a homeowners association and the homeowners association has been dissolved, and is no longer active or functioning then, in that event, the lot owners utilizing said stormwater management systems or benefited by said systems shall be pro rata responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of said systems. The City may initiate an action through the Municipal Code Enforcement Board for said violation and appropriate fines and liens may be imposed and recorded against benefited properties. The liens may be foreclosed and collected in the same manner as code liens including the City's costs and a reasonable attorney's fees. 
Sec. 30-215. - Emergency exemption. 
(a)  This section shall not be construed to prevent the doing of any act necessary to prevent material harm to or destruction of real or personal property as a result of a present emergency, including, but not limited to, fire, infestation by pests, or hazards resulting from violent storms or hurricanes or when the property is in imminent peril and the necessity of obtaining a permit is impractical and would cause undue hardship in the protection of the property. 
(b)  A report of any such emergency action shall be made to the Administrator by the owner or person in control of the property upon which emergency action was taken as soon as practical, but no more than thirty (30) days following such action. Remedial action may be required by the Administrator subject to appeal to the City Council in the event of dispute. 
Sec. 30-216. - Vested rights. 
    Any existing previously approved preliminary plat, plat, site plan, planned unit development or other project that has secured approval or possess a building permit shall be entitled to develop and continue to be developed in accordance with the existing development approval. Failure to develop in accordance with the previous approved development permit or a substantial deviation shall cause the project to lose any vested rights to the previous approval and shall be required to develop in accordance with this article. 
Secs. 30-217-30-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - STREETS/SIDEWALKS/BIKES 

Sec. 30-226. - Access to arterial streets. 
(a)  Whenever a development or subdivision that involves the creation of one (1) or more new streets borders or contains an existing or proposed arterial street, no direct driveway access may be provided from the lots within said development or subdivision onto said arterial street. 
(b)  Back-out parking shall not be allowed onto any arterial street; however, this section shall not apply to those lots platted at the time of the effective date of this subsection, where said lots abut the said arterial streets and which must, by design, utilize back-out parking. 
(c)  No person shall subdivide any parcel fronting on an arterial street without making adequate provision for frontage roads or marginal access roads. The City may deny a permit for development if this provision is violated where possible, the distance between curb cuts on large parcels fronting arterial streets shall be six hundred and sixty (660) feet. 
Sec. 30-227. - Street entrances. 
(a)  All driveway entrances and other openings onto streets shall be constructed as follows: 
(1)  Vehicles shall be able to enter and exit from the lot in question without posing any substantial danger to themselves, pedestrians, or vehicles traveling in abutting streets. 
(2)  Interference with the free and convenient flow of traffic in abutting or surrounding streets shall be minimized. 
(b)  Projects for which a site plan is required shall be considered on an individual basis and may deviate from these requirements in the interest of traffic safety, as approved by the Administrator. 
(c)  Cross access between adjacent nonresidential parcels is required for arterial street locations to minimize potential conflicts and preserve the level of service unless waived by the Administrator with just cause. Examples of just causes are site constraints such as redevelopment or inability to physically connect to adjacent sites. A cross access easement agreement may be required for site plan approval. 
Sec. 30-228. - Coordination with surrounding streets. 
(a)  When there is no street shown in the roadway classification map or future traffic circulation map for the area to be developed or subdivided, the arrangement of streets in said development or subdivision shall either: 
(1)  Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas; or 
(2)  Conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved or adopted by the City Council, after recommendation by the Planning and Zoning Commission which responds to a particular situation where topographical or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impracticable. 
Sec. 30-229. - Relationship of streets to topography and site conditions. 
(a)  Streets shall be designed to facilitate drainage and storm water runoff and street grades shall conform as closely as practicable to the original topography. 
(b)  Streets shall be constructed with grades which conform to standards set forth in the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(c)  In no case may streets be constructed with grades that, in the professional opinion of the Administrator create a substantial danger to the public safety. 
(d)  The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to all official plans and shall be considered in their relation to the following: 
(1)  Pattern of existing and planned streets. 
(2)  Topographical conditions. 
(3)  Public convenience and safety. 
(4)  Proposed uses of land to be served by such streets. 
(5)  Minimization of encroachment on woodlands, wetlands, and groundwater recharge areas. 
Sec. 30-230. - Attention to handicapped in street construction. 
(a)  When curb and gutter construction is used on public and private streets, wheelchair ramps and depressed curbs shall be constructed in accordance with the FDOT Standard Index - latest addition. 
(b)  In unsubdivided developments, sidewalk construction for the handicapped shall conform to the requirements of the Architectural Barriers Act, 42 U.S.C. 451-4157, as well as Section 336.045, Florida Statutes, and the ANSI "Specifications for Making Buildings and Facilities Accessible to, and Usable by, Physically Handicapped People." 
Sec. 30-231. - Utilities. 
    Utilities installed in public rights-of-way or along private roads shall conform to the requirements set forth in Division 7, Utilities of this chapter. 
Sec. 30-232. - Street width and drainage requirements in subdivisions. 
    Street rights-of-way are designed and developed to serve several objectives: 
(a)  To carry motor vehicle traffic, and in some cases allow on-street parking; 
(b)  To provide a safe and convenient passageway for pedestrian and bicycle traffic; and 
(c)  To serve as an important link in the City's drainage system. 
    In order to fulfill these objectives, all public and private streets shall be constructed to meet the standards set forth in the following subsections and specified in Section 9.5, Roadway Requirements of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-233. - General layout of streets. 
(a)  The general layout of streets are set forth in Section 9.6 of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(b)  No existing platted or dedicated cul-de-sacs or platted lots or flag lots shall be utilized as access for a new subdivision or public street without the express concurrence and permission of the City Council of the City of Titusville. That it is the intention and purpose of this provision to protect existing cul-de-sacs and not have said existing lots be utilized as access for future subdivisions and future public streets without the express permission of the City Council of the City of Titusville. The City Council shall consider the street design criteria as set forth in the Land Development Regulations, traffic safety and engineering, and the public health, safety and general welfare of the City in approving new public streets or subdivisions. 
Sec. 30-234. - Street intersections. 
    Street intersections are set forth in [Section] 9.9 of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-235. - Street alignment and curvature. 
(a)  Horizontal curvature. Horizontal curvature is set forth in [Section] 9.10, Street Alignment of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(b)  Tangents. As set forth in [Section] 9.10, Street Alignment of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-236. - Construction standards and specifications. 
    Construction, design standards and specifications for streets, sidewalks, and curbs and gutters are administrative regulation and adopted by reference, in the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-237. - Public streets and private roads in subdivisions. 
(a)  In all districts, except residential districts (R-districts), no building or structure shall be erected on a parcel of land which does not abut a public street a minimum width of twenty-five (25) feet. The use of an easement for purposes of abutting a lot with a public street shall not comply with this regulation. 
(b)  In all residential districts (R-districts) no dwelling, except those located in a Planned Development or in an approved lot split or small-scale plat, shall be erected on a lot which does not abut at least one (1) public street for at least fifty (50) feet, except that a minimum street abutment distance of twenty-five (25) feet shall apply to properties of an irregular shape provided that a minimum building line width of fifty (50) feet is met at the required front yard setback line, measured from the street right-of-way line. A single-family dwelling may be erected on a flag lot as defined herein and permitted within the lot split and small-scale plat process, Chapter 34, Procedures, Article IV, Subdivisions, Division 2, Lot split and Division 4, Small-scale plat where the width of such lot does not entirely abut a dedicated public street. The use of an easement for purposes of abutting a lot with a public street shall not comply with this requirement. 
(c)  Residential development may be developed with private roads that meet the private street standards of this chapter so long as: 
(1)  The proposed development having direct access onto a private street shall be connected to a public street and such private road shall be improved to public local street standards at a minimum. 
(2)  No road intended to be private is planned to be extended to serve property outside that development. 
(3)  The standards set forth in Sections 30-226 thru 30-230 are complied with. 
(4)  The subdivider demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Planning and Zoning Commission and City Council that the private roads will be properly maintained. At a minimum, a provision for same shall be incorporated in the articles of the maintenance association. (See [Article I, Division 3,] Operating and Maintenance of this chapter.) 
(5)  No final plat that shows lots served by private streets may be recorded unless the final plat contains the following notations: 
a.  "Further subdivision of any lot shown on this plat as served by a private street shall be prohibited." 
b.  "All owners of land included by this plat shall be subject to any assessment of costs required to correct deficiencies caused by substandard construction and hold the City of Titusville harmless for any accident or injury to persons or property that may result therefrom." 
(6)  The recorded plat of any subdivision that includes a private road shall clearly state that such road is a private road. Further, the initial purchaser of a newly created lot served by a private road shall be furnished by the seller with a disclosure statement outlining the maintenance responsibilities for the road. 
(d)  The following general requirements shall apply to all subdivision streets within the corporate limits of the City: 
(1)  Paving. Road base and paving shall be installed in accordance with the specifications and standards set forth in the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. The developer shall be responsible for all construction costs for all streets within and abutting the proposed subdivision necessitated by said subdivision. 
(2)  Curbs and gutters. Curbs and gutters shall be installed in all streets in accordance with the Transportation Infrastructure Technical manual. 
(f)  Streets within apartments, townhouses, etc., may be private provided they meet the construction standards adopted by Section 30-236. 
Sec. 30-238. - Road and sidewalk requirements. 
(a)  Sidewalks shall be constructed along any lot or parcel of ground abutting any public or private street, on which a permit for new construction is granted, except as provided herein. Such sidewalks shall be of concrete and shall be inspected by the City. No building permits shall be issued by the Administrator, nor shall a certificate of occupancy be issued unless such sidewalk(s) are shown, with elevations, on the plans for construction, unless the requirement for sidewalks is specifically waived by the Administrator, based upon the following criteria: 
(1)  There are future plans for widening or improving the abutting road right-of-way within five (5) years and the construction of the sidewalk would be currently imprudent. 
(2)  The lot or parcel is located on a local street within an existing unplatted/platted subdivision, where over seventy-five (75) percent of the lots are developed and no sidewalks exist adjoining the developed lots. 
(3)  When the construction of the required sidewalk is programmed within the proposed capital improvements program or funds have been appropriated for its construction through an assessment program or other funding mechanisms. 
(4)  No certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the Administrator until required sidewalks are constructed or the requirements for sidewalks are waived or delayed as provided herein. When the requirements for sidewalks are deemed by the Administrator to be "not practical", monetary contributions to the sidewalk trust fund shall be made required as described in paragraph (c) below, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. The provision of payment into the sidewalk trust fund shall not be eligible for a variance before the Board of Adjustment and Appeals. 
(b)  Sidewalk standards as set forth per the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(c)  Sidewalk trust fund. 
(1)  There is hereby established a sidewalk trust fund to be used for the deposit, maintenance and distribution of all monetary contributions made in lieu of constructing a sidewalk pursuant to Section 30-238 of this Code, or a trail pursuant to Section 30-239 of this Code. The sidewalk trust fund shall be administered by the City's Public Works Department and shall be appropriated within the City's Roads and Streets Capital Improvement Fund and approved by the City Council annually, or as contributions are made to the trust fund. All contributions made pursuant to Sections 30-238 and 30-239 of this Code shall be monetary payments into the sidewalk trust fund. All contributions made to and interest derived from the sidewalk trust fund shall be used solely for the purpose of constructing, upgrading, or improving sidewalks along or on public streets within the City limits. 
(2)  If a sidewalk is required by this Code, but the construction of the sidewalk is determined to be not practical, then the property owner or permit applicant shall make a contribution to the sidewalk trust fund. 
(3)  The Administrator shall make the decision as to whether the construction of a sidewalk is "not practical." The following factors shall be utilized in making such a decision: 
a.  The project does not meet the waiver requirements in paragraph (b) above; 
b.  There is no connectivity for the required sidewalk; and 
c.  The required sidewalk will provide functional pedestrian access when connectivity is created. 
(4)  The sidewalk trust fund fee shall be established by City Council resolution. The fees shall be set on per linear foot of street frontage basis and shall be calculated as one hundred (100) percent of the average of the sidewalk construction costs on a per linear foot of street frontage basis as established by the City. 
(d)  Appeals. Appeals of the Administrator's determination as to the practicality of installing required sidewalks shall be processed as described in Section 34-248(b). If the appeal is granted by the Board of Adjustment and Appeals, the applicant shall make the required payment into the City's Sidewalk Trust Fund. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 3, 2-28-17) 
Sec. 30-239. - Bicycle facilities. 
(a)  All developments are required to construct those bicycle facilities designated in the Titusville Trailways Plan that abut their project. In lieu of construction, developments may complete all engineering and site work to construct the bicycle facility, including dedication of the required easement to the City of Titusville if necessary, and make a monetary contribution to the sidewalk trust fund equivalent to a sidewalk, as described in Section 30-238(c) of this Code. All facilities shall, at a minimum, meet the standards adopted by FDOT for bicycle facilities and the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. The provision of payment into the sidewalk trust fund shall not be eligible for a variance before the Board of Adjustment and Appeals. 
(b)  If it is contemplated that state controlled roads will provide bicycle paths within the road pavement area then pedestrian sidewalks only will be required. The Administrator shall make the final determination. 
(c)  Lighting, curbouts, slope, vertical clearance as set forth per the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 3, 2-28-17) 
Sec. 30-240. - Street names and house numbers. 
(a)  Street names. Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment with existing streets shall bear the assigned name of the existing street. In no other case shall the name for proposed streets duplicate or be phonetically similar to existing street names. New street names within a subdivision are named as part of the plat approval process. Renaming of existing streets shall require the approval of the City Council upon recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission and shall comply with the provisions below. 
(1)  Street renaming. A proposed street renaming may be initiated by either the City on its own initiative, or by the filing of a complete application with the City in accordance with the procedures set forth herein. All street name changes shall be for the entire length of the street. However, a segment of a street may be renamed if that segment is created by the intersection of a collector or arterial street. 
a.  Application. To be deemed complete, an application for a street renaming shall include the following information in addition to any other information that the Administrator may generally require for a street renaming application: 
1.  A signed, notarized consent to change street name form executed by at least seventy (70) percent of the owners of those properties abutting the segment of the street to be renamed. The consent to change street name form shall be in a format provided by the city. No consent shall be valid if it is executed more than one hundred twenty (120) days prior to the date of submission of the application. The applicant shall submit a complete list of all owners of property abutting the street to be renamed. This requirement shall not apply to a City initiated application. 
2.  Any request to rename a street for a person shall include a biography and explanation of the person's importance or relevance to the street, City, region, state or nation. Any request for any other street name change shall include information and an explanation of the importance or relevance of the proposed name to the street. 
3.  Letters from Brevard County E911 Administration Address Assignment, the Titusville Public Works Department and the Titusville Fire Department indicating their recommendations/concerns regarding the street renaming request shall be included. 
4.  No application shall be processed unless the application is complete, all documentation required by this subsection is provided, and the application fee is paid. 
b.  Review process. 
1.  The City shall hold two (2) public meetings on the street renaming proposal. One (1) public meeting shall be before the Planning and Zoning Commission and one (1) public meeting before the City Council. A courtesy notice of the public meetings shall be sent by City staff to all owners of property abutting the street to be renamed. The courtesy notice shall be mailed to those owners listed on the latest ad valorem tax rolls prepared by the county at the time of mailing at the address listed thereon. The notification shall be sent at least ten (10) days prior to the first public meeting and shall include a description of the street to be renamed, the proposed name change and the dates for the public meetings. Notice shall be deemed to have been given when the courtesy notice is deposited in the U.S. mail. 
2.  The street renaming application shall be submitted to the Planning and Zoning Commission for its review and recommendation to the City Council. 
3.  Naming guidelines. In addition to any other information deemed appropriate by Council, the following information, as applicable, shall serve as guidelines in consideration of a street renaming application: 
(A)  Recognized geographic names. 
(B)  Natural historic features. 
(C)  Significant historic contributions to the City, State, or United States. 
(D)  Persons of historic service to the City. 
(E)  Persons of outstanding civic service to the City. 
(F)  Documented community support for the name. 
(G)  Emergency 911 and public safety considerations. 
(H)  The cost that the renaming will have on the City or any other person that is or could be materially affected by the name change. 
4.  The naming/renaming of streets is a legislative action of the City Council and shall be determined in the Council's sole and absolute discretion. Nothing herein shall be construed as a delegation of any authority to name a street to any other person or entity, or to otherwise infringe upon Council's legislative authority in this regard. 
c.  Honorary street naming. 
1.  In lieu of renaming a street, the Council may consider any application submitted pursuant to this section as an application for designation of an honorary street name, authorizing an honorary street designation and the appropriate memorial marker to be placed along a street or segment thereof, in order to honor a distinguished person, place or event. 
2.  Streets carrying an honorary designation are not officially renamed, but carry a honorary name. 
(b)  Uniform numbering system adopted. 
(1)  A uniform system of numbering properties and principal buildings as shown on the map known as the "Property Numbering Map, Titusville, Florida," and filed in the office of the Administrator, and all explanatory matters on said map are hereby adopted and incorporated herein. 
(2)  In order to promote more responsive public safety and postal services, the following uniform system of assigning street names shall apply: 
a.  "Avenue" shall be assigned to linear streets aligned on a north/south axis. 
b.  "Street" shall be assigned to linear streets aligned on an east/west axis. 
c.  "Road" shall be assigned to linear streets aligned on a diagonal axis. 
d.  "Drive" shall be assigned to curvilinear streets. 
e.  "Boulevard" shall be assigned to streets on which a vegetated median exists on at least fifty (50) percent of its length. 
f.  "Court" shall be assigned to streets which terminate in a cul-de-sac. 
g.  "Circle" shall be assigned to streets which form a connected loop. 
h.  "Way" or "lane" shall be assigned to marginal access streets. 
(c)  Assignment of numbers. 
(1)  All properties, parcels of land and principal buildings within the corporate limits of the City of Titusville, Florida, shall be identified and numbered by the owners and occupants thereof in conformity with the uniform numbering system adopted in (b) above, provided that all owners and occupants of properties, parcels of land and buildings that are not numbered in conformity with said system shall have ninety (90) days from the effective date of these regulations in which to conform. 
(2)  Each principal building shall exhibit its assigned number on the frontage in which the front entrance of said building is located. If a principal building is a multiple-family structure comprised of four (4) or more dwelling units, the principal building shall bear a separate number and each dwelling unit therein shall affix a letter suffix or "apartment number" suffix to the building number. 
(3)  Numerals indicating the official numbers for each principal building or each front entrance to such buildings shall be posted in a manner as to be clearly visible and distinguishable from the street on which the property is located. Such numerals shall be a minimum of three (3) inches in height and one-half (1/2) inch in width and of a contrasting color with the building. 
(d)  Enforcement, generally. If the owner or occupant of any building required to be numbered by this article shall neglect for the period of thirty (30) days to duly attach and maintain the proper number on such building, the building inspector shall serve upon him a notice requiring such owner or occupant to properly number same, and if he neglects to do so for ten (10) days after the service of such notice, he shall be deemed to have violated this article. Each day that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
Sec. 30-241. - Street requirements. 
    Street design requirements are set forth in Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual, Section 9.2. 
Sec. 30-242. - Required Access Points. 
    A residential development shall have one (1) or more means of access as described below. The design of the collector or arterial roadway(s) providing access to the subdivision shall be constructed in accordance with the Manual of Uniform Minimum Standards for Design, Construction and Maintenance for Streets and Highways (Florida Greenbook), as determined by the City. 
Number of Households (lots or units) Number of Access Routes 1-100 One (1) 101-200 Two (2) except as described below 201-600 Two (2) 601 + Three (3) except as described below  
    Residential developments between one hundred one (101) and two hundred (200) households (lots or units) may be approved by the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ, defined as the Fire Chief or designee) with only one (1) point of access, if, in the opinion of the AHJ, equivalent safety measures consistent with NFPA Standards are implemented. 
    Subdivisions with six hundred one (601) or more lots or units shall have three (3) means of egress and ingress, unless, in the opinion of the AHJ, equivalent safety measures consistent with NFPA Standards are implemented. 
Secs. 30-243-30-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - UTILITIES 
Subdivision 1. - Utility Requirements 

Sec. 30-251. - Utility ownership and easement rights. 
(a)  In any case in which a developer installs or causes the installation of water, sewer, electrical power, telephone, or cable television facilities and intends that such facilities shall be owned, operated or maintained by a public utility or any entity other than the developer, the developer shall transfer to such utility or entity the necessary ownership or easement rights to enable the utility or entity to operate and maintain such facilities. 
(b)  Utility and other easements shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Utility easement, not less than twenty (20) feet in total width, centered on rear or side lot lines where deemed necessary by the City. 
(2)  Contingency easements centered on side lot lines of every lot, at least ten (10) feet in width. Contingency easements shall be for the purpose of repair, extension or maintenance of public facilities and utilities by public agencies and may be shown on the plat by note. 
(c)  Storm drainage, sanitary sewer, and water distribution systems shall be designed by an engineer, installed by the developer or subdivider and approved by the City, prior to formal acceptance of ownership by the City. 
Code of Ordinances Reference- Connection to the sewage disposal system, § 21-79. 
Sec. 30-252. - Sewage disposal/water supply facilities required. 
(a)  The cost of trunk line extensions for either water or sewer, when required for the development of a site or a subdivision shall be paid by the developer thereof. In the event the Council should determine in its sole discretion that the extension of a water or sewer trunk line shall be for the common good of various areas or lands abutting thereon or capable of being served thereby, and it shall be determined by Council that the extension provides specific benefit to said lands, areas or lots to be served, the economic cost of providing said extension shall be shared on an equal basis by all of such properties receiving said benefits. In no event shall the City be required to extend any such trunk line or pay the cost thereof, except upon its own volition and after appropriate action of the Council. 
(b)  Sanitary sewer and water distribution systems shall be designed by an engineer, installed by the developer or subdivider and approved by the City. 
(c)  The City shall have the sole and absolute discretion to determine if the distribution shall be owned by the City or maintained by the developer. 
Sec. 30-253. - Electric power. 
    Every principal use and every lot within a subdivision shall have available to it a source of electric power adequate to accommodate the reasonable needs of such use and lot within such subdivision. 
Sec. 30-254. - Telephone service. 
    Every principal use and every lot within a subdivision must have available to it a telephone service cable adequate to accommodate the reasonable needs of such use and every lot within such subdivision. 
Sec. 30-255. - Underground utilities. 
    All utility lines (telephone, cable T.V., power) shall be placed underground with the exception of major transmission corridors. 
Sec. 30-256. - Utilities to be consistent with internal and external development. 
(a)  Whenever it can reasonably be anticipated that utility facilities constructed in one (1) development will be extended to serve other adjacent or nearby developments, such utility facilities (e.g., water or sewer lines) shall be located and constructed so that extensions can be made conveniently and without undue burden or expense or unnecessary duplication of service. 
(b)  All utility facilities shall be constructed in such a manner as to minimize interference with pedestrian or vehicular traffic and to facilitate maintenance without undue damage to improvements or facilities located within the development. 
Sec. 30-257. - As-built drawings required. 
    Whenever a developer installs or causes to be installed any utility line in any public right-of-way, the developer shall, as soon as practicable after installation is complete, and before acceptance of any water or sewer line, furnish the City with a reproducible drawing that shows the exact location of such utility lines. Such drawings must be verified as accurate by the utility service provider. Compliance with this requirement shall be a condition of the continued validity of the permit authorizing such development. 
Sec. 30-258. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  The number and location of fire hydrants shall be approved by the City and shall meet the requirements of fire insurance underwriters or similar formula. 
(b)  The following amendments to the Standard Fire Code are hereby adopted: 
(1)  Section 603.1.3 of the Standard Fire Code is herein repealed and replaced with the following: 
"Fire hydrants shall be installed and operational prior to the issuance of a building permit for the construction of a building for all development, including single-family subdivisions, multifamily subdivisions, townhouses, condominiums, apartments, office complexes, shopping centers, industrial development, marinas, mobile home parks and subdivisions, and other similar development. This requirement shall be deemed to be satisfied when an operational fire hydrant capable of delivering the necessary flow is located within the prescribed distance measured along a paved right-of-way or inspected and approved private road or driveway. The prescribed distance for fire hydrant spacing is two hundred fifty (250) feet between hydrants in compact commercial, industrial and multifamily areas and not more than five hundred (500) feet in detached single-family district. Maximum dead-end distance shall not exceed two hundred (200) feet." 
(2)  A new subsection is herein added to Section 603.1.2(b) which reads: 
"Fire department connections shall be sited at the discretion of a fire official. All plans and specifications for any fire suppression system shall be designed and sealed by a Florida Registered Engineer or approval [approved] factory built systems. Permits for these systems will only be issued for a Florida licensed contractor in accordance with state statutes. The fees for permits shall be based on valuation of the installation of the system in accordance with Appendix K of the Standard Building Code and the administrative fee outlined in the fee schedule for construction permits. No installation of fire suppression systems, including underground piping from the municipal water supply, stand pipes and sprinkler systems can be contacted [contracted] or subcontracted to any company or individual not licensed in accordance with applicable statutes." 
Code of Ordinances Reference- Fire code adopted, § 9-1. 
Sec. 30-259. - Screening of dumpsters. 
    Refuse facilities shall be located only in the side yards or rear yards except when such yard is adjacent to a collector/arterial street as designated in the City's Roadway Classification Map. Such facilities must be constructed of an architectural surface similar to that of the principal building(s) and screened from view. 
Secs. 30-260-30-165. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 2. - Water and Sewers 

Sec. 30-266. - Sewage; sewer connections compulsory; connection required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner or agent of all improved property located within the City upon which property there is situated a building or structure from which liquid human sewage may be generated and there is an available City sanitary sewer line to connect to City sewer system. 
(b)  For purposes of this regulation [subdivision], "available" shall mean: 
(1)  The City sewage system is not under a moratorium; 
(2)  The City sewage system has adequate hydraulic capacity to accept the quantity of sewage to be generated by the proposed establishment; 
(3)  For all single-family residences or for establishments with estimated sewage flows of six hundred (600) or less gallons per day, a sewerage system shall be considered available if a sewer line exists in a public easement or right-of-way which abuts the property, and if gravity flow can be maintained from the building drain to the sewer line; 
(4)  For estimated sewage flows exceeding six hundred (600) gallons per day, with the exception of single-family residences a sewerage system shall be considered available if a sewer line, force main, or lift station exists in a public easement or right-of-way which abuts the property or within one hundred (100) feet of the property as accessed via rights-of-way or easements. 
(5)  For areas zoned or used for industrial or manufacturing purposes or its equivalent, a sewer line existing within one-quarter (1/4) mile of the development as accessed via easements or rights-of-way shall be considered available. For repair or modification purposes, an available sewer is any sewer line within five hundred (500) feet of the building sewer stub out as accessed via rights-of-way or easements. 
(c)  In the event the owner or agent has failed to connect to the sewer line after notification that a City sewer line is available, the City shall charge and collect a sewer service charge, even though the building or structure is not connected to the City sanitary sewer line, in the total amount established in Chapter 21 of the Code [of Ordinances].
