(d)  Every building or structure from which human waste may be generated is hereby required to have a sanitary water closet connected with the City sanitary sewage system where a City sanitary sewage system is available and if none is available, the owner or agent of said building or structure shall have a sanitary method of human waste disposal, namely, have an approved type of septic tank or a sanitary privy and obtain a permit therefor from the County Health Department or such other applicable agency. 
(e)  The City of Titusville hereby encourages the conservation of energy and resource and hereby authorizes the owner or agents of residential property to install a gray water system which is defined as a sewage system which retains waste from showers, bathtubs, laundries, lavatories, clothes washers, laundry tubs and bar sinks on-site in a drain field or in a recirculating retention tank or other approved type of disposal system approved by the Brevard County Health Department. Other waste generated from toilets, dishwashers, floor drains, kitchen sinks, latrines, etc., would continue to be disposed through the City sanitary sewage system. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to industrial, business, commercial, office buildings or other nonresidential users. 
(f)  Every new subdivision regardless of distance shall be required to connect to the City sewage system unless expressly waived as provided in the subdivision regulations. 
(g)  Any existing improved property upon which there is a building or structure from which liquid human sewage may be generated and not currently connected to the City sewage system shall be required to connect to the City sewage system within three hundred sixty-five (365) days of notification that a sewer line is available as defined above and located within a public easement or right-of-way which abuts the property and pay all applicable fees. 
(1)  Any existing building or structure which applies for a plumbing permit or increases its sewage flow because of modification or expansion of said building or structure, shall be required to connect to the City sewage system if the building or structure meets the "available" criteria specified in Subsection (3) above. 
(h)  In the event any new development is required to connect to the City sewage system, and the City does not have currently available plan capacity or line capacity, or currently is under a moratorium prohibiting the issuance of additional wetline sewage connection system permits or building permits, then in that event, the City will process a dry line permit in accordance with Section 39-132 of the Land Development Regulations and application FDER Regulations, provided the new development complies with all applicable City codes and regulations and Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services Regulations applicable to on-site sewage disposal system. If an on-site sewage disposal system permit is granted, the new development shall be required to install all of the necessary dry lines and associated equipment to connect to the City system when the City system is available at the time of the development. 
(1)  The City shall, within forty-five (45) days, connect the development to the City sewage system after written notification to the owner that the City system is available. 
(2)  The City shall require any new development receiving an on-site sewage disposal system permit to escrow such funds or monies with the City to cover the cost of connection of said system to the City sewage system and applicable connection and tap-on fees. 
Sec. 30-267. - Water and sewer utility construction, site plan review, and permit review fees. 
    Water resources, utility construction, site plan review and permit review service fees may be imposed by the City and shall be included with the Land Development Regulations and permit review fees of the Code of Ordinances. 
Secs. 30-268-30-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - PARKING/LOADING/STORAGE 
Subdivision 1. - General Requirements 

Sec. 30-271. - Purpose. 
    In addition to the requirements of this article, all developments shall adhere to the parking and dimensional standards set forth in the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-272. - Number of parking spaces required. 
    The number of parking spaces are set forth in Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual, Number of Parking Spaces Required, Section 9.16. 
Sec. 30-273. - Credit for required parking spaces. 
(a)  For industrial and office purposes only, a reduction may be given to the number of required parking spaces provided the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Applicant must submit a transportation plan for their operation detailing how employees will be utilizing different modes of transportation to and from work. 
(2)  Applicant must demonstrate a reasonable number of their employees will be utilizing bus service, ride share, van pooling, or any combination thereof. 
(3)  Applicant must submit a site plan which will maintain sufficient land available to reinstate all required parking if applicant's transportation plan should not be implemented or subsequently terminated. 
Sec. 30-274. - Parking space dimensions. 
    The parking space dimensions are set forth in Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual, Parking Design Standards, Section 9.17. 
Sec. 30-275. - Required widths of parking area aisles and driveways. 
    Parking drive aisle and driveway widths are set forth in Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual, Parking Design Standards, Section 9.17. 
Sec. 30-276. - General design requirements. 
(a)  Unless no other practical alternative is available, vehicle accommodation areas shall be designed so that, without resorting to extraordinary movements, vehicles may exit such areas without backing onto a public street. The requirement does not apply to parking areas consisting of driveways that serve one (1) dwelling unit, although backing onto highway, major arterial or minor arterial streets is not allowed. 
(b)  Vehicle accommodation areas of all development shall be designed so that sanitation, emergency, and other public service vehicles can serve such developments without the necessity of backing unreasonable distances or making other dangerous or hazardous turning movements. 
(c)  Every vehicle accommodation area shall be designed so that vehicles cannot extend beyond the perimeter of such area onto adjacent properties or public rights-of-way. Such areas shall also be designed so that vehicles do not extend over sidewalks or tend to bump against or damage any wall, vegetation, or other obstruction. 
(d)  Circulation areas shall be designed so that vehicles can proceed safely without posing a danger to pedestrians or other vehicles and without interfering with parking areas. 
(e)  Impervious parking lot requirements in the area of critical concern as set forth per Division 6, Stormwater, Section 30-207, Area of critical concern performance standards. 
Sec. 30-277. - Joint use of required parking spaces. 
(a)  To the extent that developments that wish to make joint use of the same parking spaces operate at different times, the same spaces may be credited to both uses. In order to be eligible for this credit, a parking analysis of the uses included must be provided to and accepted by the Administrator. 
(b)  If the joint use of the same parking spaces by two (2) or more principal uses involves satellite parking spaces, then the provisions of Section 30-278 are also applicable. 
Sec. 30-278. - Satellite parking. 
(a)  If the number of off-street parking spaces required by this chapter cannot reasonably be provided on the same lot where the principal use associated with these parking spaces is located, then spaces may be provided on adjacent or nearby lots in accordance with the provisions of this section. These off-site spaces are referred to in this section as satellite parking spaces. 
(b)  All such satellite parking spaces must be located within four hundred (400) feet of a public entrance of a principal building housing the use associated with such parking, or within four hundred (400) feet of the lot on which the use associated with such parking is located if the use is not housed within any principal building. Such satellite spaces shall be utilized or assigned to employees of the building served. 
(c)  The developer wishing to take advantage of the provisions of this section must present satisfactory written evidence of ownership or lease for at least ten (10) years. The developer must also sign an acknowledgment that the continuing validity of his permit depends upon his continuing ability to provide the requisite number of parking spaces. 
Sec. 30-279. - Curbing. 
    Curbing requirements are set forth per Section 9.19, Parking Lot Curbing and Tire Stops of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-280. - Loading and unloading areas. 
(a)  The general application of this section requires that whenever the normal operation of any development requires that goods, merchandise, or equipment be routinely delivered to or shipped from that development, a sufficient off-street loading and unloading area must be provided in accordance with this section to accommodate the delivery or shipment operations in a safe and convenient manner. Loading and unloading area requirements are set forth per Section 9.20 Loading and Unloading Areas of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(b)  Whenever (i) there exists a lot with one (1) or more structures on it constructed before the effective date of this chapter, and (ii) a change in use that does not involve any enlargement of a structure is proposed for such lot, and (iii) the loading area requirements of this section cannot be satisfied because there is not sufficient area available on the lot that can practically be used for loading and unloading, then the developer need only comply with this section to the extent reasonably possible. 
Sec. 30-281. - Excessive parking. 
    Required off-street parking areas for all uses shall be required to have all spaces covered in an impervious all-weather hard surface with the remainder to be in a clearly defined, approved, stabilized area to accommodate overflow parking; shall be marked to indicate driving lanes, parking spaces, and, if appropriate, direction of vehicular movement; and shall be maintained in good condition and clearly marked at all times. Impervious parking in excess of one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of that required by this section shall be prohibited unless approved by the Administrator. 
Sec. 30-282. - On-street parking regulations. 
    On-street parking regulations, including the travel trailers, campers or boat trailers, wrecker trucks, emergency parking of disabled vehicles and construction related parking are set forth per Chapter 20, Traffic and Motor Vehicles of the Code of Ordinances. 
Sec. 30-283. - On-street parking credit. 
(a)  The following zoning districts may utilize on-street parking allowance parking strategy located in Section 9.21.3.8 of the Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual: 
(1)  Downtown Mixed Use (DMU). 
(2)  Urban Mixed Use (UMU). 
(Ord. No. 37-2017, § 33, 11-14-17) 
Secs. 30-284-30-290. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 2. - Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) Parking Requirements 

Sec. 30-291. - Parking standards in the Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning district. 
(a)  It is the intent of this section to provide parking requirements for any and all areas covered by the Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning district guidelines. The purpose of these regulations is to provide flexibility within the DMU zoning district and create a pedestrian oriented core within the City. 
(b)  Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning district boundaries. The boundaries of the Downtown Mixed-Use zoning district (DMU) are the same as the boundaries of the Downtown Community Redevelopment Area, with the exception of the Residential Historic Preservation Zoning District (see Chapter 28, Zoning, Article III, Downtown Mixed-Use Smart Code). 
(c)  Parking requirements, including the number of spaces required, aisle and space dimensions, loading requirements, queuing for drive-through facilities, visibility and access to off-street parking, are set forth per in Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual, Downtown Mixed-Use Parking Requirements, Section 9.21. 
Secs. 30-292-30-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - LANDSCAPING 
Subdivision 1. - Landscaping Requirements 

Sec. 30-301. - Intent. 
    The intent of this section is to establish standards that enhance the City's appearance and encourage sustainable practices. This section establishes sustainable landscaping practices that will maintain a healthy landscape for a prolonged period of time with extremely low water usage and low/minimal maintenance requirements. 
Sec. 30-302. - Applicability. 
    The standards set forth herein prescribe the regulations applicable to all development in the City. Additional standards applicable to the Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning are specified in Subdivision 8 of this division. Where there is a conflict the most restrictive regulation shall apply. 
Sec. 30-303. - Standards. 
(a)  Landscape areas include buffers (Subdivision 3, Buffers and screening), streetscape landscaping (Subdivision 4, Streetscape landscaping), building landscaping (Subdivision 5, Building landscaping), and parking lot landscaping (Subdivision 7, Parking lot landscaping) of this article. This article applies to the applications described in the applicability of standards table. To ensure that the landscaping provided is adequate to meet the intent of this article, the following items shall be addressed with labels and notation on the landscaping plan where appropriate: 
(1)  Native vegetation is preferred and encouraged to be drought tolerant. Newly installed plant materials are encouraged to be drought tolerant species. Areas to be preserved in their natural state shall meet the requirements of the regulations for other areas. A listing of said species is available for reference in the Landscape Technical Manual. 
(2)  All other areas. All property, except for land utilized for principal structures, accessory structures, off-street parking areas, other vehicular use areas and required landscaped areas shall be landscaped with grass, ground cover, shrubs, or trees. Other areas. 
(3)  Clearing. Clearing of development sites, shall not be allowed prior to the issuance of a site clearing permit and shall be consistent with these regulations. Within the area of critical concern (see Chapter 29, Special districts and overlays, Article X, Area of critical concern overlay), an approved phased clearing plan, showing cut and fill quantities to be moved on-site, is required. 
(4)  Installation. All landscaping shall be installed in a sound, workmanlike manner and according to accepted good planting practice (including mulched areas around appropriate species so as to protect and present a finished appearance) with the quality of plant materials as hereinafter described. A qualified representative of the City of Titusville or designated qualified agent shall inspect all landscaping and no certificates of occupancy or similar authorization will be issued unless the landscaping meets the requirements provided herein. 
(5)  Materials (Subdivision 2, of this division). 
(6)  Yards (Subdivision 3, of this division). 
(7)  Streetscape where applicable (Subdivision 4, [of this division]). 
(8)  Building landscaping (Subdivision 5, of this division). 
(9)  Maintenance (Subdivision 6, of this division). 
(10)  Parking area landscaping (Subdivision 7, of this division).

Sec. 30-304. - Maintenance and inspections. 
(a)  The health and viability of all required landscape materials on the site, whether preserved or newly planted, must be maintained through proper care or replacement in perpetuity after issuance of the certificate of occupancy, certificate of completion, or restoration as may be required to resolve a code violation. 
(b)  For multifamily, residential subdivisions, commercial, institutional, public and industrial projects, failure to have viable landscape materials or preserved areas consistent with the approved landscape plan after the issuance of the certificate of occupancy or certificate of completion shall constitute a violation. Failure to remove nonnative invasive plants and control re-growth prior to the final landscaping inspection is a violation and shall be enforced. The city reserves the right to enter property to make the necessary inspections. 
(c)  An on-site inspection shall be conducted prior to the approval of the land clearing permit. 
Sec. 30-305. - Continuing maintenance required. 
(a)  Any person owning or occupying the site shall have the continuing duty and obligation to maintain or cause the maintenance of all landscaping required pursuant to this article by the approved site plan, landscape plan, or this Code in compliance with the following minimum maintenance standards: 
(1)  All landscaping and landscape areas shall be maintained so as to present a neat and orderly appearance. 
(2)  All dead plant material shall be promptly replaced with plant material meeting the requirements of the approved site plan and landscape plan. 
(3)  Trees and palms that are removed, excessively pruned, dead, or beyond recovery shall be replaced. 
Sec. 30-306. - Redevelopment. 
    All property where there is redevelopment proposed or where an addition or an increase in impervious surface to an existing development is proposed shall be required to comply with this division to the greatest extent possible as determined by the Administrator. The Administrator shall also utilize the criteria specified in Article I, General provisions, Division 2, Administrative exceptions, Section 30-3, Standards for administrative exceptions when addressing the redevelopment provision of this section. 
Sec. 30-307. - Interpretation of terms. 
    Where necessary to interpret the precise meaning of technical landscaping terms used in this division, reference shall be made to Chapter 37, Definitions. 
Sec. 30-308. - Landscape plan. 
(a)  All developments shall have a landscaping plan prepared by a licensed landscape architect or certified nursery professional and shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of this article and shall include: 
(1)  Location and size of each landscape yard (public, private and service areas). 
(2)  A table that includes the landscape materials. The table should include the following: 
•  Genus, species and common name of plants, 
•  Number of each plant type existing and size, 
•  Number of each plant type removed and size, 
•  Number of each plant type installed and size, 
•  Species of each plant removed or installed, 
•  Locations of each plant type and size, and 
•  Type of sod, groundcover, shrub, and trees. 
(3)  An irrigation plan with the identification of water-use zones including building perimeter, yards, buffers, screens, parking and streetscape, where applicable. 
a.  High or oasis water-use zones: areas requiring regular watering. This zone is highly visible, high maintenance areas of the landscape, such as the area closest to the property structure where plants are watered regularly in the absence of rainfall. 
b.  Moderate or drought-tolerant water-use zones: landscape areas requiring occasional watering. Plants established in this zone requires watering only when they wilt or show other symptoms of moisture stress. 
c.  Low or "tolerant" water-use zones water-use zones: landscape areas requiring low or natural (rainfall) watering and would not require irrigation. 
(4)  Location and size of areas to be preserved in a natural state. 
Sec. 30-309. - Landscaping and screening. 
    Landscaping and screening standards are set forth per Subdivision 3, Landscape yard (buffer/screening) of this division. 
Secs. 30-310-30-320. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 2. - Landscape Materials 

Sec. 30-321. - Plant materials. 
(a)  Quality: Plant material used in conformance with the provisions of this article shall be good, healthy and sturdy plants. All plant material shall be Florida #1 grade or better. Plant materials which are known to be intolerant of paving environments or whose physical characteristics may be injurious to the public or which produce a quantity and/or quality of debris so as to present maintenance difficulties shall not be specified for use under this article. 
(b)  Native vegetation: The applicant is encouraged to utilize plant material native to Brevard County in meeting these landscaping requirements. The existing vegetation that is native to Brevard County with the exception of that listed in Section 30-4(d) shall be preserved and utilized except when removal is justified and determined to be acceptable by the enforcement official (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(c)  Ground cover: Ground covers, other than grass, shall be planted in such a manner so as to present a finished appearance and reasonably complete coverage within six (6) months after planting (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(d)  Lawn grass: Grass areas shall be planted in species normally grown as permanent lawns in Brevard County. Seeding and sprigging may be used if grass cover is complete within six (6) months, or sodding will be required (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(e)  Hedges: Hedges, where required, shall be planted in sufficient number and maintained so as to form a continuous, unbroken, solid screen within a maximum of six (6) months after time of planting (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(f)  Synthetic plants prohibited: Synthetic or artificial material in the form of trees, shrubs, ground covers, vines or artificial turf shall not be used in lieu of the plant requirements in this section. 
(g)  [Overstory trees:] Overstory trees shall be species having an average mature spread of crown of greater than twenty (20) feet and reach a mature height of at least sixty (60) feet, and having a trunk which can be maintained in a clean condition with over five (5) feet of clear wood (no branches). Trees, including palms, having an average mature spread of crown less than twenty (20) feet may be arranged in groupings so as to create the equivalent of twenty-foot crown spread and shall count as one (1) required tree. Invasives shall not be used to fulfill the requirements of this article (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(h)  Caliper: Plant materials required by this section shall comply with the minimum size requirements of Table 30-5, Minimum landscape planting specifications at the time of installation. Plant height shall be measured from the average grade level of the immediate planting area to the top horizontal plane of the shrub at planting; for single-trunk trees, the measurement shall be taken six (6) inches above grade level; for multitrunk trees, the tree shall be measured from the average grade level of the immediate planting area. 
(i)  Planting areas and shrubs: Planting areas shall consist of permeable surface areas only. The permeable surface areas for shrubs may be included with permeable surface areas required for trees. 
(j)  Pavement edges: Each overstory, coniferous, understory [tree] or shrub shall be planted at least twelve (12) inches from the edge of any paved surface. 
(k)  Irrigation: Irrigation must be indicated on the landscape plan. Any landscape area must be shown by water tolerant usage area. 
Sec. 30-322. - Minimum size of plantings/grading of planting. 
(a)  In the case of multi-story buildings, tree caliper shall increase at twenty-five (25) percent per floor up to four (4) floors above ground level. 
(b)  In the event a site plan layout does not have adequate open space to accommodate required plant quantities, such quantities per species can be combined into less quantities per species, provided total required height or caliper is maintained and approved by the Administrator. 
(c)  All newly installed plants shall meet the requirements established in Table 30-5, Minimum landscape planting specifications and Table 30-6, Acceptable palm tree substitutions below:

Sec. 30-323. - Existing vegetation. 
    All open areas of any site not occupied by building, parking, storage, or required landscape plant materials shall be retained as a natural vegetated area or (sodded) grass or ground cover. The developer shall make a good faith effort to incorporate existing vegetation in the landscaping throughout the property. 
Sec. 30-324. - Landscape. 
(a)  Residential development: 
(1)  All single-family residential lots or developments shall preserve an area of approved low and moderate tolerant water usage mixed vegetation (native trees and shrubs are preferred) equal to at least ten (10) percent of the total lot or development area. In the event there is no approved low and moderate tolerant water usage mixed vegetation on a lot or development, the applicant shall be required to establish an area of approved low and moderate tolerant water usage mixed vegetation equal to ten (10) percent of the lot or development. Required landscaping may be credited as established in the Landscape Credits Table, 30-7 of this section. 
(2)  At a minimum, fifty (50) percent of newly installed vegetation must be shrubs. 
(3)  The front yard tree requirement may be waived by the Administrator if the residential lot(s) preserves trees and underlying vegetation in the front yard setback area. 
(b)  Commercial development: 
(1)  Ten (10) percent of the required landscape area for a commercial development shall utilize low and moderate tolerant water usage mixed vegetation (native trees and shrubs are preferred). The City can supply the applicant with a list of approved mixed low and moderate tolerant water usage vegetation upon request (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(c)  Industrial development: 
(1)  Ten (10) percent of the required landscape area for an industrial development shall utilize low and moderate tolerant water usage mixed vegetation (native trees and shrubs are preferred). The City can supply the applicant with a list of approved mixed low and moderate tolerant water usage vegetation upon request (see Landscape Technical Manual). 
(2)  Industrial development may consolidate all required landscaping between the public right-of-way and the building. For example, the required planting materials in a building perimeter landscape strip for the entire perimeter of the proposed structure may be consolidated along the front edge of the building. As the minimum plant materials will be consolidated along the front of the building, the remainder of the perimeter will not require a building perimeter landscape strip. This consolidation can be applied to required building perimeter landscape strips, and required landscape yards except as noted below. This regulation shall not be construed to not require landscaping between the building and any public right-of-way. 
(3)  Required landscape yards may only be consolidated between the building and public right-of-way for property lines that abut other industrial development or zoning districts. Industrial development that abuts non-industrial development or zoning districts shall provide the required buffer along those property lines abutting non-industrial development or zoning districts. 
(4)  Industrial development which is adjacent to two (2) public rights-of-way (ex: a corner lot) may consolidate the required landscaping between the building and the two (2) rights-of-way. 
[(d)]  [Reserved.] 
(e)  Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning district. The DMU landscape standards can be found in Division 7 of this chapter. 
(f)  Required landscaping may be credited as established in the landscape credits table below.

Note- Irregular shaped lots - It is the intent that by following the above-outlined performance standards, each newly planted tree (palms not included) will have an average two hundred (200) square foot rooting area. If a conflict occurs between newly planted trees, trees preserved, and the number of trees required because of lot size, the Administrator may make the determination to ensure the required rooting area of two hundred (200) square feet for each tree. 
Secs. 30-325-30-330. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 3. - Landscape Yard (Buffer/Screen) 

Sec. 30-331. - Applicability. 
(a)  This section applies to any of the following: 
(1)  Provides landscaped separation between land-use intensities where appropriate; 
(2)  Screens from view certain land uses that may create visual clutter and distraction; and 
(3)  Provides for increases in the width and opacity of the landscape buffer yard as the land-use intensity of the new or expanded development increases. 
(b)  Landscape yard: Landscaped area measured from the property line to a depth as prescribed in the code. The term includes landscape strip, landscape buffer, buffer yard, and landscape screen. In a platted subdivision, the required landscape yard shall be located in a separate tract or common area to be maintained by the Homeowners Association. 
(c)  This section applies to any construction or erection of any new building or structure for which a development approval is required. 
(Ord. No. 54-2018, § 1, 12-11-18) 
Sec. 30-332. - Required landscape yards. 
(a)  Required landscape yard type establishes when a landscape yard is required for differing land use intensities. Only the proposed development or redevelopment shall be required to provide the buffer. In a platted subdivision, the required landscape yard shall be located in a separate tract or common area to be maintained by the Homeowners Association. The applicant shall install the type of landscape yard indicated in the Required Landscape Yard Type Table.

Sec. 30-333. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The requirements of Subdivision 3, Landscape yards of this division do not apply to the following situations: 
(1)  Accessory structures. 
(2)  Agricultural uses. 
(3)  The reconstruction of an existing building of which fifty (50) percent or less of the floor area was destroyed or ruined by flooding, fire, wind storm, or act of God. This exemption shall apply only where reconstruction of that building will not result in an increase in building size or paving area of the parking facilities to be provided. 
(4)  Interior finish work or remodeling in a portion of a building unless the work results in an increase in the paving area of the parking facilities within the street yard or in an enlargement of the exterior dimensions of an existing building. 
(5)  Any use, building, or structure for which only a change of use is requested and which requires no structural modifications that increase its volume or scale. 
(6)  Single-family dwellings located on an existing lot of record. 
(7)  Residential lots. All residential lots shall provide a minimum of one (1) boulevard tree (planted between the curb and lot line) and one (1) front yard tree (planted between the lot line and the front building line). 
(Ord. No. 54-2018, § 3, 12-11-18) 
Sec. 30-334. - Reduction in required landscape yards. 
    Any landscape areas reduced in size shall be offset by an equal amount in another area of the site. 
Sec. 30-335. - Description of landscape yards. 
(a)  There are five (5) types of landscape yards. The landscape yard standards table illustrates a typical landscape yard and shows the minimum width and number of trees and/or plants required per two hundred (200) linear feet for each landscape yard. Each landscape yard type provides several plant material options. The applicant may either plant new trees or plants or preserve existing trees or plants within the required buffer that meet the requirement of this section.

(c)  Exhibit A: Buffers 

Sec. 30-336. - Landscaping required for all site development. 
(a)  For sites already disturbed/cleared or where little or no approved low and moderate tolerant water usage mixed vegetation already exists, the same buffers shall be required and the site shall be reforested with approved low and moderate tolerant water usage trees and shrubs suitable for the existing soils and topography. In addition, sites adjacent to the roadways identified in Exhibit "A" shall comply with the Required Landscape Yard Type Table 30-8. 
(b)  A landscape plan will be required for all landscape yards and shall be reviewed under the criteria established for non-residential projects in Section 30-332. 
(c)  Landscape areas may be less than ten (10) feet in depth required in the required landscape yard type table to provide safe access and clear zones. 
(d)  Necessary accessways from the public or private right-of-way through all such landscaping shall be permitted to service the parking or other vehicular use areas. 
Sec. 30-337. - Permitted uses within the landscape buffer yard. 
(a)  No active recreation area, storage of materials, parking, or structures, except for necessary utility boxes and equipment, shall be located within the landscape buffer yard. 
(b)  Landscape yards shall not be included as drainage, right-of-way, utility or other easements unless otherwise approved by the administrator, providing that the original intent and purpose of this section is met and there are unusual circumstances provided to the administrator. 
(c)  The landscape buffer yard for development, other than platted subdivisions, may be included in the required building setback. 
(d)  The landscape buffer yard may be included in the required open space (see Article III, Improvements, Division 3, Open space of this chapter). 
(e)  Landscape buffer yards may be used as greenways (see Development Options Chapter, Article II, Planned Industrial District). 
(f)  In a platted subdivision, the required landscape yard shall be located in a separate tract or common area to be maintained by the Homeowners Association. 
(Ord. No. 54-2018, § 4, 12-11-18) 
Sec. 30-338. - Natural buffer yards. 
    Existing vegetation with native vegetation may be used to meet any of the buffer yard requirements if the criteria of the required landscape yard type table are met. The applicant shall retain as much of the existing native vegetation towards the buffer or landscape yard requirement. 
Sec. 30-339. - Visual buffer and screening requirements. 
(a)  A screen refers to a visual barrier designed to separate differing land use intensities and to remove service bays, outdoor storage and handling areas, and trash receptacles from public view. 
(1)  A screen shall be a continuous hedge, or a solid wood or masonry wall fence. An earth berm may be used in concert to achieve a portion of the required height. 
(2)  Said screen shall be a minimum of six (6) feet in height. (In the case of a hedge it must reach the required height and provide a continuous one hundred (100) percent opaque screen within six (6) months from installation.) 
Note: Said hedge shall not be credited against the requirements established in the landscape yard standards table. 
(b)  Fences and walls used for visual buffer and screening shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  Fences and walls shall be a minimum of six (6) feet in height. 
(2)  Fences and walls shall be solid and one hundred (100) percent opaque. 
(3)  Fence materials shall be a minimum of a one-half-inch thick and shall be made of wood, precast concrete, or other similar materials. 
(4)  Corrugated and/or galvanized steel or metal sheets are not permitted. 
(5)  Walls may be concreted, concrete block with stucco finish, masonry, stone, or a combination of these materials. 
(6)  Support posts shall be placed on and face toward the inside of the developing property so that the surface of the wall or fence is smooth on the abutting property side. 
(c)  Berms used for visual buffer and screening shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  Berms shall have a slope not greater than the slope created in three (3) horizontal feet with a one (1) foot vertical rise. 
(2)  The surface of the berm that is not planted with trees and shrubs shall be covered with grass, perennial ground cover, vines, and woody and herbaceous perennials, with mulch. 
(3)  Grass or other coverings shall be maintained in conformance with applicable City of Titusville codes. 
(d)  Parking stalls shall be screened from the view of neighboring uses and from the street. Screening for parking stalls shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  The screen shall be a minimum of thirty (30) inches in height. 
(2)  The screen shall be an architecturally compatible solid masonry wall, earth berm, or shrubbery hedge planted three (3) feet on center, or any combination thereof. 
(3)  If shrubbery is used, it shall meet the minimum height within six (6) months, and the shrubbery shall not be credited towards any other required landscaping. 
(e)  Dumpster enclosures shall be required to meet the following standards: 
(1)  Dumpsters shall be screened with a fence or wall that meet the standards of subsection (b) above. 
(2)  Enclosures shall have a perimeter landscape strip clear of all doors and accessways, five (5) feet wide, and shall be planted with shrubs three (3) feet on center grass and/or ground cover. 
(3)  Dumpster enclosures shall be oriented such that the opening is not exposed to public view or shall be screened as provided for above. 
(f)  Off-street loading spaces, refuse and outdoor storage areas, antennas, satellite dishes, and mechanical equipment shall be screened from all public streets. The screening shall be a minimum of six (6) feet in height or a height sufficient to obscure the area or equipment requiring the screening, whichever is less. The screening may be provided by plants, a fence or wall that meets the standards in Section 30-15(b), or a combination of walls and plants. The height of plants shall be based on reaching their size of maturity within five (5) growing seasons. 
(g)  Planned Industrial Development (PID): In addition to the requirements of Section 30-15, no off-street loading area shall be located in a required front yard or within ten (10) feet of a side or rear property line. Such loading facilities that are visible only to another lot shall be screened to fifty (50) percent opaqueness using a combination of berms, shrubs, trees, fencing and/or architectural design. 
Sec. 30-340. - Utilities. 
    Utility companies shall provide landscape yards for electrical substations, water pumping/storage sites, and wastewater treatment plants. The buffer shall comply with the requirements for a Public R.O.W. per Exhibit A described in the required landscape yard type table. 
Secs. 30-341-30-350. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 4. - Streetscape. 

Sec. 30-351. - Streetscape. 
(a)  Streets classified as boulevards shall have boulevard trees planted at an interval of at least one (1) per one hundred (100) feet between the edge of pavement and the property line. These trees shall not be credited to the required minimum landscaping under Section 30-322(c), Minimum landscape planting specifications table. 
(b)  Chapter 30-240(b)(2)(e), Uniform numbering system adopted, states that boulevards are defined as streets on which a vegetated median exists on a least fifty (50) percent of its length. 
Secs. 30-352-30-360. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 5. - Building Landscaping 

Sec. 30-361. - Applicability. 
    This section applies to any commercial, industrial, mixed-use or multi-family structure that has a building footprint that exceeds one thousand (1,000) square feet. 
Sec. 30-362. - Standards. 
(a)  Building landscaping shall abut the building and shall be used or installed in such a manner as to screen mechanical equipment attached to or adjacent to the building, provide direction to and enhance entrances, and enhance walkways and provide visual breaks along blank building facades. Building landscaping is required on all building sides except those sides facing an alley, openings for overhead or loading-area doors, motor vehicle bays or entrances to the building, or the perimeter of attached or detached canopies. Landscaping, buffering, and screening for loading areas, vehicle bays, service areas are set forth in Section 30-340, Visual buffer and screening requirements. 
(b)  All development except residential: All buildings shall have a five-foot wide perimeter landscape strip adjacent to the building, clear of all doors and accessways. 
(c)  This area shall be planted with shrubs three (3) feet on center, grass and/or ground cover. 
(d)  Variations to this requirement may be approved by the Administrator, providing that the original intent and purpose of this section is met and there are unusual circumstances provided to the Administrator. At a minimum an equal area shall be set aside within the development for any building perimeter landscape reduction. 
(e)  NOTE: Native vegetation is preferred and encouraged to be drought tolerant. A listing of said species is available for reference in the Landscape Technical Manual, as updated regularly by the Administrator. (See Section 30-6(k), Irrigation.) 
Secs. 30-363-30-370. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 6. - Plant Area Maintenance 

Sec. 30-371. - Maintenance. 
    The owner, tenant and their agent, if any, shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of all landscaping, which shall be maintained to present a healthy, neat and orderly appearance at all times and shall be kept free from refuse and debris. The property owner, tenant, or their agent shall provide weeding, mowing of grass, irrigation, fertilization, prevention of pests, pruning, and other maintenance of all plantings as needed. The pruning of trees shall be to establish a central leader (except for multi-trunk species) and minimize co-dominant stem growth. All landscape material shall be maintained so as to provide for access for utilities, emergency services and vehicles. Maintenance shall include the immediate replacement of all dead plant material. The maintenance area also includes adjacent public and/or private streets and rights-of-way. This section shall also apply to all existing landscaped non-residential areas throughout the City. 
Sec. 30-372. - Planting standards. 
(a)  Plant areas must be protected from vehicular traffic through the use of concrete curbs, wheel stops, or other permanent barriers. Each large tree, small tree, or large shrub shall be planted at least twelve (12) inches from the edge of any paved surface. Trees of species whose roots are known to cause damage to public roadways or other public works shall not be planted closer than twelve (12) feet to such public works. 
(b)  Soil in all planting areas is to be of suitable quality with adequate pH value and no large aggregates so as to support healthy plant life. 
(c)  Trees. All newly planted trees shall be planted in a mulched area of at least twenty-five (25) square feet with the minimum dimensions of five (5) feet. 
(d)  Landscape islands are to be free of base material or pavement. Hardpan material should be removed to a depth of four (4) feet. 
Sec. 30-373. - Irrigation. 
(a)  Irrigation: A hose bib or other source of irrigation shall be provided within one hundred (100) feet of any landscaped area. All proposed commercial, industrial and multi-family developments shall provide an irrigation plan as part of the site plan review process outlined in Chapter 34, Procedures, Article V, Site plan of these regulations. This plan shall detail the layout, head type, coverage area, pipe size and water source for the irrigation system. The system shall be controlled by an automatic timer with a rain sensor. The high, moderate and low water-use zones be labeled on the on the greenspace (landscape) plan for irrigation purposes. This requirement may be waived by the Administrator for areas utilizing low water tolerant mixed vegetation. 
(b)  In the Planned Industrial Development (PID) zoning district, underground irrigation shall be required for all front yards, corner side yards, and rear yards if adjacent, to S.R. 405, U.S. #1 or Grissom Parkway; or any collector/arterial street as designated in the City's Future Traffic Circulation Map. Such irrigation shall extend to include the public boulevard and into general parking islands, except natural areas to be preserved. See development options for development standards, Chapter 33, Article II. 
Sec. 30-374. - Overhead power lines. 
    Large species trees shall not be planted under or within fifteen (15) feet of overhead power lines. Where existing or proposed overhead electric lines conflict with tree canopies, required overstory trees may be placed elsewhere within the development to avoid overhead infrastructure. 
Secs. 30-375-30-380. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 7. - Parking Area Landscaping 

Sec. 30-381. - Applicability. 
(a)  Shading is required for any parking area (excluding driveways or garages). Overstory trees, as identified on the approved plant list, shall provide shade for parking areas. A "parking lot" does not include an area used exclusively for the display of motor vehicles for sale as part of an automobile dealership. 
(b)  These regulations shall apply to any construction of a new parking lot or expansion of an existing parking lot. 
Sec. 30-382. - Design. 
(a)  Landscape island. Landscape islands shall be required to break up long continuous rows of parking spaces. Landscape islands shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  Landscape islands shall be a minimum of fifteen (15) feet in width. 
(2)  Landscape islands shall be a minimum of two hundred seventy (270) square feet in total area. 
(3)  In no instance shall a parking bay contain more than fifteen (15) continuous parking spaces or extend more than one hundred fifty (150) feet, whichever is more restrictive, without being broken up by a landscape island. 
(4)  These landscape islands must have one (1) overstory tree with a minimum diameter of three (3) inches caliper, twelve (12) feet high at the time of planting. 
(5)  The remaining landscape island shall contain ten (10) shrubs and/or ground cover and be completely covered within six (6) months. 
(6)  The required landscaping in these areas shall not be counted towards any other landscaping required by these regulations. Landscape islands which do not form a peninsula from other landscaped areas shall be planted with trees, shrubs and/or ground cover. The use of grass in these isolated islands is discouraged unless the applicant can demonstrate to the Administrator's satisfaction that adequate maintenance thereof can be provided. 
(7)  Sites containing two (2) acres or less may be given consideration for the reduction of the above requirements in (a) and (b) by the Administrator. In no case shall landscaping area be less than ten (10) feet wide and one hundred eighty (180) square feet. 
(b)  Terminal island. Terminal islands shall be required for each row of interior parking spaces to terminate the row of parking. Terminal islands shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  Terminal islands shall be a minimum of fifteen (15) feet in width. 
(2)  Terminal islands shall be a minimum of two hundred forty (240) square feet. 
(3)  Terminal islands must have one (1) tree of a minimum diameter of three (3) inches caliper, twelve (12) feet high at time of planting. 
(4)  No shrubs or other landscaping material shall block the visual access between thirty (30) inches and eight (8) feet and shall be maintained as such. 
(5)  Landscaping areas that terminate two (2) rows of parking in a corner or angle formation shall be required to provide a minimum twenty (20) feet × twenty (20) feet area. 
(6)  The required landscaping in these areas shall not be counted towards any other landscaping required by these regulations. 
(7)  Sites containing two (2) acres or less may be given consideration for the reduction of the above requirements in (a) and (b) by the Administrator. In no case shall a landscape area be less than ten (10) feet wide and one hundred eighty (180) square feet. 
(c)  Wherever a row of parking spaces does not face another row of parking spaces or a required landscape area, then a landscape strip shall be provided. Said landscape strip shall have a minimum depth of five (5) feet and shall form a continuous strip between landscape islands, and meet the requirements in Section 30-15(d). 
(d)  An optional landscape area to separate two (2) rows of head-on parking may be provided. In cases where parking stalls are allowed to overhang optional landscape islands the Administrator may approve a reduction in the required minimum parking stall length dimension, not to exceed a minimum dimension of eighteen (18) feet. 

Secs. 30-383-30-390. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 8. - Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) Landscape Standards 

Sec. 30-391. - Intent. 
(a)  It is the intent of this section to provide guidelines for the installation of landscape plant material on any and all development and redevelopment sites within the downtown community redevelopment area (DCRA) and covered by the Downtown Mixed-Use zoning district guidelines (DMU). The design of plantings and irrigation shall be done with the intent of minimizing the use of potable or well water for irrigation. Landscape plans submitted for projects within the DCRA shall be prepared by a Landscape Architect or a Certified Nursery Professional registered to practice in the State of Florida. 
(b)  Downtown Mixed-Use (DMU) zoning district boundaries. The boundaries of the Downtown Mixed-Use zoning district (DMU) are the same as the boundaries of the downtown community redevelopment area, with the exception of the Residential Historic Preservation zoning district (See Chapter 28, Zoning, Article III, Downtown Mixed Use Smart Code). 
(c)  Plant material shall be selected based on its appropriateness for use on and around the property. A percentage of the total cumulative landscape plant material used to meet the provisions of this section shall be "moderately" or "very" drought tolerant, as classified and listed in the most recent edition of Waterwise Florida Landscapes published by Florida's water management districts and as amended as shown in Table 30-10, Landscape Requirements. 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, open space and landscape areas shall be defined as follows and as specified in Division 3, Open space of this chapter. 
(1)  Open space: Any area of a development site not covered with buildings or vehicular use areas. Utility equipment pads and other "nonaccessible" spaces outside of a building shall not be considered open space. Areas of a site partially covered by trellises, loggias, pergolas, or other commonly used outdoor structures may be counted as open space. 
(e)  The following table governs landscape requirements for developments within the DMU:

Where possible, sidewalk cut-outs should be a minimum of 16 square feet (4 feet × 4 feet generally) and should contain 1 street tree or palm. The location of any sidewalk cut-out or freestanding planter shall be located so as to not obstruct the pedestrianway along the street. A minimum 8-foot wide pedestrianway should be maintained between any building and the street or parking area where possible. Planter requirements Where planters are used, a minimum requirement of 1 planter on each side of the entryway must be met. The planters must be at least 10" wide and 10" in depth and constructed in concrete, ceramic, clay, or like material and should be designed to compliment the building colors and architecture. Tree credits Per Section 5.7.4. Notes:

Sec. 30-392. - Spacing requirements. 
(a)  Plantings are measured as equivalent to the number per linear feet. However, plantings are required to be clustered, rather than placed in a right-of-way. Tree and plant spacing and size specifications shall be as follows: 
(1)  Overstory trees: Clusters are to be spaced no less than twenty-five (25) feet and no more than fifty (50) feet apart. Overstory trees shall constitute at least fifty (50) percent of the required trees. 
(2)  Palm trees: Palms shall be clustered in groups of at least three (3) and spaced no less than eight (8) feet apart and no more than fifteen (15) feet apart. Palm clusters may count as one (1) overstory tree. 
(3)  Understory trees: No less than eight (8) feet and no more than fifty (50) feet between trees or groups of trees. 
(4)  Shrubs/understory grasses: Planted on twenty-four (24) to thirty (30) inch centers. 
(5)  Ground cover: Shall be planted at spacing appropriate to achieve full coverage within six (6) months of planting. 
(6)  Turf: Use of turf is discouraged; however, where it is used, it shall be located to facilitate efficient irrigation with a minimum dimension of four (4) feet in any one direction. Turf may not be used in vehicular use areas. 
(b)  Required distances from walls, buildings, or sidewalk for in-ground plantings:

(a)  Landscape material size requirements:

Existing palm trees or those proposed to satisfy these requirements shall count as a ratio of two (2) palms = one (1) tree, unless otherwise noted in Section 30-393.

Sec. 30-395. - Irrigation. 
    Permanent underground irrigation systems shall be provided for all new landscape areas required by the code, except preserved areas of existing vegetation. Irrigation system design and installation shall follow the principles associated with Florida Green Industries June 2002, Best Management Practices for Protection of Water Resources in Florida, Florida Friendly yards and Low Impact Development, as amended. 
Secs. 30-396-30-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - SITE SUSTAINABILITY 

Sec. 30-401. - Sustainability, alternative energy, and green programs. 
    The City encourages the use of alternative energy design measures in all sign design, incorporating energy efficient lighting, solar energy for energy sources, recycled materials for cabinetry, [and] other appropriate technologies and techniques. The City may utilize and create an incentive program which would allow for enhanced sizes, heights, coverage areas, off-premises, or nontypical signage systems when an applicant proposes to incorporate such practices. 
Secs. 30-402-30-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONCURRENCY 

Sec. 30-411. - Development orders, approval and conditional approval. 
(a)  Rezoning applications and annexation requests may be approved; however, such approval shall be conditional in nature and shall not entitle the applicant to proceed with the development unless the public facilities are available concurrent with the impacts of development as provided in the City's Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(b)  Preliminary plats, preliminary plans, and nonresidential site plans may be conditionally approved; however, such approval shall be conditional in nature and shall not entitle the applicant to proceed with the development unless the public facilities are available concurrent with the impact of development as provided in the City's Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
(c)  Building permits, and final plats may be approved if a deficient public facility is scheduled for improvement in the annual capital improvements budget, or is under construction or is under contract for construction or is a part of a binding developers agreement requiring the construction of the public facility concurrent with the impacts of the proposed development, and the improvements will provide a level of service sufficient to accommodate the potential impact of the proposed development as set forth in the Titusville Comprehensive Plan as further provided in the City's Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual. 
Sec. 30-412. - Levels of service-Minimum levels of service established. 
    Level of service used from concurrency reviews are adopted for traffic circulations, potable water, sanitary sewer, recreation and open space, solid waste, stormwater/drainage, law enforcement and fire protection in the capital improvements element of the City of Titusville Comprehensive Plan. The minimum levels of service requirements and calculation methodologies are contained in Section 10 of the City's Concurrency Technical Design Manual. 
Sec. 30-413. - Annual concurrency report. 
(a)  At least once per year during the initiation of the capital improvement program/budget process, a concurrency management report will be drafted by the Administrator and forwarded to the Planning and Zoning Commission (acting as the Local Planning Agency) and the City Council. The report will serve as a summary of the current status of the concurrency management system and the capital improvement program, and provide for recommendations from the LPA and policy direction from the City Council. At a minimum the report shall contain: 
(1)  Update of capacities, demands, and existing levels of service for the public facilities and services set forth in the City's Transportation Infrastructure Technical Manual of these regulations. 
(2)  Summary and projections of expected development activities and their impact on capital improvement needs. 
(3)  The fiscal resources to be utilized to support identified needs and the feasibility of implementing new sources. 
(4)  Recommended changes, modifications or amendments to the schedule of improvements in the capital improvements element of the Comprehensive Plan and the Capital Improvements Program of the City. 
Sec. 30-414. - City of Titusville Proportionate Fair-Share Program. 
    Impacts of development on transportation facilities may be mitigated through the proportionate share program. The intent, methodology, submittal requirements, and review and approval procedures are in Section 10 of the City's Concurrency Technical Design Manual. The process and procedures in the Technical Design Manual can be used to apply for the proportionate fair-share program. 
Secs. 30-415-30-420. - Reserved. 
Chapter 31 - AGENCIES AND BOARDS 
ARTICLE I. - CITY COUNCIL 

Sec. 31-1. - Composition and authority. 
    The City Council of the City of Titusville is composed of a Mayor and four (4) councilmen and is the legislative body of the City and has the authority to adopt the comprehensive plan, future land use map, future traffic circulation map and amendments thereto. The City Council also has the authority to approve annexations, enact zoning changes, approve site plans and conditional uses as set forth therein. The City Council also has the authority to designate Boards and Commission as required by federal, state or other law and local need, including the Local Planning Agency (LPA). The City Council reserves all powers unless specifically delegated. 
Sec. 31-2. - Legislative powers and duties. 
    The City Council, when considering proposed changes in the text of these regulations, or in amending future land use map, the future traffic circulation map or the zoning map, or rezoning property or changing land use designation, acts in the legislative capacity and will proceed in accordance with the requirements of Section 163.3184 and Section 166.041, Florida Statutes (F.S.) (whichever is applicable) and Chapter 34, Procedures, Article IV, Site plans, and Article V, Variances and appeals, Division 2, Appeals to the Board of Adjustment, and Article VI, Nonconforming uses/structures and vested rights of these [Land Development] Regulations. All actions of the Council shall be deemed fairly debatable and the burden of proof shall be on those challenging the actions of the Council. 
Sec. 31-3. - Judicial powers and duties. 
    The City Council acts in a quasi-judicial capacity during public hearings where variances, appeals, conditional use permits, site-specific zoning changes, or other site-specific development orders are considered. Quasi-judicial does not include comprehensive rezoning or any Comprehensive Plan changes of any size. 
Sec. 31-4. - Special powers and duties. 
    Pursuant to Florida Statutes Section 163.357 (1989), the City Council is designated as the Community Redevelopment Agency for the City of Titusville. The Community Redevelopment Agency shall have all powers and duties as authorized by Sections 163.330-163.450, Florida Statutes. This provision hereby ratifies and reaffirms that previous Ordinance No. 2-1986. 
Sec. 31-5. - Ad hoc and advisory committees. 
(a)  The City Council may from time to time, based upon a majority vote of the membership, establish ad hoc committees to assist the Council in carrying out its responsibility. Said Ad Hoc Committee shall be limited to a particular subject area, and serve only in that capacity for a specific period of time. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prevent the City Council from establishing independent temporary, or ad hoc advisory groups, committees, or commissions to make recommendations on any issue directly to City Council. 
Sec. 31-6. - Appeal of Council decisions. 
    All decisions of the City Council whether zoning, annexation, conditional use, CPA or other approvals required by these [Land Development] Regulations shall be presumed correct and shall be final. Any substantially effected person may appeal the decision of the City Council to the Circuit Court in and for Brevard County, Florida. All appeals must be filed within thirty (30) days after the decision is rendered. All appeals shall be based upon the record before the City Council and not a trial de novo. All appeals shall be processed in accordance with the procedure set forth in the Florida Rules of Appellate Procedure for appeals from the County Court to the Circuit Court. 
Secs. 31-7-31-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATOR/ENFORCEMENT OFFICER 

Sec. 31-16. - The Administrator. 
    The Administrator of these [Land Development] Regulations shall be the City Manager or his designee. 
Sec. 31-17. - The Enforcement Officer. 
    The Enforcement Officer and Administrator may be the same individual or the Enforcement Officer or Code Enforcement Inspector may be such other member of City staff as designated by the Administrator. 
Sec. 31-18. - City staff, consultants. 
    In addition to the above powers and duties, the Administrator is responsible for allocation of City staff resources to the Boards and Commissions required by these [Land Development] Regulations, any necessary research (data and analysis), comprehensive planning, current planning, land use review, regulatory reviews and other administrative services related to development orders and the enforcement thereof. 
Sec. 31-19. - Administrative powers and duties. 
    Specific duties of the Administrator are normally performed by the Community Development Department or such other department that may be designated by the City Manager. Such duties include the processing and recommendations related to the following: 
(a)  The Comprehensive Plan; 
(b)  Land Development Regulations and codes including: 
(1)  The zoning ordinance; 
(2)  Zoning map changes; 
(3)  Subdivision plats; 
(4)  Site plans; 
(5)  Conditional land use requests; 
(6)  Engineering improvements; 
(7)  Concurrency management; 
(c)  Capital improvements program; 
(d)  Engineering inspections; 
(e)  Building inspections; 
(f)  Code compliance inspections; 
(g)  Occupational license inspections; 
(h)  Issuance of development orders; 
(i)  Issuance of building permits; 
(j)  Issuance of certificates of occupancy; 
(k)  Issuance of engineering permits; 
(l)  Administration of development fees and violation fines; 
(m)  Administration of city construction projects; 
(n)  Coordination of development activities with other agencies; 
(o)  Other projects as assigned by the Administrator. 
Secs. 31-20-31-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - THE PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION 

Sec. 31-31. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The Commission shall act in an advisory capacity to City Council in all matters affecting the Comprehensive Plan and serve as the Local Planning Agency (LPA) pursuant to Section 163.3174, Florida Statutes, the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act. 
(b)  The Commission shall recommend the study of resources and possibilities, and needs of the City, and shall review and recommend to City Council plans and maps for the systematic future development and betterment of the City and recommend such change(s) as are deemed advisable; and may recommend to the City Council the division of the City into districts or zones or the preparation of maps and plans of same, specifying and governing the height, area and manner of construction of buildings to be erected, altered or reconstructed in such zones. 
(c)  Before any new street is opened, or any existing street extended, widened, relocated, closed or vacated, or corrected within the corporate limits or planning jurisdiction of the City or before any new subdivision within the corporate limits of the City for residence, business or industrial uses is made, the person opening such street or proposing such new subdivision for residence, business, or industrial purposes, shall submit a detailed plan with blueprints and other necessary data to the Commission. It shall be the duty of the Commission to examine carefully the plans for such subdivision as regards their nature and purpose, the number, width, character and location of streets and alleys, and the size, material and manner of laying of water and sewer lines, and shall transmit such application with all data to the City Council with its recommendations in writing. 
(d)  The Commission shall have the duty of recommending the purposes for which buildings and premises therein may be used, and establishing rules governing building lines, and shall submit same to the City Council for its approval, approval with condition, or denial. 
(e)  Other duties that may be assigned by the City Council in furtherance of its legislative powers and in Chapter 34, Procedures of these [Land Development] Regulations and the specific needs of the City, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Review, recommend amendments to and monitor the Comprehensive Plan; 
(2)  Evaluate land development regulations and codes; 
(3)  Review and update the land use and zoning designations in the City, including interpretation of boundary lines and applicable areas; 
(4)  Evaluate rezoning requests and requests for changes in the future land use map/future traffic circulation map; 
(5)  Review proposed subdivisions; 
(6)  Interpretation of uses permitted; 
(7)  Review proposed Master Plans; 
(8)  Review plans that affect the shoreline district, the conservation district, the areas of critical concern, the flood plain areas, as provided for in these [Land Development] Regulations; and 
(9)  Hear site plan appeals. 
(f)  In addition to the above, it shall be the duty of each member of the Commission, if funds are made available by the City Council, to: 
(1)  Attend one (2) local, regional, or state planning conference during each two (2) years served; 
(2)  Attend one (1) staff sponsored field trip within the first year of each term served; 
(3)  Join a planning organization; 
(4)  Attend one (1) City Council meeting every three (3) months (regardless of funds); 
(5)  Attend workshop session conducted by the City staff for orientation of new members and other such workshops that may be called as necessary; and 
(6)  Familiarize themselves with the Comprehensive Plan and these Land Development Regulations and other sections of the City Code applicable to the Commission. 
(g)  None of the powers, duties or prerogatives of the Commission shall be construed to be in any way a limitation upon the duties, powers and prerogatives of the City Council, but in every case shall be subordinate and subject to the approval of the City Council. 
Sec. 31-32. - Appointment and terms of office. 
(a)  The Planning and Zoning Commission shall be composed of seven (7) regular members and two (2) alternates, each of which shall be a resident of the City of Titusville appointed by City Council. In addition to the Council appointments, one (1) non-voting member shall be appointed by the Brevard County School Board. Four (4) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed at the last regular meeting of the City Council in January of each even-numbered year, and three (3) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed at the last regular meeting of City Council in January of each odd-numbered year. 
(b)  The terms of all members appointed shall commence on January 31 and shall be for a period of two (2) years. The City Council shall fill any vacancy occurring on the Commission by appointment and such appointment shall be for the unexpired term of the vacancy. Any vacancy occurring during the unexpired term of office of the non-voting member shall be filled by appointment of the Brevard County School Board for the remainder of the term. Members may be appointed to successive terms without limitations. All members shall be residents of the City of Titusville for at least one (1) year, shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age and a registered voter in the City. 
(c)  Members of the Planning and Zoning Commission may be removed by majority vote of the City Council. 
(d)  Members of the Commission shall be appointed by City Council and whenever possible shall represent a well-balanced cross section of community interests. Members shall be appointed to represent environmental development and general public interests based upon education and/or experience in these areas. 
(e)  During the month of February of each year, the Commission shall elect a Chairman, Vice Chairman and Secretary from among its membership. 
Sec. 31-33. - Standing committees. 
    The Commission may establish a standing committee from its membership for environmental issues and such other issues or concerns that the Commission deems necessary. 
Sec. 31-34. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The Commission shall meet twice a month on the Wednesday proceeding the second and fourth Tuesday of the given month when there is business to conduct. The Chairman may, with due notice, cancel any meeting due to a lack of business. 
(b)  The Commission shall prescribe such rules of procedure and adopt such bylaws as may be necessary to carry into effect the duties and powers hereby granted, and may prescribe penalties for the non-attendance or disorderly conduct of its members and enforce the same. 
(c)  A majority of the Commission or standing committee (i.e. four (4) members) shall be necessary to constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. In the event more than seven (7) members (regular member and alternates) attend the meeting, no more than seven (7) members may sit and act on items presented to the Commission. The Chairman will determine which alternate members shall fill in for an absent regular member or when a regular member abstains from voting on an item due to a conflict of interest. The non-voting member may participate in discussions; however, non-voting members shall not make motions and may not be used to constitute a quorum. 
(d)  The affirmative vote of a majority of the sitting Commission at a meeting shall be required to pass any action of the Commission. If a majority vote in the affirmative is not made, the action shall be deemed to be denied. 
(e)  Minutes shall be kept of all Commission meetings. 
(f)  All Commission meetings, as well as the Commission members individually, shall be subject to the requirement of Chapter 286 F.S., the "Open Meeting or Sunshine Law." 
(g)  Agendas for each meeting shall be available to the public at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to any meeting of the Commission. 
(h)  Whenever the Commission is called upon to make recommendations concerning an annexation, a Comprehensive Plan Amendment (CPA), conditional-use permit, or a zoning amendment, the planning staff shall send written notice to adjoining property owners consistent with state law, but in any case no less than five hundred (500) feet from the subject property. The applicant shall be required to provide the names and addresses of all such property owners on mailing labels, most recently listed in the Brevard County Tax Rolls. Staff shall also place a conspicuous sign on said property stating the action requested and the date of the public hearing. Failure of a property owner within five hundred (500) feet to receive written notice shall not invalidate the action of the Commission or Council. 
(i)  Any standing committee created pursuant to Section 31-33 shall meet prior to the Commission meeting, in order to expedite the review and recommendation to the Commission on matters charged to said Committee. 
(j)  Members of the Commission may be reappointed to successive terms without limitation. 
Secs. 31-35-31-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARD OF ADJUSTMENTS AND APPEALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Code of Ordinances Reference- Enforcement of the standard code for the elimination or repair of unsafe buildings by the board of adjustments and appeals, § 6-117. 

Sec. 31-51. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The Board of Adjustments and Appeals shall have the power to hear and decide appeals of any decision, order, requirement or an interpretation of an administrative official of these [Land Development] Regulations, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Zoning of land and water use (Chapter 28, Zoning); 
(2)  Subdivision regulations (Chapter 34, Procedures); 
(3)  Protection of potable water well fields, the regulation of areas subject to seasonal and periodic flooding, drainage and stormwater management and the protection of environmentally sensitive lands (Chapter 30, Development standards); 
(4)  Signage; 
(5)  The provision of public facilities and service concurrent with the impacts of development, and; 
(6)  The provision of safe and convenient on-site traffic flow, including vehicle parking (Chapter 30, Development standards). 
(b)  The Board shall also hear and decide appeals and variances regarding the following: 
(1)  Building code, electrical code, fire prevention code, gas code, housing code, mechanical code, motion picture theaters ordinance, plumbing code, streets regulations, swimming pool regulation, as provided for in the Code of Ordinances, Volumes I, and II. 
(2)  Hear and decide requests for variance from these regulations in accordance with the procedures set forth in Chapter 34, Article V of these [Land Development] Regulations. 
(3)  Hear and decide conflicts between the minimum building code and minimum safety code as authorized by Section 553.73, Florida Statutes (1989), including any conflicts between the local building official and local fire official concerning the application or interpretation of the minimum building code and minimum safety code. 
(c)  Appeals, variances and interpretations, shall not extend to decisions of an administrative official relating to public projects; or public policy decisions made by the City Council. 
Sec. 31-52. - Appointment and terms of office. 
(a)  The Board of Adjustments and Appeals shall be composed of five (5) regular members and two (2) alternates. All members shall be residents of the City of Titusville for at least one (1) year and be a registered voter. Members of the Board shall consist of the following: 
(1)  At least three (3) of the regular members of the Board shall be persons with the following expertise/experience in at least one of the following disciplines: 
a.  A licensed architect, engineer, landscape architect or surveyor; 
b.  A general or building contractor; 
c.  A person associated with the building trades industries; 
d.  A person having an education degree (bachelor or master degree) in urban planning or with a current American Institute of Certified Planner certification; 
e.  A person with a minimum of ten (10) years' experience in land development or urban planning field. 
(2)  The other two (2) remaining members of the Board and the two (2) alternates may be appointed from the City citizenship at large. 
(b)  All five (5) regular members and the two (2) alternates of the Board shall be appointed by the City Council for two-year terms. There shall be appointed at the second regular meeting in July of each odd-numbered year three (3) regular members and one alternate for two-year terms, and in each even-numbered year, two (2) regular members and one alternate for two-year terms. The term of the members appointed shall commence on August 1, and shall be for a period of two (2) years or until their successors are appointed. 
(c)  The City Council shall fill any vacancy occurring on the Board, and such appointment shall be for the unexpired term of the vacancy. The alternate members may serve on the Board in lieu of a regular member when said regular member is unable to attend an official meeting of the Board or when a regular member has a conflict of interest on any item, and said alternate shall serve for the entire meeting. 
(d)  Members of the Board may be reappointed to successive terms without limitation. 
(e)  Members of the Board may be removed at the discretion of the City Council. If any member of the Board is convicted of a felony his position on the Board shall be forfeited immediately and his seat vacated. The seat of any member who is absent from three (3) or more meetings during any period of six (6) successive months shall be vacated, unless such absences are officially excused by a majority of the Board members. 
Sec. 31-53. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The Board shall establish rules and regulations of its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of these Land Development Regulations. The Board shall meet on the fourth Wednesday of every month or in any event frequent enough so that business of the Board may be expeditiously completed. 
(b)  Minutes shall be kept of all Board meetings. 
(c)  The Board shall conduct its meetings in accordance with the quasi-judicial procedures set forth in Chapter 34, Procedures, Articles V, Variances and Appeals, Division 1, Variances and Division 2, Appeals to the Board of Adjustment of these [Land Development] Regulations. 
(d)  All meetings of the Board shall be open to the public and the agenda for same shall be available to the public at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the meeting. 
(e)  Board members shall be subject to Chapter 286, Florida Statutes, the "Open Meetings Law." 
(f)  Four (4) members of the Board shall constitute a quorum. In varying the application of any of the provisions of any City ordinance or in modifying any order of any administrative City official, concurring votes of four (4) members of the Board shall be necessary. If four (4) concurring votes cannot be reached, the subject matter before the Board shall be considered denied. 
(g)  The procedure for a member to withdraw, abstain or be excused from voting is in accordance with Section 112.3143, Florida Statutes. 
Sec. 31-54. - Board of Adjustments and Appeals officers and staff.
