    Residential use: For purposes of the airport zoning ordinance, single-family dwellings, condominiums, townhouses, multifamily dwellings, including mobile homes, but not including hotels, motels, timeshares, transient lodgings, or employer-owned dwellings or other facilities primarily used by the employer's employees or contractors. 
    Restaurant: An establishment where food and beverages are ordered, prepared and served for pay. 
    Retail sales and services: Those business activities that customarily provide retail convenience goods. Such uses may include: department stores, variety stores, including retail pharmacies, however, excluding cash-only pharmacies, restaurants, delicatessens, cafeteria, grocery and markets, gift shops, wearing apparel, home and auto supply, furniture and appliances, hardware, package stores, cocktail lounges, taverns, newsstands, book and stationery stores, shoe repair shops, luggage shops, bakeries and candy shops (provided that products made on the premises are sold on the premises), camera and photo supply shops, radio and television sales and services, floor coverings, sporting goods, florists, jewelers, music and piano sales and services, art shops, pawnshops, electrical and lighting, laundry and dry cleaning pickup stations, coin-operated or self-service laundry, farm and garden supplies excluding farm machinery and equipment, pet shops, and similar uses. 
    Retention, stormwater: Facilities that prevent the discharge of a given volume of stormwater runoff into surface waters or the act of preventing same, by complete on-site storage of the given volume, which may only be reduced by a decrease of stored water caused only by percolation through soil, evaporation or evapotranspiration. 
    Right-of-way: Land reserved, used or to be used for a street, alley, walkway, drainage facility or other public use or service purpose and the title to which is in public ownership. 
    Roadway: That portion of a right-of-way improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a right-of-way includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Road tractor: Any motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon, either independently or as to any part to the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn. 
    School: Any building or group of buildings or part thereof which is designed, constructed or used for educational or instruction of any branch of knowledge. 
(a)  School; college/university: An educational institution authorized by the State of Florida, to award baccalaureate or higher degrees. 
(b)  School; elementary: Any school licensed by the State of Florida and which meets the State of Florida requirements for elementary education. Elementary school shall be from kindergarten to sixth grade. 
(c)  School; high school and/or secondary: Any school licensed by the State of Florida, which is authorized to award diplomas for high school and/or secondary education. High School and/or Secondary school shall be from ninth to 12th grades. 
(d)  School; Jr. high and/or middle: Any school licensed by the State of Florida and which meets the State of Florida requirements for Jr. high and/or middle school education. Jr. high and/or middle school shall be from sixth to ninth grades. 
(e)  School; parochial: A private school supported and controlled by a church or religious organization. 
(f)  School; private: Any building or group of buildings the use of which meets State of Florida requirements for elementary, Jr. high and/or middle, high/secondary school or higher education and which does not secure the major part of its funding from any government agency. 
(g)  School; vocational, trade and business: A higher educational facility above secondary school, teaching usable skills that prepare students for jobs in a trade and meeting the State of Florida requirements as a vocational facility. Such schools shall also include adult educational schools, business schools or professional schools. 
    Screen: A visual barrier which is one hundred (100) percent opaque to a height of at least six (6) feet. Said screen may be attained through the use of earth berms, hedges, fences, walls or any combination thereof. 
    Screened porch: An enclosure, at least one (1) wall of which is a common wall to the principal building, the remaining wall surface area consisting of screen mesh with no more than a thirty-two-inch splash wall. All walls, except those common to the principal building, shall provide for the free flow of air between the outside and the interior of the enclosure. 
    Seasonal high groundwater table: The highest level to which groundwater is expected to rise during the wet season. This level usually occurs between August and September and is often identified in the subsurface by soil staining. 
    Self-propelled mobile home: A self-propelled vehicle containing living facilities and includes the term "house-car" or "motor home." 
    Setback: The open space existing on the same lot with a principal building unoccupied and unobstructed by buildings from the ground to the sky, between the lot line and building line. Specific yard definitions as contained in these [Land Development] Regulations are defined as follows: 
(a)  Front setback: The area measured from the front lot line extending across the entire width of the lot. The lot line of a lot abutting a public street shall be deemed the front lot line. The front setback of a corner lot shall be that yard abutting the street with the least frontage, unless otherwise determined on a recorded plat or in a recorded deed. The front setback of a lot existing between two (2) streets not intersecting at a corner of the lot shall be that area abutting the street on which adjoining properties face, unless determined on a recorded plat or in a recorded deed. 
(b)  Rear setback: The area measured from the rear lot line extending across the entire width of the lot. The rear lot line shall be the lot line farthest removed from the front lot line. 
(c)  Side setback: The area measured from the side lot line extending from the front setback to the rear lot line. 
(d)  Corner setback: The side yard area abutting a public or private street and extending from the front setback line to the rear lot line. 
    Setback line: The line established by setback requirements outside of which no building may be erected. 
    Shipping container: A standardized, reusable metal vessel that originally was designed for, or used in, packing, shipping, movement or transportation of freight, articles, goods for commodities by commercial trucks, trains and/or ships. 
    Shrub: Any low, self-supporting woody plant as normally grown in Brevard County, Florida. 
    Side yard: See Yard, side. 
    Sign: See Chapter 32, Signs, Article, I, General sign regulations, Division 1, General provisions, Section 32-2, Definitions. 
    Single-family residential area: Any portion of the City divided into lots intended to contain a single dwelling unit designed for occupancy by one (1) family. 
    Single-family dwelling (detached): A detached building on a single lot containing one (1) dwelling unit, or a factory assembled structure constructed to state building code standards. 
    Site plan: The plan required to acquire a development, construction, building or stormwater permit or development order which shows the means by which the developer will conform with these regulations. 
    Site-related improvements: Capital improvements, landscaping, grading and roadway improvements to the development in question. Direct access improvements, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Site driveways and internal roads; 
(2)  Right and left turn lanes leading to those driveways or internal roads; 
(3)  Traffic-control measures and devices for those driveways and internal roads; 
(4)  Median cuts and landscaping; 
(5)  Drainage and stormwater management systems; and 
(6)  Other improvements in the public right-of-way necessitated by the development to facilitate direct access to the development and compliance with these regulations. 
    Skateboard ramps: An outdoor structure whether or not permanently affixed to the ground that has a semi-circular, or semi oval shape, or more than one (1) surface and that is intended or used to permit persons on skateboards or roller skates to move continuously from one (1) side to another. 
    Sketch plat: A rough sketch map of a proposed subdivision of sufficient accuracy to be used for the purpose of discussion and classification, meeting the requirements of Section 34-152, "Required submittals and exhibits". 
    Small-scale plat: The division of a single parcel of land into three (3) but less than ten (10) lots meeting the requirements of Section 34-143. Per Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, the division of land into three (3) or more lots requires the subdivider to follow the platting process. 
    Solid wastes: Garbage, rubbish, refuse, bulky items and other discarded materials, including materials resulting from residential habitation, industrial, commercial and/or agricultural operations, and from community activities. The term "waste" shall be synonymous with "solid waste," and shall include recyclable materials. 
    Sound level: The weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of a metering characteristic and weighting A, B or C, as specified in American National Standards Institute (ANSI) specification for sound level meters, and measured in decibels (db) (ANSI 551.4-1979). If not indicated, the A-weighting shall apply. (Also includes sound pressure level.) 
    Stage: A specified portion of the planned unit development that may be developed as an independent entity that is delineated in the preliminary master density plan and final master development plan and specified within the development schedule. 
    Stormwater management system: Refers to all public facilities, manmade structures, and all natural watercourses which collect, convey, store, constrain or divert the movement of stormwater to reduce flooding and water quality degradation. 
    Story: That portion of a building included between the upper surface of a floor and the upper surface of the floor or roof next above. 
    Street: Any public or private right-of-way set aside for public travel thirty (30) feet or more in width. The word "street" shall also include the words "road, avenue, boulevard, lane, drive, circle, court, way, arterial and highway." For the purpose of this definition the word "street" shall also include "street system" a group of public rights-of-way functionally classified on the future traffic circulation map as follows: 
(a)  Accessway: An improved area intended to provide ingress and egress of vehicular traffic between a public street and required off-street parking areas serving more than one (1) residential unit. 
(b)  Alley: Any public or private right-of-way set aside for public travel less than thirty (30) feet in width. 
(c)  Cul-de-sac: A dead-end street, terminated by a turnaround, which provides access only to abutting properties. 
(d)  Highways: Those traffic routes officially designated as federal or state highway routes. 
(e)  Local streets: Those streets which function primarily to provide access and service to abutting properties. This includes access and service to residential, business, industrial and public uses. 
(f)  Major arterials: Those routes intended to carry relatively heavy volumes of traffic for major distances through the Titusville area. Also includes the term "principal arterial" and are generally state and federal numbered roadways. 
(g)  Major collectors: Those streets designed to carry medium volumes of traffic, provide access to major and minor arterials, and collect traffic from intersecting local streets. 
(h)  Marginal access streets: Those streets parallel to and adjacent to limited access highways and arterials which provide access to abutting properties. These streets are designed to protect the abutting properties from the danger of rapid arterial traffic and to protect the arterials and highways from the danger created by numerous points of conflict created by driveways and individual access to abutting properties. 
(i)  Minor arterials: Those routes intended to carry relatively heavy volumes of local traffic for intermediate distances. 
(j)  Minor collectors: Those streets designed to carry lower volumes of traffic and provide access to other streets as well as some access to abutting properties. 
(k)  Private streets: Those streets not located in a public right-of-way and not accepted by the city for repair or maintenance, as may be permitted by these regulations. 
    Street furniture: Any manmade, above-ground items that are usually found in street rights-of-way, including benches, kiosks, plants, canopies, shelters and phone booths. 
    Structure: That which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner and required to be affixed to the ground; but shall not include fences or signs. 
    Subdivider: Any person, firm, association, syndicate, partnership, or corporation who owns land which is divided or developed into a subdivision as herein defined. The term "subdivider" shall include the term "developer," his duly authorized agent or representative, and shall include the word "person" as defined herein. 
    Subdivision: All divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two (2) or more lots, building sites, or other divisions of land. The term "subdivision" includes re-subdivision (minor adjustment or vacation of property lines which reallocates or consolidates land area of contiguous lots or parcels), and when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided, provided, however, that the following shall not be included within this definition nor be subject to these [Land Development] Regulations: 
(a)  The combination (consolidation into fewer number) or recombination (new configuration or consolidation) of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased, the resultant lots are equal to or exceed the standards of the City as required by these regulations and necessary adjustments in utilities and site improvements meet the approval of the Public Works Official. 
(b)  The public acquisition of strips of land for the widening or opening of streets. 
    Major subdivision: The division of land (parcels or tracts) into three (3) or more lots in conformity with the requirements of the zoning district applicable to the lots created. This shall also include the creation, opening or dedication of public streets, or any change in an existing public street. The following shall not be considered subdivisions: 
(a)  Lot split. 
(b)  The combination or recombination of lots or parcels, when the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to or exceed the requirements of the zoning district in which they are located. 
(c)  The public acquisition of strips of land for the widening or opening of streets pursuant to official action of the City Council. 
    Submerged lands: Any naturally occurring or manmade water bodies, including rivers, streams, lakes, ponds, and canals, generally characterized as any area within a clearly defined literal [littoral] zone containing water on a year-round basis. 
    Take-out/non-seating restaurant: An establishment that offers take-out or delivery of food or beverages but does not permit customers to dine in. 
    Temporary (or portable) storage units: Transportable units designed and used primarily for temporary storage of building materials, household goods, personal items and other materials for use on a limited basis on residential and commercial properties. This definition does not include storage sheds authorized by the Florida Building Code pursuant to Section 553.73, Florida Statutes. Truck bodies and semi-trailers are prohibited. 
    Temporary use: A use established for a fixed period of time, with the intent to discontinue such use upon the expiration of the time period. 
    Tree: Any self-supporting, woody plant or palm having at least one (1) well-defined stem of a minimum dbh caliper of two (2) inches. 
    Townhomes: A one-family dwelling in a row of at least three (3) such units in which each unit has its own front and rear access to the outside, no unit is located above or below another unit. 
    Toxic substances: Hazardous wastes as defined in Chapter 17-730, F.A.C., hazardous substances as defined in the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, Pub. L, No. 96-510, 94-510, 94 Stat. 2767; a pollutant as defined in Chapter 376, Florida Statutes; a substance which is or is suspected to be carcinogenic, mutagenic, teratogenic, or toxic to human beings, or to be acutely toxic as described in Rule 17-3.021(1) F.A.C.; or a substance which poses a serious danger to the public health, safety or welfare. 
    Trailers: Any portable or movable structure or vehicle including trailers designated for living quarters, offices, storage or for moving or hauling freight, equipment, or merchandise of any kind. 
    Transient accommodation: A dwelling unit or other accommodation used as a dwelling unit or other place of human habitation with sleeping accommodation which is rented, leased or subleased for less than monthly periods or which is subject to time sharing pursuant to applicable law for less than monthly time share periods. Transient accommodations shall include hotels, motels and similar uses if used as dwelling units and/or residence for more than one (1) month. A transient accommodation shall be considered a residential use. An accommodation is not a transient accommodation if it is rented, leased or subleased for periods longer than one (1) month. 
    Transitional area: A setback area which acts as a buffer between two (2) land uses of different intensity. 
    Transit oriented development: Mixed-use villages and centers that promote pedestrian and transit travel being located within walking distance of a transit stop and core commercial area. 
    Travel trailers: A vehicular, portable structure having no foundation other than wheels, or jacks, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling unit for travel, recreational and vacation uses, which: 
(1)  Is identified on the unit or classified by the manufacturer as a travel trailer; and 
(2)  Is not more than eight (8) feet in body width; and 
(3)  Is of any weight provided its body length does not exceed thirty-two (32) feet; or 
(4)  Is of any length provided its gross weight, factory equipped for the road, does not exceed five thousand (5,000) pounds; and 
(5)  Also, see "camper trailer." 
    Travel trailer park: A place in which sites are rented for the placement of travel trailers, camper trailers, or other recreation vehicles (including tents) for use as temporary living quarters. 
    Tree caliper: A measurement used in purchasing or planting trees which is the diameter of a tree measured twelve (12) inches above the ground. 
    Truck stop plaza: A site oriented to the service of trucks, including the sale of fuel to truck drivers, and provision for support facilities for truck drivers. They may also be utilized by non-truck traffic and the interstate traveler. Business activities which are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to the truck stop or travel plaza, may include, but not be limited to: scales, truck wash, tire repair and sales, barber shop, restaurant with or without alcohol service, shower facility, convenience store, truckers lounge (for services such as television, exercise, internet access, et cetera), laundry, and vehicle fuel. The facility may allow for overnight parking (excluding for the loading and unloading of cargo) of commercial motor vehicles which are en-route to or from a destination along an interstate freeway system, for free or a fee that may be independent of any other use on the premises. The term "truck" shall mean a commercial vehicle driven by an operator who is required to have a Class "A" CDL (Commercial Driver's License) or equivalent. 
    Twenty-five-year storm: That storm which has a one-in-twenty-five probability or a four-percent chance of occurring in any year. 
    Unity of title: A document recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court of the County, stipulating that a lot, lots, or parcel of land shall be held under single ownership, shall not be eligible for further subdivision, and shall not be transferred, conveyed, sold, or divided, in any unit other than in its entirety. 
    Urban plazas: An area used for passive recreational activities and relaxation. Plazas may be improved, landscaped, or paved areas typically provided with amenities, such as seating, drinking, ornamental fountains, art, trees, and landscaping for use by pedestrians. 
    Vacant: A building or parcel of land shall be deemed vacant when it is neither occupied nor used, or when it is in a nonoperative status. 
    Variance: A relaxation of the terms of these regulations where such variance will not be contrary to the public interest and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of the actions of the applicant, a literal enforcement of these regulations would result in unnecessary and undue hardships. 
    Vehicle accommodation area: That portion of a lot that is used by vehicles for access, circulation, parking, and loading and unloading. It comprises the total of circulation areas, loading and unloading areas, and parking areas (spaces and aisles). 
    Vehicle-for-hire establishments: An establishment where vehicles-for-hire are stored and maintained. These establishments may include administrative and dispatch offices and areas for vehicle repair and maintenance. 
    Vehicle sales: The use of any building, land area or other premise for the display and sale of new or used automobiles, panel trucks or vans, trailers, or recreation vehicles, as defined in Section 320.01, Florida Statutes. 
    Vehicle service and repair: Any building, structure, improvements, or land used for the repair and maintenance of vehicles including, but not limited to, body, fender, muffler, or upholstery work, oil change and lubrication, painting, tire service and sales, and installation of car alarms or stereo equipment. 
    Veterinarian: As defined by Section 474.202, Florida Statutes. 
    Videogame arcades: Any electric or electronic machine (e.g. pinball, videogames) which provides amusement, enjoyment, or entertainment and which may be operated upon the insertion of a coin or token. This shall not include arcade amusement centers or electronic gaming establishments. 
    Vine: Any group of woody or herbaceous plants which may climb by twining, by means of aerial rootlets or tendrils, or which may simply sprawl over the ground. 
    Vocational school: See "School." 
    Warehousing/wholesale: The display, storage, and sale of goods to other firms for resale, as well as activities involving significant movement and storage of products or equipment, including truck terminal or bus servicing facilities, motor freight transportation, moving and storage facilities, warehousing, and storage activities. 
    Water detention structure/water management structure: A facility which provides for storage of stormwater runoff and the controlled release of such runoff during and after a flood or storm. 
    Water table aquifer: An aquifer with an unconfined upper surface, that is, a free surface where the fluid pressure equals atmospheric pressure or zero gage pressure; also known as a phreatic or unconfined aquifer, it is the uppermost aquifer and can receive direct recharge by infiltration from the ground surface. 
    Well: Any excavation that is drilled, cored, bored, washed, driven, dug, jetted, or otherwise constructed when the intended use of such excavation is to conduct ground water from a source bed to the surface, by pumping or natural flow, when ground water from such excavation is used or to be used in a public utility potable water supply wellfield. 
    Wetlands: Land with either, fresh or salt water marshes, swamps, bogs, and wet woodlands, whether flooded at all times, flooded only seasonally, or having a water table within six (6) inches of the ground surface for at least three (3) months of the year. Also defined as areas which support a dominance of wetland vegetation type listed in the rules of the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, Chapter 17-4.02(17) and (19) and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Wetland Maps. 
    Yard, front: A space extending the full width of the lot between the principal building and the front lot line, and measured perpendicular to the building at the closest point to the front lot line. 
    Yard, rear: A space extending across the full width of the lot between the principal building and the rear lot line, and measured perpendicular to the building to the closest point of the rear lot line. 
    Yard, side: A space extending from the front yard to the rear yard between the principal building and the side lot line measured perpendicular from the side lot line to the closest point of the principal building. 
    Zoning map: Shall mean the official zoning map of the City of Titusville, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 30-2017, § 2, 10-24-17; Ord. No. 44-2017, § 6, 12-12-17; Ord. No. 5-2018, § 3, 2-13-18; Ord. No. 33-2018, § 4, 7-24-18; Ord. No. 50-2018, § 2, 11-13-18) 
Secs. 37-2-37-10. - Reserved.
